PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Sex Discrimination Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 55 citizens), Childs (from 37 citizens) and Richardson (from 34 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that WHEREAS the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And WHEREAS the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
(5) Subjecting Australia to monitoring and control by foreign nations.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 59 citizens) and Lewis (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that the Tertiary Education Allowance Scheme (TEAS Allowance) has been progressively reducing in real terms throughout the 1980s, and is no longer at an adequate subsistence level.
2. that the situation where the independent TEAS allowance is substantially below the single, no dependant, unemployment benefit is inequitable and not supportable by cost relativities.
3. that the low level of TEAS allowance is detrimental to maintaining the proportion of students currently partaking in tertiary education.
4. that effective immediately the TEAS allowance should be increased to the same level as the single unemployment benefit and thereafter be maintained in line with changes in said benefits.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adelaide-Darwin Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That in 1911, as part of its new responsibility for the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth accepted a binding legislative commitment to construct a railway from Adelaide to Darwin-a promise which has never been fulfilled.
The lack of essential transport links has had, and continues to have, serious consequences for the economic and social development for the Northern Territory, and indeed all of Australia.

That the future expansion of new industries in the Territory and new trade opportunities for Australia, particularly with South-East Asia and the Western Pacific, depend on the development of the railway to link the port of Darwin with the rest of Australia. The railway is therefore an essential national project related directly to Australia's overall prospects for all future economic growth.
We therefore protest the Commonwealth's continuing failure to construct the railway.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Prime Minister and Members of the Federal Government honour the promise made by the Commonwealth over 70 years ago , the promise made by the previous Commonwealth Government this year, and endorsed by the present Government in opposition to complete the construction of the railway by 1988, Australia's Bicentennial year. We call on the Prime Minister to give his personal assurance that the Commonwealth will honour its past and present promises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Mart Niklus
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That we are deeply concerned for the well-being of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist who is in ill health and imprisoned in solitary confinement in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36 in Siberia.
(2) That Mr Mart Niklus has been imprisoned as a 'prisoner of conscience' for the non-violent exercise of his beliefs and is denied visiting and communication rights.

(3) That the Australian Government give its support to any initiatives in this case by Amnesty International which has adopted Mr Mart Niklus. Amnesty International believes he has committed no real crime and has never used or advocated the use of violence.
(4) That we urge the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly release Mr Mart Niklus and grant him a passport and exit visa.
(5) That in its representations to the Government of the Soviet Union advise that the Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADELAIDE CONVENTION CENTRE-HOTEL COMPLEX AND OFFICE BLOCK

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Hamer proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to come to a decision on the long term future of uranium mining in Australia, and the importance of that decision to the economic development of this country.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that we are debating today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to come to a decision on the long term future of uranium mining in Australia, and the importance of that decision to the economic development of this country.

This is the third time that the Opposition has been forced to raise, as a matter of public importance or as an urgency motion, the subject of the Labor Government's total confusion on the question of the mining and export of uranium -and we shall raise it again and again until the Government finally stops shilly -shallying and appeasing its crazies and gets around to making a clear decision in the national interest.

At the very moment, uranium is the tenth largest export earner for Australia- tenth behind coal, wool, meat, iron ore, aluminium, wheat, sugar, grain and nickel. In 1982-83 uranium earned $360m in export income for Australia. It must be remembered that we have hardly begun in this industry. We are sitting on nearly half of the world's readily recoverable uranium reserves and about one quarter of the world's total uranium reserves. These are inescapable facts. In this decade we have the opportunity to develop an industry generating export earnings of $1 billion a year. At the moment we have two operating uranium projects. Together they produce close to 4,000 tonnes of uranium a year, equal to 10 per cent of the West's present nuclear power station consumption. These projects are Energy Resources of Australia's Ranger mine and Queensland Mines Ltd Nabarlek mine and each has the capacity to produce and sell more uranium.

Nuclear power stations account at present for more than 10 per cent of the world's electricity. According to the International Atomic Energy Authority, at the end of 1982 there were 294 operating nuclear power stations in 25 countries with a generating capacity of 173,000 megawatts. At the end of last year, an additional 215 nuclear power stations were under construction in 27 countries. I have here a table which shows the proportion of electricity generated from nuclear power in various countries. At the head of the list is Finland with 40.3 per cent, followed by Sweden, a country that the Labor Party often sets up as a model, with 39 per cent, France with 38.7 per cent, Switzerland with 28.2 per cent and so on. I seek leave to have that table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —The United States of America was the largest producer of uranium in the world until last year when it was superseded by Canada. In the United States there is no doubt that the nuclear power industry and uranium mining industry are in deep trouble. That has nothing to do with safety. It is because the Americans are extremely litigious people and they have enmeshed themselves in a web of laws and regulations which makes sensible development of their energy resources almost impossible. I can see why. A recent poll showed that 60 per cent of American people believed that under certain circumstances a nuclear power station can blow up like an atom bomb. Everyone with the slightest technical knowledge knows that this is quite impossible.
—What about a fast breeder?
—I am talking about existing nuclear power stations.
—A fast breeder will blow up.

—I will come to fast breeders in a moment. I am talking about existing nuclear power stations. The American people believe that under certain circumstances they can blow up and if they believe that, which is absolute nonsense, it is not surprising that they do not want them as neighbours. They have been able to tie up the whole nuclear power industry in America in a web of litigation. But this is not happening in the rest of the world. Look at Finland, look at Sweden, look at Switzerland. The nuclear power industry is growing and will continue to grow. I repeat that the United States was the largest producer of uranium in the world until last year when it was superseded by Canada. There are only four other countries in the West with significant resources in uranium. Australia is one. The others are in Africa. South Africa will supplant the United States as the world's second largest producer of uranium fairly soon. The other three uranium producers are Namibia, Niger and Gabon. Our two major competitors, as production in the United States declines, are Canada and South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the problems for Australia while the Government shilly-shallies on this very important natural resource? We had potential mining of uranium by Pancontinental Mining Ltd. That company was approached last year from British Power Utilities for supplies from its 200,000 tonne Jabiluka uranium deposit. The company cannot get permission to export and the British will now buy from South Africa. One of the managers of M.I.M. Holdings Ltd recently commented that while the Government equivocates and the anti-uranium demonstrators demonstrate, 'those of us in the mining industry only hear the popping of champagne corks in the board rooms of Toronto and Johannesburg'. Those people will be the chief beneficiaries if Australia ceases to mine uranium.

Western Mining and BP Australia have spent $90m so far and have uncovered what could be the largest mine in the world. It contains more than 30 million tonnes of copper, one million tonnes of uranium, one million kilograms of gold and seven million kilograms of silver. There is a catch-it will not be economic unless all the minerals are extracted. The Olympic Dam project covers 20 square kilometres on Roxby Downs station. With the mine in operation there will be permanent jobs for as many as 8,000 workers, with export earnings from this project alone matching the total present export sales of the Australian sugar industry. The present situation in the uranium industry seems to be fairly good and the future certainly even more so, so what is the problem? The problem is that this Government cannot make up its mind. In 1982 the Australian Labor Party platform made a categorical statement on uranium:
. . . a Labor government will--
a declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;
b repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor Government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium;

That was in 1982. Yet in May of this year the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, signed a communique from the meeting of the International Energy Agency which 'stressed the importance of encouraging stable trade in nuclear equipment, fuel cycle services and nuclear fuel'. In June this year the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, announced:

The Government will allow two uranium mining companies, i.e. the two I have already mentioned, Energy Resources of Australia and Queensland Mines to negotiate for sales of uranium to the United States.

So we have the situation where the Labor Government's Cabinet favours the writing of further sales contracts for uranium and also the development of the Olympic Dam project on Roxby Downs. But the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has also said:
Of course the policy within the ALP will be given effect to by me when in Government.

Of course he has already broken the ALP platform by continuing to export uranium to the United States. What will be the decision of this Government? Will it be forced to wait until July of next year, since the ALP platform can be changed only at the Federal Conference? It is a dilemma for the Prime Minister but it is an even worse dilemma for Australia.

Why do members of the ALP, or perhaps the left wing of that Party, so ardently oppose the mining and export of uranium? Why do they not object, say, to the mining and export of coal? The mining of uranium as it is conducted in Australia now is one of the safest mining operations. It is far safer than the underground mining of coal-in fact, about 100 times safer. One has only to recall the tragedy at the Appin colliery when 14 miners were killed. Imagine the outcry there would have been had that happened in a uranium mine. This was only one of typical accidents in coal mines. All uranium mines in Australia are open cut mines and the risks in uranium open cut mining are well established. They are the lowest of any of the available sources of energy. I have here a table which shows 16 non-nuclear energy related accidents that occurred during 1982. I wonder whether any honourable senators have heard of any of them-a coal mine explosion, 17 killed; an oil line explosion in Mexico, 8 killed; an oil rig sank off Newfoundland, 84 killed; a coal mine collapsed; a hydro-electric dam collapsed in Libya, killing 200; a coal mine explosion in Poland killed 18; and an oil-fired power station explosion in Venezuela killed 145. I doubt if any honourable senator noticed any of them, yet when there was an accident, in which no one was killed and no one was injured, in the nuclear power station at Three Mile Island, we had world headlines. We have very selective and misleading judgment. What we have to look at is the relative cost in human life, in suffering and in the shortening of life by the various means of power generation -a point I will come to in a moment.

Coming back to mining, rational people cannot object to the mining of uranium on safety grounds when they do not oppose coal mining, which is far more dangerous. They cannot object rationally, if they look at any figures and any studies, because of the supposed long term health risk to uranium miners. There has been the most intensive study in connection with radiation and subsequent cancers. Uranium miners, by the way, are exposed to very low doses of radiation because in fact uranium is not very radioactive. If they object to the risk, not to us but to the people who are going to operate nuclear power stations overseas , this may be noble minded but it is misguided.

Nuclear power stations have been in operation in Britain for a quarter of a century. An intensive study was made of all the available long term nuclear power workers. The health of nuclear power workers was in every respect, including cancer, found to be marginally better than that of their peer group in the community. If we are concerned about the way in which other countries might use our exports, let us look at the safety facts with regard to nuclear power generation. I am indebted to Lord Rothschild, the former head of the British Labour Government's think tank, for a table that shows the estimated deaths and the shortening of lives for a specified energy output from various sources. Put simply, the table shows that the estimated number of deaths for the production of 10 gigawatt years of energy would be coal, 800; oil, 700; wind, 450; hydro, 100; solar or space heating, 95; and uranium, 8 1/2. Coal is 100 times as dangerous as power generated by uranium; wind is 60 times as dangerous; and solar power is 12 times as dangerous.

Every method of power generation, of course, has its risks. One might think that hydro-electric power generation is nice and safe, but it is, as I pointed out, about 12 times as dangerous as generating the same amount of power by nuclear power stations. In recent years two large hydro-electric dams have collapsed, one in France which caused 420 deaths, and one in Italy which caused more than 2,000 deaths. The generation of power by nuclear means is the safest method available for large scale power generation anywhere in the world. So if we assume that people opposed to nuclear power are rational, there must be other reasons for their objections. Do they object because there have been problems in the past with the disposal of nuclear waste materials? I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the current situation in regard to the disposal of high level nuclear waste.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The possibilities for disposal being considered are placing the blocks on or under the bed of the ocean or in deep geological formations on land. Research into the feasibility of ocean disposal and drilling programme to investigate the properties of certain rock formations and the feasibility of geological disposal .

At the National Reactor Testing Station in Idaho, acidic wastes are stored in stainless steel tanks prior to calcination; calcined wastes are stored in stainless steel bins. Most high activity wastes from this plant were made alkaline and are stored in a mild steel tank but small quantities of special wastes are stored in a stainless steel tank. The Barnwell Nuclear Services Plant in South Carolina is awaiting authorization to commence operation.

All high activity wastes are to be solidified as soon as practicable. Long-term options being evaluated including storage in existing tanks or vaults, storage on-site in underground caverns, or shipment to off-site federal repository. Industrial scale plant to vitrify wastes is expected to begin operation in the 1980s. Storage of solidified waste in near-surface facilities and deep geological disposal concepts are being studied.

TALK.START.PARA: —The solution envisaged in all countries is to deposit the waste in a mine repository. The technology to drill very deep holes-as deep as four kilometres or more, with diameters up to three metres-has recently become available. A series of holes of this nature offers very considerable possibility for nuclear waste disposal.
—Possibility?
—Yes. It is a certainty, actually.
—Make up your mind.
—It is not the only solution. I say it is a possible solution; there are a number of solutions which are all viable. To quote A. E. Ringwood:

SPEECH.PARA: Initially immobilise waste in Synroc, then deposit the synroc cylinders in the bottom 2,500 metres of such a hole, and finally seal the upper 1,500 metres. A single hole of these dimensions is capable of accepting the waste from one hundred large nuclear power stations operating for a year.

There is no technological problem in dealing with waste. There is a social problem because of widespread ignorance and exaggeration of the risks involved, and that is a task for all of us to overcome. Does the Australian Labor Party object to the mining and export of uranium because of fear of its use for nuclear weapons? I have repeatedly stated in this chamber and elsewhere that if I thought that Australia, by refusing to mine uranium, could in the slightest degree reduce the risk of nuclear war or the spread of nuclear weapons, I would be the most ardent advocate of leaving uranium in the ground. Whether we leave our uranium in the ground or not, there are at present between 40,000 and 50,000 nuclear weapons in the world. Whether we mine uranium or not will not make the slightest difference to their existence. They are there. They have none of our uranium in them. Any country wanting nuclear weapons can get uranium out of sea water if it has to. The cost of uranium is trivial when compared with the cost of nuclear weapons.

If we are worried that somehow we might export uranium that might be put in a nuclear weapon, why do we not ban the export of iron ore because steel might be used in a nuclear weapon, or aluminium because aluminium might be used in the vehicle carrying the nuclear weapon? The attitude of some of these people is the most incredible nonsense we can imagine. Whether we like it or not there is a great deal of uranium in the world.

If we wanted to, we could create an artificial shortage. But if we do cease exporting uranium we will have even less effect on the availability or the use of nuclear weapons. At least if we are an exporter we will have some effect on the enrichment of uranium into weapons grade material. It is not a perfect system; no one could claim that it is. But at least it is something. By being an exporter we have some chance of influencing the way it is used. If we did somehow manage to create an artificial shortage of uranium for power generation, all we would do would be to force countries into reprocessing their waste material or to go in for the fast breeder reactor.The way to avoid either of those-both of which would create free plutonium, of great danger to the whole world-would be to have uranium available reliably and readily. If we do not do that, if we create an artificial shortage or uncertainty of supply, other countries will not go in for nuclear power stations; they will go in for reprocessing or developing fast breeder reactors.

I think it is time that the Australian Labor Party and the Government realised that they have moral and economic obligations in the mining and export of uranium. In relation to mining, not only is there the opportunity for the creation of a very large number of jobs but also exporting uranium is the only opportunity that Australia can have in influencing a degree of control over safeguards and the reprocessing of nuclear material. It is not enough for Senator Walsh to say that the price is not right at the moment. This is nonsense . The price is firm and rising. In any case, that is not a matter for governments. Governments are bad predictors. Let the people who want to take the risk make the decision. If they want to take the risk of mining uranium that is a decision which they should make. The Government should not back-seat drive them in that area. We must not allow our policies to be decided by fears, ignorance or political manipulation.

There can be no dispute that uranium mining and export will create many jobs and will effect a substantial improvement in our balance of payments at a time when we desperately need something to balance our oil import bill. But, beyond this, we have responsibilities to the rest of the world. We have three moral questions which we must ask ourselves. The first question we must ask ourselves is: Have we the right to decide for other countries whether they should use nuclear power generation, or is that a decision for the governments of the countries concerned? The second question is: Have we the right to neglect to use our power to improve nuclear safeguards and to prevent the world from moving into the plutonium age, with all its attendant dangers? The third moral question which we must ask is whether this country, with 0.4 per cent of the world's population, has the right to deny the rest of the world access to 25 per cent of its most important energy source. I submit that the answer to each of these questions must be an unequivocal no. A responsible government must make the decision to make our uranium available for the world. This is one of those rare cases where our moral duty to the world and our own economic interest coincide. The Government has a duty to make an early and clear decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the claim that the Opposition has raised once again that it is a matter of public importance that there is an urgent need for the Government to come to a decision on the long term future of uranium mining in Australia, and the importance of that decision to the economic development of this country. When Senator Hamer introduced this matter of public importance he said that the Opposition-the Liberal and National parties-would raise this issue again and again in this chamber as it has done so many times before. How true, and how tedious it is becoming. Three times in as many sitting weeks the Opposition, which is bereft of ideas on how this country ought to be developing and on alternatives as to the government of this country, brings up this one issue on which it thinks it can embarrass the Government. It cannot. I will explain why it cannot as the debate progresses.

SPEECH.PARA: I ought to say also why this subject has been submitted as a matter of public importance today. Yesterday, on broadcast day, no matter of public importance was brought on for discussion. The Senate has decided, quite extraordinarily, to meet tomorrow, on a Friday and then to meet on Friday fortnight to get through the urgent business which the electorate expects us to deal with so that we may get through a certain amount of legislation in the Government's program before Christmas. As we all know from around the corridors last night, the Opposition is demonstrating petulance at the fact that yesterday evening the Government would not agree to the program which the Opposition wanted to force on this chamber last night in relation to the Budget debate. So what we have here is a petulant matter of public importance designed to disrupt the progress of business in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the first MPI of the week.

—I am coming to that. Whilst it might be mildly disruptive of the work of the chamber, it will not be disruptive of the due deliberate consideration of this matter by this Government. What we say-of course, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) touched on this in answer to a question yesterday in relation to another matter-is that within the Parliamentary Labor Party we will not be stampeded. We have our internal democratic processes which ensure that Ministers alone do not make decisions on the basis of professional advisers submitting briefs to them. Rather, the committees of the Parliamentary Labor Party will have access to the best possible advice before the Parliamentary Labor Party comes to a decision, which will accord with the policy of the Party. As I say, we will not be stampeded on these matters. When we have completed our internal review we will come to a decision. We are taking time over that internal review precisely because we see the importance of the issues involved. We can contrast that absolutely with the attitude of honourable senators opposite in the Liberal and National parties-of course, I exclude the Australian Democrats on this issue-because they want fast decision making and hasty decision making.
—Anything for a quick quid.

—As Senator Robertson said, anything for a quick quid. The only criterion mentioned in the matter of public importance concerning the development of this industry is the importance of that decision to the economic development of this country. That is the sole criterion offered in the matter of public importance for the development of this great industry. I know that Senator Hamer at the tail end of his speech found it helpful to assuage the consciences of honorable senators opposite to find three moral points which happened to coincide with our economic well-being as a nation. But in fact, if one looks at the wording of the matter of public importance, the only criterion offered is the economic development of this country. That is a perspective and a ground from which to judge the necessary decisions in relation to the development of this industry which we utterly reject. But it is not surprising, as I have pointed out before in this chamber, that the parliamentary members of the Liberal and National parties take that attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: I tried to identify and find out what the Federal platform of the Liberal Party of Australia was on uranium. When I looked in the library under the heading ' natural resources', where one might hope to find some mention of uranium, there was nothing. Then when I had a look under the heading of, I think, 'development and energy' I found that the only criterion offered for development of energy resources in Australia was reliance to the greatest extent possible on competitive market forces, including the pricing mechanism. If ever there was prevarication and shilly-shallying around in the sense of a failure to face up to the real issues involved in the development of this natural energy resource, it is in the Liberal Party platform. The competitive pricing mechanism is the guidance that the Liberal Party offers to the people of Australia in coming to this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no morals in its policy.

—No, it is only bluff and bluster. The actual policy is therein laid bare. Of course, it is not surprising, therefore, that in the course of his remarks Senator Hamer should take note of the diminishing demand in the United States of America for this particular form of energy production. He blamed that diminishing demand on the web of regulations which surround the public energy utilities which use this source to generate energy. What an admission that is that Senator Hamer, on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, finds that he would much prefer the unfettered, unrestrained and unregulated attitude to the generation of power by public and private power utilities in the United States to the very stringent regulations which the United States authorities, reacting to the concerns of their constituents, think appropriate. But, as I have said, we should not be surprised because the underlying philosophy of the Liberal and National parties in this matter is bereft of anything except a reference to competitive market forces.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have dealt very publicly and painfully in their various conferences with the real decisions that have to be made. They have identified in their policies not just in occasional speeches from platforms, the issues which have to be confronted.

Nuclear non-proliferation issues are of concern to all of us as we try to stop a situation where the holocaust that could bring an end to human history hovers as a quite imminent possibility. We want to ensure that the international community in 1985 continues to give allegiance to the Treaty on the Non- Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. For that reason this Government has appointed an ambassador for disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, who is making that his first priority under directions from Mr Bill Hayden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. We are extremely concerned that the nuclear non-proliferation treaty ought to be extended to those countries which at the moment will not give their allegiance. We are equally concerned, of course, that the super-powers, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States of America, adhere to article 6 of that treaty which required them to reduce their nuclear arsenals as a sign of good faith to encourage other countries to come into that regime. We are working very hard at that but we recognise the matter and are taking practical steps to try to ensure that it is addressed.

Senator Hamer was very confident that solutions for the disposal of waste products exist. He spoke of certainty in relation to these matters. He quoted Professor Ringwood. Professor Ringwood, the Director of Research in the School of Earth Sciences at the Australian National University, is a scientist for whom I have the highest regard. I think most honourable senators would have received from Professor Ringwood some two weeks ago a document-Senator Hamer possibly quoted from that document-in which he claimed to have developed a method of immobilising high level and toxic nuclear wastes in synroc which could then be further incorporated in a geologically stable structure to prevent the movement of those toxic wastes into the environment over eons of time, as will be required. But I think it is also fair to point out, as I did at the time of the tabling of the report of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council late last year-Senator Sir John Carrick will recall this-that that Council made it clear that no toxic nuclear wastes had yet been incorporated in the synroc material, not even at the laboratory stage, let alone in a prototype of the size that would be necessary.

I think the Government did the right thing in the last Budget in allocating funds to enhance further the resources available to the synroc program. This is the correct way to go about it and I know that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), on his imminent overseas trip, will look at ways in which that particular research project can be furthered. I concede-I am only speaking personally-that Professor Ringwood may have a solution to the problem of waste disposal but it has not-one has to be fair about this and Senator Hamer , I believe, did not acknowledge this fact-yet been proved even at an experimental laboratory stage. I think it is a great advance on glassification- honourable senators should make no mistake on that-but it has not been proved and that has to be said.

The Australian Labor Party Government is aware of those matters. It is also aware that it would not be fair and responsible to come into Government, immediately create havoc amongst the townships and the workers who are dependent upon the Ranger and Nabarlek mines, and snatch away their livelihood. There are hundreds of workers. It would not have been a fair way in which to act, nor would it have been responsible to have put in jeopardy overnight the various arrangements for the Aboriginal comunities which have been entered into in relation to those operating mines. I emphasise that they are existing and operating mines in connection with which people are employed and that economic relationships have been established with the Aboriginal communities concerned.

To create an immediate situation of havoc and disruption would not be to take our responsibility as a federal government seriously and responsibly. Far from prevaricating or shilly-shallying around, I believe the Government has been very responsible. We have addressed and identified the issues in a responsible way. We, too, have taken urgent decisions where they have needed to be taken and they have not been very easy decisions. For the Australian Labor Party Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to meet with the French President, a colleague in the Socialist International, and tell him of our concerns about testing in the Pacific and to suspend a shipment of yellowcake that was due to go to France, was not an easy matter but a decision that had to be taken quickly and urgently.

The overall development of the uranium industry in Australia if, indeed, it is to go ahead at all is something which requires a prudent consideration. That is what we are undertaking. I believe that the Australian people in entrusting the Australian Labor Party with the mandate of government in March expect us to be prudent in that best sense. For that reason our taking of a cautious and practical attitude will, in the end, lead to better decision making. For that reason the chamber ought to reject the matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats tend to agree that there is an urgent need for the Government to come to a decision on the long term future of uranium mining in Australia. We would not like to force the Government into a hasty or ill-considered decision. But I suggest that the factors now exist to make that decision and that it is not likely that, in the next days, weeks, months or even years, matters will be brought up which will substantially alter the practical moral issue which lies behind this matter. I do not agree with the second part of the matter of public importance relating to the importance of the decision to the economic development of this country. That is sheer absolute nonsense. Everybody in the world knows that there is an enormous oversupply of both natural uranium and yellowcake all over the world. Utilities in America are flogging off their stockpiles to one another at increasingly lower prices. This situation can be expected to continue at least well into the 1990s and possibly well into the next century.

SPEECH.PARA: A factor which is often underrated here is the extent to which other new developing technologies are improving and lowering costs whereas, at the same time, the nuclear industry is increasing its costs. There has to be a point, very soon I think, where there will be major other new developments, which I will deal with shortly, for the generation of electric power which will be far more regional, cheaper and safer than nuclear power. It is quite a strong possibility that the market for uranium will collapse completely and that there will not be a market at all for any uranium within 10 or 15 years from now. As a result, to accept infrastructure development, say in South Australia for Roxby Downs, is the most imprudent and stupid thing that can be done. It is a betrayal of the people of South Australia because it is an inducement to them to put vast sums of money, many millions of dollars, into what will almost certainly be a clanger, an industry which cannot be justified on economic terms.

The Australian Democrats certainly believe that we need a clear-cut decision. The clear-cut decision we need is against nuclear power and thereby exerting, as one of the world's largest owners of uranium, a moral influence of enormous and historic importance to the world which I think could be quite decisive. I think it is wrong to say, with all respect to Senator Hamer, that we will have any kind of influence on proliferation by giving people our uranium freely. I would have thought that we would be much more likely to do it by putting even harder and tougher conditions and saying: 'Okay, you will not have our uranium until we can be absolutely guaranteed that it is not going into weapons'. Of course, that is not the case now. I will deal with that matter in a few minutes time.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not make weapons from nuclear power stations. That is a lot of ignorant nonsense.

—I have chapter and verse for Senator Jessop. He should listen carefully and I will do what I can for him. There is nothing more dangerous to the world than the proliferation of nuclear materials. Plutonium 239 is only one of the long lasting pollutants which are associated with the generation of electric power by nuclear methods. Every school child knows that one of the major pollutants, one of the major isotopes that is taken out of the spent fuel rods of a nuclear power-house, is plutonium 239. In fact most so-called peaceful power-plants produce plutonium 239 faster than a fast breeder reactor can. 'Fast ' refers, of course, to the speed of the neutrons. So there is enormous danger.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us recall the situation in London a century and a half ago when pollution from coal and smog was a serious problem and people died regularly from it. If we go to London now we find nothing of that kind because those pollutants were of a nature that could be removed from the environment quickly and easily. The half-life of plutonium 239 is 24,400 years, further into the future than we can look back. At that stage its dangerous radioactivity would be half of what it is now. That is only one of the dangerous isotopes which are floating around the world.

Senator Hamer made the point, and I think it is worth taking up at this stage, that we have to sell our uranium freely or we will get into the plutonium economy. That seems to me the most false type of logic one can imagine. What Senator Hamer is really saying to us is this: 'You have to con the world into relying absolutely on nuclear power using uranium, then when uranium runs out we will have no alternative but to go into faster breeder reactors in the plutonium economy'. That is the real point at issue. I should like a later speaker from this side to answer that point. I believe it is unanswerable. I should very much like it taken up and to be given a view on it because I think it is a serious matter for consideration by the Senate. That is a crunch issue.

Are we going to develop nuclear energy to the exclusion of other forms of energy, rely on that and then find that when the time comes, as it must inevitably do because we know that the supplies of uranium are finite, the only answer is a fast breeder reactor? To answer Senator Hamer, and I think he knows this himself, that is a device which can explode like a nuclear weapon, but it is unlike any other nuclear weapon the world has never seen because a fast breeder reactor has tonne lots of plutonium in its core and in the breeding blanket around the core. It has been estimated that an explosion of a fast breeder reactor would be a disaster which would eclipse anything that has ever happened on the face of the earth, short of the explosion of Krakatoa. It would be of that order, and the contamination of radioactivity would be formidable indeed.

It is interesting that Senator Hamer mentioned Sweden as a country which generates electric power by nuclear means. That country certainly did get into this, but it is trying to get out of it as fast as it can. The Swedish people have decided by referendum that they will phase out all nuclear generation of electric power in Sweden and replace it with other forms of power as fast as they can. The absolute last date set by that referendum is the year 2010. At that stage there will be no more use of nuclear power in Sweden. I suggest that is only one of many countries which will eventually do that. The State of California, by referendum of the people, has already decided that it does not want anything to do with nuclear power.

It is interesting that in the State of California some of the most advanced, successful and enlightened research into alternative forms of energy is going ahead-that is not an accident-and going ahead successfully. I said in the Senate only yesterday that there are now under construction in the Mojave Desert large solar-powered plants which hard-headed, competitive American utilities are building and from which they have promised to supply power at prices lower than those for ordinary fossil fuel reactors and lower than those for nuclear. That is because economies of scale and modern computer science have made it possible for these new power-stations to operate at much lower levels of staff and cost than they did in the past. Are we going to say that that should not go ahead? If it is going to go ahead it will need all the research and money we can get.

If the enormous subsidies which are going all over the world to the nuclear power industry were devoted to these other alternative areas we would make an enormous breakthrough in the alternatives within the next decade or two. I have mentioned once or twice in the Senate the tremendous work done in amorphous silicon cells, which is the placing of amorphous silicon on a substrate of plastic or metal. So the time will come quite soon, probably within five or six years, when sheets of plastic will roll out of a machine on a mass production basis and be put in arrays anywhere and produce electric power in good quantities wherever there is sunlight or even light available. Remote areas could thereby be provided with power. The enormous power reticulation losses, which are contingent with a nuclear powerhouse, because of its size, will not be a factor.

One of the problems of nuclear powerhouses is that they operate most efficiently if they are very large. If we have very large amounts of electric power we will have a situation which, as I have said in this place before, encourages the wasteful use of electricity because literally so much of it is produced. The question of waste disposal is a critical one. Waste disposal methods would be of benefit if they could succeed. I agree with Senator Tate that they have not really been brought to the stage of being proven; in fact, glassification which was hailed for years is now regarded by all nuclear scientists and physicists as being quite dangerous because the glass in fact does fracture. It has been found that it is not as good as it was once thought it would be. The latest experiments show that there is an almost inevitable leaching over periods of historic time.

We have to look at periods of historic time-not at 10-year or 20-year periods, but at a period of thousands of years-to see how this thing will react then. The latest reading I have had-and I think this is regrettable-is that Professor Ringwood's synroc process has been rejected by the United States Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely wrong.
—Well, it was published recently in a--
—Produce the facts. Produce your reading.

—I will do that for the honourable senator. I make the point that I am saying that only on a reading of a statement I read in a popular magazine, but it is a reliable, normally authoritative magazine which I will provide for the honourable senator to look at later. I regret that the United States has rejected the synroc process. I think it would be better if it were to look at what Professor Ringwood was doing a little more carefully, because the writer of that article, as it happened, supported Professor Ringwood rather than the view of the United States Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer questioned our right to say to other nations that they cannot use nuclear power. The answer to that, of course, is: Yes, we have a perfect right to do so if they propose to use the power in a way which might even have the faintest risk of contaminating the atmosphere, the sea, or anything outside their boundaries. It is not possible for a country to make nuclear power houses and have them without that kind of risk. That brings me to the issue of safeguards. There is no way of ensuring that Australian uranium will not be transferred from countries favoured by Australian export and safeguard policies to those that are prepared to operate outside their guidelines. For instance, the European Economic Community countries to whom we are selling uranium freely, through France, have entered into several nuclear agreements with other countries, including Iraq, Libya, Pakistan, South Korea, Argentina and Brazil.

I think one of the most irresponsible acts of the previous Liberal Government was to allow that kind of situation to happen. To come into this Senate and say that there are adequate safeguards when, in fact, those safeguards do not exist and are not worth the paper they are written on is irresponsible. Later in this debate I would like someone to tell me whether there is any way it can be ensured, for instance, that Australian uranium cannot be substituted for uranium from other sources which could as a result then be fed into military development programs. How can anyone identify our piece of uranium after it has gone through , say, a reprocessing process? All of us know perfectly well that that is impossible. Therefore, our safeguards policy in Australia is in ribbons, in tatters; it is not worth the paper it is written on. It is a gross betrayal of the planet.

It is a fact that nuclear power will never solve any energy crisis in the industrialised nations. First, electricity consumption is only 30 per cent of all energy consumed, and nuclear energy contributes about 10 per cent of that 30 per cent. In overall terms, nuclear energy at present contributes 3 to 4 per cent of the world's total energy needs. That could be far more than compensated for by a quite limited international conservation program using known technology at relatively low cost. That is not being done in areas where nuclear power is being generated because, as I said earlier, there is an interest on the part of owners of nuclear power houses to flog off just as much power as they possibly can. It is a bad thing for the world that that should be so.

A proper conservation program could eliminate the need for nuclear power completely. Nuclear power will never be able to replace fuel sources such as oil and coal. Indeed, 50 per cent of all usage of oil and coal is for the petro- chemical and transport industries, industries for which electricity cannot be applied. So there is no question of there being a coal-oil-nuclear choice. Of course, there are excellent alternatives for the generation of electric power. I mentioned them earlier when I referred to things such as Solar I and its later developments which will provide power in the range of approximately 100 to 110 megawatts and which are now on the drawing board.

These sorts of powerhouses will be a cheaper, easier, safer means of generating electric power. I think they will come into operation quite soon. Of course, this is recognised in the United States. I found it to be recognised when I went there last year. That is the reason that there have been no orders for nuclear reactors in the United States since 1978. In fact, all nuclear plants ordered in the United States of America since 1974 have now been cancelled. Over the period 1972-82, over 100 plants have been cancelled throughout the world, and many of these cancellations involved huge cost penalties, of up to $500m. But indeed, the hard-nosed people in business know that it is not a goer and, because of that, they are getting out of it while the time is right. Is this, then, a time for us to be getting into it? Of course it is not. It could not be a more disastrous decision for us to get into that now. From a purely economic point of view, it would be quite crazy to do so.

I should like, briefly, to look at the world situation, and the implications of nuclear power-houses all around our cities throughout the world in the event of a time of war. If anyone thinks that we can get an agreement by which nations would be gentlemanly enough not to attack nuclear power-houses with bombs, he is a fool. Of course that would happen. The research has been done on this subject. It has been done by many reputable people. I refer to that excellent book The Fate of the Earth, serialised in the New Yorker and recently published in Australia and America by Jonathan Schell. I inform Senator Sir John Carrick that there Jonathan Schell quotes very carefully his sources for his information. The dangers and risks to a city in the case of nuclear war if it has a power-station are about 35 times what they would be if it did not have one. So one places one' s cities in hostage to an enemy, because if the nuclear powerhouse is blown up, all its isotopes, all the products which are in its fuel cells, will then be distributed throughout that city, with the rest of the contaminants. On that sobering note, I end my speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate has heard two contributions, that of Senator Tate and that of Senator Mason. Both presented a gross distortion of the facts, and I shall proceed to demonstrate that. Senator Tate has said that the delays, the ambiguities and the confusions that are occurring day by day in the uranium debate inside the Australian Labor Party are based on one thing: That its members will not be hurried into reaching a conclusion; that they need time; that they have not had time. What nonsense. They were seven years in opposition. They had all the time necessary to go to their Federal Conference and to make a policy-which they presented and for which they sought a mandate. Senator Tate asks about a mandate. The mandate-if he was given one-was to phase out uranium. Let us not pretend otherwise about that.

SPEECH.PARA: What a nonsense it is to suggest that they have not had time. The Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, the Fox Inquiry, was held eight or nine years ago . What nonsense it is to suggest that its findings have not been thoroughly debated. What nonsense it is to suggest that the Fraser Government was short on time on this matter. I sat patiently in this Senate as a Minister day after day, for weeks, going through an enormous package of some seven Bills on all aspects of uranium, all the aspects deriving from the Fox Inquiry. The Labor Party had every ounce of time to look at the findings of the Fox Inquiry, to see how they were to be translated into legislation. Now members of the Labor Party say that they have not had time. The truth of the matter, as they must admit, is that they are riven apart.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not saying at all that we have not had time.

—Senator Coleman can answer, if she speaks later, a very simple thing. Senator Tate has said that members of the Labor Party will do nothing on this business until they have come to conclusions, that until then they will make no decisions. But why did they make a decision to wind down and to get rid of the uranium enrichment plant inside the Atomic Energy Commission if they are not going to make any decisions? A uranium enrichment plant could not possibly increase any dangers of radioactivity. It was done, of course-as they have told me privately-to appease the left wing, because, on the one hand, they were going ahead with contracts in certain cases, and they said 'We shall have to do something to appease the left wing'. What a mealy-mouthed explanation we are given here, when in fact what they are saying is 'We did it to save money '.

SPEECH.PARA: Time after time the arguments that members of the Labor Party have put up have been absolutely spurious. Let us not hear again that they have not had time. They have had seven years, the Fox Inquiry and all the debate on legislation in this place, week after week. They reached a conclusion. That conclusion was that they would phase out uranium mining and exports. In that long time they reached that conclusion. The real tragedy is that at this moment they know they were wrong, yet they are not willing to do the right thing. Their Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tries to say that he will do the right thing-that is, to continue exports -but the others deny it. What a lot of humbug we hear day after day.

I had to wring out of the responsible Minister in Estimates Committee C a reply as to whether there had been any policy decisions regarding Roxby Downs. Indeed, it was only yesterday that finally I managed to get-because I said that I would not accept the Estimates Committee report unless the answer were there-the final answer. Let us look at this matter. It is very interesting. In questioning Senator Walsh on this, I said: 'But Roxby Downs expects that they will get the go-ahead'. It is very interesting that Senator Walsh's answer to me was:
The formal policy decision on this has not yet been made. I understand that the company has written, seeking the Commonwealth's policy attitude on proceeding with it.

He said 'I understand that the company has written'-and he is the responsible Minister. But what is the reply that we forced out of the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen)? Over Senator Walsh's signature, it is as follows:

I have now been advised by the Minister for Trade that no such assurances or undertakings have been given to the Roxby Downs Joint Venturers. I am further advised that the Joint Venturers have not applied for an authorisation . . .

Where do we stand in this situation? The Prime Minister says one thing-'Roxby Downs will go ahead'. On the other hand, Senator Walsh says 'I know that they have written a letter', and now the reply from the Minister for Trade denies that. Of course, we have an absolute nonsense in this situation. We have a Labor Party which is, as I say, utterly divided.

I pause there because I want to come to the fundamentals of this matter. I know nothing that does more discredit to this Senate than the statements day after day by Senator Mason based on corrupt and distorted, twisted facts. I can only say, when I look at Senator Mason and listen to him here when he talks of the fuel cycle, that Shakespeare had it right, and that he was thinking of Senator Mason when he had Bassanio say, in The Merchant of Venice:

Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than any man in all Venice: His reasons are two grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff; you shall seek all day ere you find them; and when you have them they are not worth the search.
He could not have had a greater concept than that of Senator Mason, because day after day he talks such nonsense here. Of course, he does that to play upon the emotions of the people.

It is a fact that solar energy research in this world is at such a primitive stage that everywhere it is recognised that it cannot in the medium term future make a significant contribution. Let me now make it perfectly clear, and let me demolish the arguments that have been put. There were two arguments put today, and one was put by Senator Tate-'We need time to think'. I think that members of the Labor Party should be put back into opposition for seven years and given time to think. The other argument is: 'You don't need nuclear fuel because the world can get energy in other ways'. I served for years on the International Energy Agency. Twenty-two nations of the free world, socialist, non-socialist, all the leading nations, were represented. I shall quote what they said:

It is impossible for the living standards of the people of the world to be maintained and to be prevented from falling seriously unless there is a very substantial increase in the development of nuclear power generation in the world .

Twenty-two nations said this, but Senator Mason knows better. Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing. Even if we have maximum energy conservation, even if we use renewable energy by way of biomass or solar means, even if we develop coal and all the other things, we will still have to have an immense input of nuclear power if all countries, and particularly the countries of the Third World, are not to suffer seriously. Lest anybody has any doubt about that, the Hawke Government agrees with this. In fact it took an active part in the deliberations of the International Energy Agency at its last meeting. It signed and agreed with the communique that was issued. I seek leave to have the whole communique and Senator Walsh's statement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY-MINISTERIAL MEETING

The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Peter Walsh, today released the Communique of the meeting of the IEA Governing Board at Ministerial level. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bill Hayden, represented Australia at the meeting, which was held on 8 May under the Chairmanship of Mr W. F. Birch, New Zealand Minister of Energy, National Development and Regional Development.

The Principal item of business at the meeting was a study of future energy requirements and security which had been prepared by the Secretariat of the Agency. The analysis had confirmed that the main problem would continue to be in the field of oil supply, although imports of gas could pose some difficulties unless suitable policies of diversification of sources, and preparations to deal with supply disruptions, were implemented effectively.

''The future role of coal from OECD countries such as Australia has been enhanced by the study'', said Senator Walsh, welcoming the Governing Board's continued recognition of the need for expansion of coal production and trade, in order to reduce further the dependence on oil of the Western economies.

The IEA Ministers had considered recent reports by a special committee of the Agency's Coal Industry Advisory Board on current and prospective developments in the coal industry, and on environmental aspects of coal use. In the light of difficulties being experienced by the Australian coal industry, it was pleasing to note that endorsement of the view that current problems in the coal trade occur largely on the demand side. Ministers decided to give particular attention in their own countries to the removal of constraints on greater coal use and trade.

The easier conditions in the international oil market, and in particular the relief which lower oil prices is giving their hard-pressed economies, were discussed. At the same time, the danger of a complacent assumption that oil supply problems had been solved permanently was recognised.
''Such easy judgments had proved disastrously wrong in the past'', observed Senator Walsh.

It was necessary that oil importing countries, in particular continue to improve the efficiency with which they used oil, and to substitute other forms of energy such as coal wherever it was economic to do so.

Australia was involved only marginally in the US/European discussions about future dependence on imports of natural gas from non-OECD sources. We have the good fortune to be self-sufficient in gas, and in a few years' time hope to be exporting liquefied natural gas to Japan. Nevertheless, Australia appreciates the concern about possible over-reliance on a single external source of supply, and is pleased that its IEA partners have agreed on a continuing review procedure to ensure that any potential risk is identified and corrected at an early stage.

During the meeting, the Governing Board of the IEA placed great emphasis on reactor safety, waste management and disposal, and non-proliferation policies in the future development of nuclear energy in those countries which have adopted this technology for generating electricity. This emphasis accords with the Australian Government's philosophy.

Senator Walsh also announced that the Government had accepted an invitation from the IEA for Mr A. J. Woods, Secretary, Department of Resources and Energy, to chair the Governing Board at Officials' level. In welcoming the appointment, the Minister said this appointment was an honour both for Australia and Mr Woods personally.
