TEXT OF COMMUNIQUE ADOPTED BY IEA GOVERNING BOARD MEETING AT MINISTERIAL LEVEL IN PARIS ON 8 MAY 1983
The Governing Board of the International Energy Agency (IEA) met at Ministerial level on 8th May 1983 in Paris, under the Charimanship of the Honourable W. F. Birch, Minister of Energy, New Zealand.
The Current Energy Situation

Ministers assessed the current energy situation and particularly world oil markets. They welcomed the relief provided in the world economy by today's conditions, characterised by price adjustments which take account of reduced economic activity world-wide. They believe that these developments also reflect growing efficiency in energy use and production from a widening range of sources . However, they recognised that conditions could change in the future, as the world economy picks up and the current stock draw down comes to an end. They expressed concern that sharply lower oil prices and uncertainty about future oil market developments could slow down investment in energy efficiency, hydrocarbon development and alternative energy sources thus creating over the longer term the possibility of renewed instability in energy and oil markets, with adverse effects on the world economy. They agreed that the easing of the oil market was no reason to change the agreed objectives of energy policies, given remaining uncertainties about short-term developments and the underlying trends pointing towards tighter market conditions in the longer term. They therefore reaffirmed their intention to fulfil the policies of oil substitution, energy conservation, and energy research and development. They instructed the Governing Board at official level to follow developments in the world oil market closely, particularly further movement of oil inventories.
Energy Requirements and Security

Ministers assessed energy requirements and security for the next two decades, bearing in mind the importance of adequate and secure energy supplies to the prospects for sustained economic growth and considering the study Energy Requirements and Security prepared by the Secretariat. They recognised the continued likelihood of heavy reliance on imported energy, particularly oil, and for the first time addressed the question of natural gas in detail. They reached the conclusions set forth in Annex 1 regarding the need for strong and cost- effective energy policies, re-confirming previous action taken within the IEA, and emphasising the need for a balanced approach which puts each aspect of energy policy into its proper perspective, including:
improved energy efficiency and appropriate pricing and fiscal regimes;
further expansion of the production, use and trade of coal and other solid fuels;
a major and increasing role for nuclear power in many countries;
obtaining the advantages of increased use of gas on an acceptably secure basis;
continuation of efforts to improve energy security in the case of oil, which will remain by far the most important factor in energy imports; and
development of new and renewable sources of energy.
Coal Industry Advisory Board

Ministers considered a report from the Special Committee of the Coal Industry Advisory Board on the current status of developments in coal and its prospects for the future. They noted the Special Committee's concern that the present oil market situation could jeopardise the effectiveness of coal in meeting the objectives set forth in the IEA Principles for Action on Coal. Ministers requested the Governing Board at Official level and the CIAB to give prompt and active consideration on these matters, taking account of the conclusions reached at the meeting concerning coal.
Ministers welcomed the publication of the report Coal Use and the Environment prepared by the CIAB and undertook to consider its recommendations carefully in formulating national policies.
Ministers also agreed on the desirability of promoting the development and increased use of other solid fuels, such as lignite and peat which have specific geographical importance.
International Energy Relations

Ministers emphasised that energy remains a decisive element for progress in the world economy, and is particularly important for developing countries. Ministers welcomed the contribution which the various contacts between oil producing and consuming countries are making to improved understanding by all parties of world oil and energy markets. They again stressed the importance of enhanced exchanges for greater stability in the world energy situation and an improved world economy.
Ministers expressed their deep appreciation of the leadership and advice provided by Ambassador Hiromichi Miyazaki of Japan, Chairman of the Governing Board at Official level since October 1980.
They welcomed the willingness of the Government of Australia to make Mr Alan J. Woods available to succeed Ambassador Miyazaki as Chairman of the Governing Board at Official level.
ANNEX 1
CONCLUSIONS

1. Ministers assessed world energy requirements and security for the next two decades, bearing in mind the importance of adequate and secure energy supplies to the prospects for sustained economic growth. They noted with satisfaction the progress that had been made since 1973 in reducing dependence on imported oil by increasing energy efficiency and the use of alternative fuels, notably coal, gas and nuclear energy. The progress has contributed to the lowering of oil prices which is now bringing an important and welcome relief to the world economy. Ministers agreed, however, that such relief was likely to be temporary and that there is a risk of a renewed energy constraint on growth later in this decade unless the industrialised countries strengthen their policies to restructure their economies. Ministers noted, in this context, that dependence on imported oil, though reduced, remains high in many of their countries and that this remains the major risk to their energy security; that the contributions of coal and nuclear energy are running significantly below earlier expectations; that the prospect of growing imports of gas to help reduce dependence on imported oil could lead to heavy dependence by some countries on single sources of gas supply ; and that the outlook for investment in the efficient use of energy and for the development of indigenous energy sources is less than satisfactory. They agreed that some of these problems could be accentuated by the uncertain outlook for oil prices.

2. Since industrialised countries as a whole will, in any event, continue to rely heavily on imported energy, smoothly functioning world energy markets over the long-term will be essential for their economic well-being. Industrialised countries must seek to reduce the risk of disruptions and be prepared to minimise the effects on their economies of any which occur. The balance between energy security and costs will have to be struck under the responsibility and in the circumstances or individual countries, having regard to their international commitments. Each country will, however, continue to develop strong and cost- effective energy policies based on that combination of market forces and government action which is best suited to its circumstances but including:
- implementing and as necessary strengthening present policies to promote the efficient use of energy and the continuing replacement of oil by other fuels:

- rapid and, where appropriate co-operative, development on an economic basis of indigenous energy resources-fossil fuels, nuclear energy, hydropower and other renewable energies-to the maximum possible extent consistent with environmental and social factors and the need to secure supplies beyond the turn of the century;
- seeking to remove impediments to its trade in energy;
- substantial programmes of research, development and demonstration;
- pricing and fiscal regimes which promote the rational use of energy and the development of indigenous energy resources;
- diversification of sources of energy imports;
- co-operation on a regional basis or as otherwise appropriate to improve the overall flexibility of energy systems and to overcome transit problems;
- effective co-operative measures for dealing with disruptions in energy supplies.

Ministers recognised that energy security and smoother functioning of world energy markets is not a matter for industrialised countries alone. More effective energy policies in the industrialised area should ease the world energy situation and thereby the energy situation of the non-oil developing countries. They emphasised the importance of mutual understanding with energy exporting and importing developing countries to the achievement of these aims. Development of the indigenous energy resources, including new and renewable energy, of the developing countries could in its turn make an important contribution to improving the world energy situation.
3. IEA Ministers reaffirmed the commitments of their Governments to:

- the International Energy program, which remains the primary international protection of their countries against tighter oil markers in the longer term and , through the IEA oil emergency allocation system, in times of a major oil market disruption;
- the Principles for Energy Policy adopted by IEA Ministers in October 1977;
- the Principles for IEA Action on Coal agreed in May 1979, which continue to provide a valuable framework for expanding world coal production, use and trade;
- the Lines of Action for Energy Conservation and Fuel Switching agreed in December 1980;
- the Governing Board decision of December 1981 regarding minor oil supply disruption.
Energy Efficiency
4. Ministers recognised the important potential contribution of improved energy efficiency to overall energy security and agreed to give particular attention as appropriate to:

- financial or other measures to stimulate the efficient use of energy and conversion from oil including help to industry and others to overcome the high initial investment costs of certain energy-saving and fuel-switching measures;

- the development of energy conservation services capable of offering a comprehensive package which would include information on rational energy use and oil substitution, provision and installation of equipment, and financial advice tailored to the needs of customers;
- the publication of technical and financial information on the efficient use of energy and of any assessments which governments may make of long-term trends in energy demand, supply and prices;
- demonstration by governments within their own operations of the value of energy efficiency;
- inclusion of energy efficiency as an element in industrial policy;
- energy efficiency in transport and in the building sector through higher voluntary or mandatory standards;
- policies to overcome structural barriers which mute the impact of market signals.
Pricing and Fiscal Regime
5. Ministers agreed to pay particular attention to:
- removal of those price regulations which discourage the development of indigenous energy or the displacement of oil by other fuels or the efficient use of energy;
- the pricing policies and where it exists regulation of the tariffs of electricity utilities so as not to impede the provision of funds for investment in new generating capacity.
- reviewing energy pricing policy, with the aims that energy prices should be more transparent and more closely reflect market prices or the long-term costs of maintaining supplies, as appropriate;
- the structuring of fiscal regimes for oil and gas production so as to encourage timely development.
Coal and Other Solid Fuels
6. Ministers agreed that to promote on an economic basis further expansion of production, use and trade of coal and, where appropriate, of other solid fuels including lignite and peat:
- their countries should continue to reduce impediments to a major expansion of coal use in electrical power generation and in industry;
- their countries should take steps to provide the infrastructure needed for increase production, transport and marketing of coal;
- coal-exporting countries should facilitate reliable coal exports in times of supply difficulties;
- their countries should promote the development of a flexible and diversified coal trading system, paying particular attention to the need for long-term contracts.

7. Coal use must be environmentally acceptable. Ministers agreed to accelerate cooperative efforts to promote strategies for the clean use of coal, including research, development and demonstration regarding coal use technologies, and to establish effective regulatory frameworks which allow coal users to choose the most economic means to achieve environmental goals. They will assess available and new technologies and review regularly the pace and impact of their introduction.
Nuclear Power

8. To fulfil its important potential for contributing to overall long-term energy security which is the concern of all industrialised countries, nuclear power will have to play a major and increasing role in many countries. Ministers :

- stressed the importance of encouraging stable trade in nuclear equipment, fuel cycle services and nuclear fuel. Export and import regulations must be predictable, and based on the strict respect of current non-proliferation policies;

- agreed that Member countries would maintain reliable standards of nuclear reactor safety and continue to co-operate in various fora on these matters. Procedures for the approval of reactors and nuclear facilities should be as clear and expeditious as possible.

- stressed the importance of international co-operation on spent fuel storage and waste disposal. They appealed to the governments of those countries in a position to do so to stimulate further progress in developing and applying effective and timely methods for managing the back end of the fuel cycle in ways best suited to their national situations and compatible with international agreements. The IEA and NEA were requested to work together on periodic consultations on the progress of Member governments into waste disposal programme;
- requested the IEA and NEA to identify for prompt examination new possibilities for research and development in advanced technologies that support these conclusions.
Action on these lines will provide the basis for both institutional impediments and public acceptance concerns on nuclear power to be vigorously addressed and allayed wherever possible.
Gas

9. Ministers agreed that gas has an important role to play in reducing dependence on imported oil. They also agreed, however, on the importance of avoiding the development of situations in which imports of gas could weaken rather than strengthen the energy supply security and thus the overall economic stability of Member countries. They noted the potential risks associated with high levels of dependence on single supplier countries. Ministers stressed the importance of expeditious development of indigenous OECD energy resources. They noted that existing contracts are currently insufficient to cover expected gas demand by the mid-1990s, and agreed that in filling this gap steps should be taken to ensure that no one producer is in a position to exercise monopoly power over OECD and IEA countries. To obtain the advantages of increased use of gas on an acceptably secure basis, they agreed that:

- their countries would seek to avoid undue dependence on any one source of gas imports and to obtain future gas supplies from secure sources, with emphasis on indigenous OECD sources. Additional supplied from other sources would be obtained from as diverse sources as possible, taking into account supply structures, the share of gas in energy balances, and the geographical situation of individual countries. In assessing the full costs of gas supply sources, gas companies and, as appropriate, governments will consider security factors;

- their Governments would either encourage gas companies and other undertakings concerned to take or take themselves the necessary and appropriate cost- effective measures suited to each country's situation to strengthen their ability to deal with supply disruptions; these measures could include increased gas storage facilities, contingency demand restraint programmes, improved fuel- switching capabilities accompanied by adequate stocks of oil or other alternative fuels, a more flexible grid structure, greater flexibility of contracts, more surge capacity, measures to accelerate into OECD trade on short notice through standby contracts for supplies in a disruption, and interruptible contracts with consumers;

- action should be taken to develop at economic cost indigenous gas resources, particularly in North America and the North Sea, which show promise of alleviating overall or particular pressures on energy imports;

- concerned member governments noting the potential for further development of North American gas resources and noting that part of the Norwegian Troll field may be declared commercial by 1984, would encourage their companies to begin negotiations on deliveries from these sources as soon as possible, with a view to making supplies available at prices competitive with other fuels in the mid- 1990s;
- trade barriers and other barriers which could delay development of indigenous gas resources should be avoided or reduced;

- their governments would encourage the companies concerned to undertake feasibility studies, if appropriate in cooperation with member governments, to determine the economic, engineering, technical and financial factors, relevant to possible imports from a variety of non-OECD sources;

- governments within one region where there is scope for effective cooperation should invite gas companies operating in their jurisdictions to address and negotiate on a commercial basis cooperative arrangements to meet a disruption of supplies to any one country or to the region as a whole;

- special attention should be given in the annual country review process in various international organisations to the future pattern of gas supplies, to the progress on the development and implementation of security measures, and to whether gas imports into the OECD from any single source constitute such a proportion of total supplies as to give rise to concern about the timely development of indigenous resources and the vulnerability of supplies, either for an individual member country or collectively;

- in considering the degree of vulnerability, relevant factors include the share of imports in total gas consumption and in total primary energy requirements, the reliability of particular sources, the flexibility of other supplies, sectoral distribution, stocks and fuel-switching possibilities;

- an in-depth exchange of views about this question would take place within the normal review process whenever considered necessary. To allow a full assessment of its energy situation, the country concerned shall inform the other member states if it plans major changes in its energy policy or gas supply pattern which are significant in the context of development of indigenous OECD resources and vulnerability of gas supplies.

Ministers expressed the view that special attention should be given in relevant international organisations to the gas import situation of individual countries and regions. IEA Ministers instructed the Governing Board to keep this issue under continuing review.
Oil

10. Ministers noted that since 1974, considerable progress has been made in improving energy security as far as oil is concerned. A continuation of these efforts will be necessary, however, as oil will remain by far the most important factor in OECD energy imports. Thus, in the year 2000 oil will still constitute more than 75% of all OECD energy imports. Ministers therefore agreed on the importance of strong cooperative arrangements for handling a major oil supply disruption and, in the case of IEA Ministers, on the need for continued improvement of the existing emergency allocation system, and the need to continue to encourage oil companies to support the improvement and, if necessary , the operation of the system. To strengthen their overall emergency preparedness, Ministers also agreed to continue to pay particular attention to the continued adequacy of their countries' oil stocks in terms of amount, structure and flexibility.
Other Energy Resources

11. Ministers reaffirmed their readiness to pursue policies both at the national and international level, aiming at exploitation of other indigenous energy resources such as hitherto unharnessed hydropower.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me read what the 22 nations said, although of course Senator Mason, speaking an infinite deal of nothing, would disagree with them. In relation to this matter those 22 nations, including the Hawke Government, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Nuclear Power

8. To fulfil its important potential for contributing to overall long-term energy security which is the concern of all industrialised countries, nuclear power will have to play a major and increasing role in many countries. Ministers :

- stressed the importance of encouraging stable trade in nuclear equipment, fuel cycle services and nuclear fuel. Export and import regulations must be predictable, and based on the strict respect of current non-proliferation policies;

That was the statement made in May of this year, but Senator Mason says: 'I, Senator Mason, am right and 22 nations are wrong'. All of these nations, including Sweden, including the Scandinavian nations, including the nations that he quotes in this debate say: 'Unless we go ahead with this the world will be threatened with lower living standards'. but he has dreamed up some kind of nonsense, some kind of solar power situation which in fact the scientists of this world through the IEA say is just not so. Let me again be emphatic: The nonsense that Senator Mason talks does great harm to the security of Australia and this world. He talks as though the people who want to make atomic weapons need to get the uranium from power stations. Nothing could be more wrong. Uranium ore is distributed over the length and breadth of this world, both in land and sea. It is there in quantities, in definite quantities, for the decades ahead, for anybody to dig out and to refine if they want it.

Let me hit now at the basic fallacy. There is no need for anybody seeking to make nuclear fuels to seek to buy yellowcake in the orthodox markets of this world. Indeed, the best way to keep the monitoring of yellowcake production honest, to make yellowcake non-available for weapons production, is for it to be handled commercially through the International Atomic Energy Agency. The situation is the very reverse of what Senator Mason has said. I say to the Senate that the world is engorged, sadly enough, with more plutonium than it would ever know what to do with if we are talking about nuclear fuels to make weaponry. It is utterly wrong to equate weaponry with nuclear power stations. But the corruption goes on within the Hawke Government. The Government says: ' Give us time. By July of next year we will have reached a decision. We will square it off with the Federal conference of the party. Give us time. The last seven years did not give us enough time. All the debates in this Parliament did not give us time. But give us time and we will reach a conclusion'. The truth is that the Labor Party is in a state of civil war. It wants to delay or simulate for the moment. I repeat that more serious than that is the kind of nonsense that Senator Mason talks here when he pretends to take scientific facts and distorts them in order to frighten the people. The world is in enough fear from the threat of nuclear weapons without that. No one should add false information to this situation just to further his cause. I know of nothing more ugly than the kinds of situations in which someone gets up in this chamber and says: 'I know that you can get solar rays which will provide electricity cheaper than existing power stations or nuclear power stations'. That is absolutely factually incorrect and every worthwhile scientist-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is the honourable senator accusing me of misleading the Senate on this point?
—There is no point of order.

—I am accusing the honourable senator of seeking to delay my speech so that I do not underline the inaccuracies of what he said. I say emphatically that the advice I have received in the past over the years as a Minister, the advice that 22 nations have given to us, is that solar development at this moment is primitive, is costly and could not in fact do more than make about a three per cent contribution to the whole of the world's energy output. I say again that we should not equate nuclear power stations with atomic weaponry. That is corrupt propaganda. I say again that nothing could be more wrong than the Labor Party's pretence that it is delaying this matter so as to think. It is delaying this matter so as to line up its forces in the civil war within its ranks. The Labor Party will adopt another resolution in July of next year. During that time the Australian people will be prevented from making the kinds of contracts and developing the kinds of industries that will provide them with employment and will provide the people of the world with nuclear energy in a peaceable fashion, will keep their living standards up and do much to preserve peace and not to aggravate war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to some of the things that Senator Sir John Carrick said because, apart from the word ' corruption', the most used word in his entire speech was 'nonsense'. The Senate might recall that the week before last when we debated a very similar matter of public importance, as I closed the debate and brought on the business of the day I said that the matter of public importance was a nonsense. I say now that this matter of public importance is a nonsense. Perhaps I would agree with Senator Tate that it is a petulant matter of public importance. It is a nonsense because this is the third debate on uranium that we have had in as many sitting weeks. It is designed purely and simply to waste the time of the Senate. This matter of public importance states:

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to come to a decision on the long-term future of uranium mining in Australia, and the importance of that decision to the economic development of this country.

Let us look at the economics of this matter and let us look firstly at the figures involved. I think it is terribly important that we look at the figures which are tossed around as to the sums of money involved in uranium mining. They may sound very impressive. They may not sound so impressive if they are taken into consideration in the overall economic context. We cannot take figures in isolation without looking at other areas, the social effects, the political factors, the effect on the economy and income and employment. Let us look at the two existing mines. We have Nabarlek which commenced operation in June 1980. The mine and mill was constructed at a cost of $75m. If we look at Ranger, which commenced operation in October 1981, the mine and mill were constructed at a cost of $366m. More than $400m was involved in construction at those two mines. Let us have a look at the economics as far as employment is concerned. In both of those mines approximately 500 people are employed. it is a very expensive employment operation. Possibly 350 people are employed indirectly, giving us a total of 850 people employed. It is definitely not economical. There is no way that anything that has been said here today can prove that on a jobs/investment ratio that is an economical situation.

But we also have to look at what is happening in other parts of the world. If we look at the nuclear power situation we see that there has been a downturn in the industry. There has been a downturn in the United States, for purely economical reasons. I think we have to stop and recognise that it is perhaps the most significant nation in relation to nuclear power, but if we look at what has happened since 1978 we see that no new nuclear power plants have been ordered. The latest problem to hit the United States has been the incredible rates shock because suddenly the owners of these utilities have discovered that the massive injection of money into the power plants has meant that their consumption rates have to be extraordinarily high, and the domestic consumers are starting to react unfavourably. They are saying: 'We don't want to be paying this amount of money just for the provision of electricity, because we know that it can be produced cheaper'. The electric utility companies have been forced to write off those nuclear projects that they originally intended to go ahead with because they just cannot afford to proceed with them. Incidentally, some of these companies have already generated money amounting to some billions of dollars. If we are really serious about looking at the economic development of this country and if we are looking at the role that uranium is to play in that economic development then we have to recognise that other countries that are not using uranium to the same extent in nuclear power plants will be hard pushed to purchase our uranium.

There are similar problems with economic development in the United Kingdom. It was originally estimated that the latest power plant to be built there would cost somewhere in the vicinity of $A425m and in actual fact it finished up costing a total of $A1,156m. The operators have said that the plant will take 30 years, running at full capacity-no one can give a guarantee that a nuclear power station can run at full capacity over such a period-to pay for itself. I remind honourable senators that the cost was $A1,156m. In France, the Government has already introduced new plans to manipulate energy usage in an endeavour to promote the demand for nuclear power. The European countries have problems, as has Japan, with waste disposal. They have really come up with only short term and very politically divisive solutions. For instance, Japan still wants to dump it in the Pacific Ocean. Perhaps the least safety conscious country of all, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, has now seriously had to look at its nuclear power schemes because of major setbacks that have beset the industry and the fact that it also has problems with the disposal of waste.

So if we are talking about the economic situation of the industry, all of those things have to be taken into account. Honourable senators cannot divorce themselves one from the other. Nor can they or should they divorce themselves from other very important areas of consideration including industrial health, worker safety and waste disposal. I am sure that everybody would be quite aware that industrial health and worker safety has never been terribly high on the list of priorities as far as members of the Liberal-National Party Opposition is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon!

—I am sure that even they, including Senator Jessop, will be very concerned about the incident at the Ranger plant only last week. If he is not concerned about it then he is doing the country a grave disservice. The plant design there is so totally inadequate that it allowed a plumber--
—Have you been up there?

—I have been there. It allowed a plumber to connect potable water-that is, the water that people drink-with water that was radioactively contaminated. The people there were washing in it and were drinking it.
—Most of the water up there is radioactive anyway, and was even before the mine started.

—It was considered to be highly radioactively contaminated water . If the honourable senator is not concerned about that then he should go and talk to the workers at Ranger who have already expressed their concern about it. I am vitally concerned about it because I think the most important factor in the whole of the uranium industry is worker safety and waste disposal. Neither of those problems has been sorted out. People can talk all they like about Professor Ringwood's solution with synroc. That is not yet past the laboratory experiment stage. There has not been, nor is there at this point of time, any manner of safely disposing of radioactive waste. The companies themselves will agree with that, if they are honest, but I doubt that we will find very much honesty among the companies that operate particularly in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We are constantly pushing the barrow that our economy will fail if we do not go ahead and mine our uranium. Our economy will not fail for that reason; we do have adequate supplies of other resources. I was interested in some of the things that Senator Sir John Carrick had to say, which just went to prove that he is entirely ignorant of some of the things that are happening in Australia. For instance, he talked about primative solar power. That was the word the honourable senator used-primitive. If he reads the report of Telecom Australia, which I understand is being tabled today and which I will be addressing, he will see that Telecom has already put in a solar powered despatcher unit in the north west of Australia which is responsible for the total coverage of the north of Western Australia as far as telecommunications is concerned. Solar power in this country is no longer primitive. There has to be a recognition by the Opposition of this point. Of course we have other very important natural resources such as coal, oil and gas, not to mention sun, wind and tide-none of which, I might add, has ever had adequate financial resources poured into it particularly under the Liberal-National Party Government that operated until March this year. People involved in these areas have never had sufficient funding to enable them to proceed with some of the things that they wanted to do. But let me tell honourable senators about some of the subsidies that have gone to the uranium industry in Australia. In 1981-82 Federal subsidies to the uranium industry amounted to $83.6m of taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read out the subsidies for solar power, biomass and all the others.

—It is nowhere near $83.6m. If the honourable senator has those figures he is entitled to present them but he cannot justify those figures to compensate for the amount provided as subsidies to the uranium industry. An amount of $37.8m went to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission; $8.2m on uranium exploration and development; $23.2m on the Commonwealth uranium stockpile; $4.4m on environmental protection, a disgraceful amount; and $10m on infrastructure for the Jabiru township. Ownership of Australian uranium reserves is 64 per cent in the hands of foreign investors; it is not even owned by the Australian people. I am always dramatically reminded about the Australian Labor Party anti-uranium stand, and I noticed that Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned in his speech-I think I counted seven occasions-the ALP and whether we support or do not support mining and whether we will or will not go ahead with it.
—Are you opposed to it?

—My attitude on uranium has been well and widely known throughout this country for many years. I am totally opposed to uranium mining and I will remain totally opposed to uranium mining, and because my Party is democratic, I will have the opportunity to maintain that total opposition to it.
—Until it makes a decision.

—I will have to make a decision when that decision is made. Let me tell the honourable senator that I will make it being well aware of decisions I have made over the past years as a member of the Australian Labor Party and this Parliament. I remind the Senate of what Jim Falk wrote about the Australian Labor Party's anti-uranium stand in his book Global Fission. He put forward a principle that I uphold. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time in the world, a major political party had taken a principled stand against nuclear power, not merely because of the effects on the people who vote at the next national election, but because of the effects world-wide.
That is my principle. It is the principle that is expounded in the Labor Party's policy and in its general philosophy.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, when I closed the debate on the previous matter of public importance on this same issue only two weeks ago-this was the second occasion on which we had had a matter of public importance on uranium-I said that it was a nonsense matter of public importance. I say again that this is a nonsense matter of public importance. At a time when we have already agreed that the Senate will sit on two Fridays to enable us to catch up with business, this matter of public importance has been put forward purely and simply to waste the time of the Senate and the time of members of parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is most important that this topic is discussed, and the fact that it has been discussed on three occasions in the last three weeks or so is a good thing. So much can be said about the subject to inform people of the facts that I think we ought to have a debate on the issue every week for the next several months. I am grateful to Senator Kilgariff for drawing my attention to an article on page 130 of the current issue of the Bulletin. The article, which is entitled 'Australia: Uranium Giant Limps on Export Front' states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's proven and potential uranium reserves dwarf those of any other country. Already, uranium products are one of our major exports. The tide in the market is turning, David Haselhurst argues, and the potential is there for a huge expansion. But will politics be allowed to interfere?

I commend that article to honourable senators and suggest they should read it so as to get an idea of the potential of this resource, the effect it could have on the economy of Australia, and the job opportunities that would be presented.

I have listened with interest to Senator Townley during the debates. The honourable senator can bring to bear some intelligence on the subject, particularly because he has two engineering degrees and a pharmacy degree. He realises from a scientific point of view that what is being said by the anti- nuclear group within the community is, to a large extent, nonsense. I refer to the political aspect of this issue. I am afraid that Hawke will never be able to fly. In fact, I think he is in a spiral at the moment because of the devastating condition of his left wing. Until that left wing can be cured to enable the bird to fly in the right direction for Australia I think we will continue to suffer.

I was interested to hear what Senator Mason had to say. The honourable senator informed us today that the question of nuclear power economics is a problem. I can tell him that the Electricity Trust of South Australia is extremely concerned about the economics associated with coal fired power-stations. This problem is not only peculiar to Australia, it is also of concern to people in our Asian-Pacific region. I said the other day in a speech that the South Koreans at the moment are generating 9 per cent of their energy through nuclear power-stations and by 1992 that amount will grow to 51 per cent. One of the main reasons behind their decision to generate power by nuclear means is the economics associated with the transportation of coal to fire their conventional power-stations.

It is interesting to note when talking about waste and the usage of energy that a 1,000 megawatt coal-fired power-plant will use 60 million tonnes of fuel in 30 years and will produce millions of tonnes of various gaseous wastes and 15 million tonnes of ash. We must remember that for every tonne of coal that is burnt, 2.8 tonnes of carbon dioxide is emitted into the environment. It is also interesting to note that 15 million tonnes of ash would constitute a heap one square kilometer in area and 15 metres high. The ash containes cadmium and mercury, which are non-degradeable and do not decay. So billions and billions of tonnes of highly toxic waste are generated from that source of power.

A 1,000 megawatt nuclear power-plant and its associated fuel cycle facilities generates about 2 cubic metres of solidified high level radioactive waste and 23 ,000 cubic metres of lower level solid waste per year. These wastes remain under control and can be safely disposed of in special waste repositories. The information that is available to all honourable senators suggests that the solidification, the glassification, of highly radioactive wastes is a satisfactory way in which to deal with the problem.

I think we are all concerned about the need to get on with the technological development of nuclear fusion. I know that in America at the moment millions of dollars are being spent on that technique. It is a difficult technique. We can do it in the laboratory; we can do it at Flinders University, and no doubt other universities in Australia can do it in a matter of seconds.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be years and years.

—It will be years before this technique is perfected. The Americans are experimenting and spending a lot of money-billions of dollars-on the containment of this one million degrees centigrade technique through electromagnetic and laser containment. I think electromagnetic containment seems to be the way to do it. Sir Mark Oliphant, with whom I talked about this subject a few years ago, seemed to think that it be about 40 years before that technique was developed to any industrial extent. He said that the only way to look at solar energy is to utilise the hydrogen economy which will result from this technology. However, it will probably be 30 or 40 years before we get anywhere near the stage where we can use that technique to activate the globes in Parliament House. That is what we ought to be doing, of course, and the Americans are progressing fairly well in that area of research.

SPEECH.PARA: I have an interesting Press article headed 'Mine Uranium, says Union Chief', which states:
Uranium, as Australia's tenth largest export earner, should be mined, a union leader said today.
He is Mr Harry Hurrell, National Secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association.
Mr Hurrell was backing a statement by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, who said it was wrong in principle to leave Australian uranium in the ground.
'Last year Australia earned over $360m in export income from the sale of uranium,' Mr Hurrell said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said it was immoral to leave it in the ground?
—Mr Hawke is the person who made that statement, and he is being supported by a union leader, the National Secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia.
—Very good fellow, Harry Hurrell.
—He has good sense because he recognises that this industry, when properly developed, will provide hundreds of thousands of jobs in the long term in other industries that will develop as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hurrell goes on to say:
This will rise substantially once Roxby Downs begins production.

What the communists and their trendy left-wing supporters never tell us is that the Western world, the Soviet Union and the Comecon countries have over 294 nuclear plants successfully and safely in operation.

I think that my colleagues Senator Hamer and Senator Sir John Carrick referred to that. This is the support being given by a top union official, one of the sensible trade union leaders of this country. According to a gallup poll which I saw recently, his view is shared by 79 per cent of the members of the community who participated in that survey with respect to uranium. In addition to those 295 or so power stations that are operating at the moment in 25 countries, 243 are in the course of construction. Those stations will be of a greater capacity than those that are in service at present. Those 243 will be progressively brought into service over the next decade. At that stage of development the uranium required for generation of electricity for those stations will represent something like 23 per cent of the total amount of electricity to be generated at that time. This seems to me to be a trend in Asian countries and in other countries, which realise that this source of energy is with us. There is no denying that. There is no way in which the Australian Labor Party or the Australian Democrats can tell the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to stop building its 7,000 megawatt nuclear power station in, I think, Smolensk. There is no way in which it will stop nuclear power programs being carried out by the Eastern bloc nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just want to stop Australia.

—They want to stop Australia. That is what worries me most of all . The other day there was a demonstration of anti-nuclear people at Olympic Dam in South Australia. Some 400-odd people, many had children with them, took part. They came from a demonstration in South West Tasmania. I ask the question: Who is paying for those people to go there? I apprehended a young man who was polluting the environment in North Terrace. He was attempting to stick an anti- Olympic Dam placard on a wall in North Terrace. I made a comment to him that he did not know what he was talking about. I carried on my dignified stroll up North Terrace. He caught up with me and said: 'Aren't you worried about your grandchildren?' I said: 'Why do you say that?' He said: 'Because of the plutonium'. There is no nuclear weapon state in the world that has acquired its weapons through civil nuclear power. That is nonsense. Senator Sir John Carrick made that point. I gave that kid a little lecture for about 10 minutes on alternative energy sources. He did not know anything about the subject. I asked him whether he had a job. He did not have a job. He was unemployed and on the dole.
—Where did they come from?
—That person came from Sydney.
—Where did he get the money from?

—That is what I want to know. I strongly suspect that money is coming into Australia from overseas to pay the expenses of these people to go to Olympic Dam and other parts of Australia to be professional demonstrators with the objective of doing exactly what Senator Townley suggested, that is, retarding the economic progress of Australia. I think that it is treachery. To do those sorts of things is bordering on high treason, particularly when one talks to union leaders such as Mr Hurrell and members of the Australian Workers Union in Port Augusta who are very anxious to develop the uranium resources that we have in the area. South Australia has a large percentage of the world's deposits. In the interests of time-I do not have time to go through these points -I pose four questions and ask the experts in the industry to answer them. Firstly, is the Australian uranium industry economic? Secondly, does it have access to world markets? Thirdly, are contracts available for the sale of Australian uranium? Fourthly, what is the situation of uranium enrichment studies in Australia? I seek leave to have a document in this regard incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Notes on the Australian Uranium Industry
These notes deal with the following topics.
(1) Is the Australian uranium industry economic?
(2) Does it have access to world markets?
(3) Are contracts available for sale of Australian uranium?
(4) The situation of uranium enrichment studies in Australia.
Economic Viability

The quality of Australia's uranium resources in terms of grade, quantity and physical accessibility is higher than most deposits in other countries. Consequently, and as has already been demonstrated by the existing mining operations, our resources are competitive on the world market.

The competitiveness of Australian production has been recently demonstrated by the fact that the Ranger and Narbarlek projects have commenced successful and profitable operation in the Northern Territory while simultaneously a number of United States producers have ceased or curtailed production due to market conditions.

United States mine production in 1981 was 14,810 tonnes of contained uranium metal. In 1982 it had fallen 10,190 tonnes and for 1983 the estimated production is around 7,300 tonnes or less than 50 per cent of the 1981 level.

This 1981/83 time span is precisely the time when Ranger and Narbarlek were coming into successful production and confirming their competitiveness against many of the operators in the worlds largest producing (and consuming) country, United States. The outcome of these recent changes is that the United States will become a nett importer of uranium instead of a nett exporter since it now produces only half of its annual requirements, estimated at 13,000 tonnes of uranium for 1983.
The significant but as yet undeveloped uranium deposits of Australia are capable of producing on a basis competitive with overseas producers in the same way as Ranger and Narbarlek have demonstrated.

The larger undeveloped deposits are at Jabiluka and Koongarra in Northern Territory, Yeelirrie in Western Australia and Olympic Dam in South Australia. All of these deposits are of world rank. The first three were discovered before 1972 and Olympic Dam was discovered in 1975.

The companies involved in the discovery evaluation and development of these projects have of necessity made a very close study of the world uranium market over more than ten years. That all of them wish to proceed with development is a consequence of their judgment that the large investments required to develop these projects are worthwhile. These are the people of commercial judgment who are close to and understand the market in detail.
Access to World Markets

The Australian minerals industry has accumulated a great deal of experience in selling mineral products on world markets. Those responsible for the commercial operations of the uranium industry have this background available to them. These professionals are convinced that markets are available to Australia for the sale of uranium. Such sales are of course subject to the Australian Government conditions including Safeguards requirements and are restricted to countries with whom bilateral safeguard agreements have been completed or may be negotiated in the future. The government has recently withdrawn the '' determinations'' from those Australian companies who are seeking sales contract arrangements abroad. It is therefore not possible to conclude any further sales of Australian uranium at present.

The consumption of uranium for electricity production throughout the world is continuing to grow. During 1982 production of nuclear electricity increased by almost 10 per cent, making nuclear by far the fastest growing energy sector, which supplied approximately 10 per cent of world electricity. This share will reach 17 per cent in 1985 and 23 per cent or more by the year 2000.
In January 1983, 295 nuclear power reactor units were in service in 22 countries. This capacity is more than seven times larger than the total Australian electrical generation system.

In addition to the 295 reactors in service there are approximately 243 nuclear power reactors under construction throughout the world. The average capacity of the units under construction is considerably higher than the average of the in- service units. The commissioning of the units under construction will take place progressively over the next ten years and will more than double the annual rate of consumption of uranium for electricity production. Commitments for new reactors will add to demand into the 1990s. Six new reactors were ordered during 1982, a year of deep economic recession.

The managements of nuclear electricity generation utilities are obliged to secure fuel supply at least three and up to five years before any new unit comes into service. Security of supply is critical and therefore utilities seek long term supply contracts for uranium. These contracts must also be co-ordinated with the necessary conversion, enrichment, and fuel fabrication contracts. First physical deliveries of yellowcake are usually required to commence two years before reactor commissioning.
Some of the reactors now under construction and which are due for commissioning in the later 80's have not yet secured fuel supplies and these represent opportunities for Australian sales contracts.

Whilst the world market weakened during the past 2-3 years the position is changing due to the combination of declining United States' production on the one hand and increasing comsumption of uranium on the other as the world nuclear electricity industry continues to grow.

The crossover point between supply and consumption cannot be accurately predicted but it is expected to take place in the second part of the 1980's. A further complicating factor is the considerable stock of uranium oxide held by producers and consumers which will influence the market for some time.

The condition of the market over the past two years was reflected by the decline of the spot price from over $US40 in 1979 to as low as $US17.50 per lb uranium last year. The price has now recovered to $US23.25. However only 10 to 15 per cent of transaction tonnage is through the spot market and long term contract purchases are based on much higher price levels. Although the spot price is an indicator of short term conditions in the market it should not be regarded as relevant to the long term situation which is the concern of Australian producers and intending producers.
Inquiries continue to be received by the Australian industry for long term uranium supply.
Contracts Available for Australia
As already mentioned the Ranger and Nabarlek projects have secured long term contracts for much of their total forward production and are operating efficiently and profitably under those contracts.
However in assessing whether contracts would be available for new projects in Australia it is relevant to consider the Canadian position.
What will become of the world's largest uranium mine, Key Lake, in Canada, will commence production in July of this year. It has a planned maximum capacity of 4 ,600 tonnes of uranium metal per year.
Adequate contracts have been completed to enable production to commence and some 58 per cent of cumulative production up to 1990 and about 40 per cent up to 1995 has already been sold.

The Canadians have a long experience in uranium mining and sales and whilst the Canadian Federal and Provincial Governments take a responsible attitude to this industry and its export business they nevertheless support its development and exhibit a flexible policy which takes into account commercial and market situations from time to time.

Australia's uranium deposits are on a par with those in Canada in terms of quality and basic competitiveness. In addition there are a number of other factors which will favour new Australian producers in competing for satisfactory long term sales contracts.

Firstly, Australia has very large proven resources of uranium and potentially could emerge with the largest resources in the western world when in Olympic Dam deposit has been more fully evaluated. Our assured and probable resources now stand at about 550,000 tonnes of uranium. Indicated resources at Olympic Dam many increase this by one million tonnes.
Secondly, Australia represents to large uranium consumers an additional substantial and reliable supplier which would enable them to spread their risks of supply security.
There is an additional incentive for countries which share Australia's views on international safeguards to seek supplies from Australia in preference to other sources.

A number of countries are obliged to source uranium from South Africa, Namibia and other African countries which incur for them some political and supply security risks which would not be involved if Australian uranium was available.
The main disadvantage under which intending Australian producers find themselves at present is the uncertain posture of the Federal Government as to its uranium policies.

However the people in the industry believe that if government provides a supportive framework for its productive and commercial activities then inquiries that are being received at present could be converted into satisfactory contracts.
Enrichment

The Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia (UEGA) comprising a group of Australian companies reported last to the Federal Government in September 1982. This report was later tabled in parliament. No work is proceeding at present while the new government policy on enrichment is being clarified.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much in those questions to do with uranium enrichment. In closing, I wish to say that it is regrettable that the initiatives taken years ago by Mr Dunstan, the former ALP Premier of South Australia, have been neglected and overlooked by the ALP Government here. As the former Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, knows, South Australia was leading the way. Dr Tonkin, when he was Premier, tried to keep that ball going because it would have been in the interests of our State to have that significant industry, which is non-pollutant. There is no radiation. It is a chemical process which, under proper management, has no effluent that would cause any problem at all. In fact, the effluent that comes out of the uranium enrichment plant at Lucas Heights is purer than the waters of the river into which it flows. I think it is a very important subject to deal with. I am grateful to Senator Hamer for being able to say a little more about the subject which ought to be discussed as often as we possibly can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -It is with some reluctance that I take part, once again, in this debate. It could be a very valuable debate in this and in other places and one to which I would be happy to contribute if it were not for the fact that at least half of the contributions do nothing but drag out the tired old shibboleths, expose extraordinary paranoia and do nothing to add any light at all to the subject. Perhaps Senator Jessop's wits are somewhat dulled by his anxiety for South Australia's lack of energy. I suggest that South Australia buy some of Western Australia's natural gas. We seem to have an embarrassment of the stuff as a result of some excruciatingly bad decisions by the Court Government. The question of uranium mining seems to obsess the Opposition. I am quite amazed that so much emphasis should be given to the fact that Australia is exporting quantities of uranium which earn something like $380m in one year.
—It would have been $1,200m by now if-

—I inform Senator Townley, with all his scientific qualifications, that currently accepted macroeconomic policy holds that a zero balance on the balance of payments should be aimed at. In short, this means that any increase in a particular export would lead to an equivalent reduction in other exports, an increase in imports, an increase in incomes payable abroad, or some combination of these three results. The result would be in effect that an increase in any export area would produce an equivalent decline in the total of all other items in the current account of the balance of payments. This occurrence allows us to make some estimates of overall employment effects.

SPEECH.PARA: If the uranium mining workers receive the industry average pay of twice average weekly earnings and if various taxes, royalties, et cetera, are imposed on an industry average, we can estimate the value of these two components of the total average of exports. The remainder is corporate gross operating surpluses plus the value of intermediate goods, services, energy costs, et cetera, which are assumed to be split 50-50. With such macroeconomic assumptions this means that if additional net exports of $380m are generated by uranium exports other net exports must fall by $380m. Exports in other areas will fall; imports will replace local production, or some combination of the two will occur, which means a fall in Australian production of $380m. The job loss has been estimated at something like 10,000 jobs in less capital extensive industries and multiplier effects would cause much greater job loss. It is abundantly clear that whatever decisions are finally made-we will not be steamrolled or coerced by the Opposition or anyone else-the uranium industry is hardly the one on which this country depends for financial or employment recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this for you?

—It is all in my own fair hand. Even if there were such an argument I for one would consider the costs much too high, outweighing any so- called advantages as currently defined by the Opposition. Let us examine once again the facts about uranium mining. I will leave the economic theory if Opposition senators find that embarrassing. It is inefficient in the extreme in its social use of capital. Along with other failed elements of the so-called resources boom, it has had the effect of reallocating resources away from other parts of the economy, with devastating effects on the Australian work force. Capital available for development in Australia must be utilised to generate and maintain employment. Let Opposition senators disagree with that if they dare. Where many more jobs per dollar should be provided in secondary and tertiary industries, uranium mining provides few jobs but generates profits to be repatriated overseas or put into more labour destroying technology. We have plenty of evidence of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign capitalists clearly do not share the sensitivity that the Australian business community has lately shown. Unemployment and its corollary, lack of demand, has concentrated the minds of local entrepreneurs quite wonderfully. Is it the interests of foreign capital which concern the Opposition to the exclusion of all else? Does the Opposition really believe that the Australian Government should without serious investigation allow the commitment of social resources, capital, technology, labour and expertise to the production of a material which has an intrinsically negative value in being the raw material for nuclear weapons and having unaccepted social costs in safety, environmental and cultural problems throughout the process of production and usage.

If in the long run we are not all dead and the exploitation of uranium can be shown to be safe, Australia's deposits will still be there. They will not go rusty or mouldy, get flyblown or disappear. In the meantime may I repeat something that I said during the debate on 7 September. The responsibilities we have are unique in human history. We will be handing over to future generations responsibilities of monitoring and guardianship which we cannot be sure they will be in a position to discharge. That being the case, in 1983 we must acknowledge that there are still serious, important and potentially crucial questions to be resolved. They cannot be resolved in the course of a debate on a matter of public importance such as this. They can be resolved only in the context of a responsible government prepared to face up to these crucial issues. I move:
That the business of the day be brought on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have a statement on this paper incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
TABLING STATEMENT BY THE ATTORNEY-GENERAL, SENATOR THE HON. GARETH EVANS
Human Rights Commission Report No 5-Review of the Crimes Act 1914 and Other Crimes Legislation of the Commonwealth

Pursuant to section 30 of the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 I present Report No. 5 of the Human Rights Commission on a review conducted by the Commission of the Crimes Act 1914 and other Crimes Legislation of the Commonwealth.

One of the functions of the Human Rights Commission is to examine enactments for the purpose of ascertaining whether they are inconsistent with or contrary to any human rights, and to report to the Minister the results of any such examination.
The human rights with which the Commission is concerned are the rights and freedoms recognised and declared in certain international instruments, being-
the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights,
the Declaration of the Rights of the Child,
the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons, and
the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons.

The full texts of all of these instruments are set out in Schedules to the Human Rights Commission Act 1981, and the articles which are most relevant to this particular report are contained in Appendix 2 of the Report.

In addition to its functions under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 the Commission has functions relating to racial discrimination under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, and in particular the function of propagating the purposes and principles of the International Convention on the Elimination of All forms of Racial Discrimination. The present Report indicates that the legislation reviewed has been examined in the light of that Act and that Convention.
The particular Acts subjected to review in this report are as follows:
Crimes Act 1914
Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963
Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973
Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972
Crimes at Sea Act 1979
Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980
Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976
Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978
Crimes (Biological Weapons) Act 1976
Crimes (Overseas) Act 1964.

It is reported that ten provisions are inconsistent with human rights. In addition, questions are raised concerning three other provisions. The report does not go so far as to conclude that those provisions are inconsistent with human rights, but it alerts me and the Parliament to the possibility that this is so.
The provisions which the Commission concludes are inconsistent with human rights are as follows.
Crimes Act 1914

Section 17-which empowers a Court, when declaring a person to be a habitual criminal, to direct that on the expiration of the person's imprisonment, he be detained during the pleasure of the Governor-General. The Commission's view is that this provides for 'arbitrary detention'.

Section 20B-which requires that where a person has been charged with an indictable offence and is unfit to be tried by reason of unsoundness of mind or is acquitted by reason of unsoundness of mind at the time of the commission of the offence, the Court is required to direct the person to be kept in strict custody until the pleasure of the Governor-General is known. The view taken by the Commission is that this provision provides for 'arbitrary detention'.

Section 30FD-which provides for a disqualification from voting for the Parliament for seven years of persons who are members of the Committee or Executive of associations declared unlawful. The Commission's view is that this is an unreasonable restriction for a person who was not aware of the matter which gave rise to the association's being declared unlawful.
Section 78-which deals with the subject matter of espionage and, according to the Report, contains an unacceptable reversal of onus of proof.
Section 79-which deals with the subject matter of official secrets and, according to the Report, contains a similar reversal of onus of proof.

Sub-sections 82 (4) and 84A (2)-which contain provisions that female persons should only be searched by females and not that persons generally should be searched, where necessary, by a person of the same sex.
Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963

Sub-section 25 (1)-which empowers the person in command of an aircraft to arrest persons found committing offences against Part II of the Act or suspected of committing such offences. The Commission's view is that sub-section (1) should have a requirement that the bringing of the person concerned before a judicial authority should be done 'promptly'.

Sub-section 25 (2)-which empowers the commander of an aircraft in certain circumstances to place a person on board the aircraft under restraint or in custody, and if the aircraft is not in the course of a flight, remove a person from the aircraft. The Commission has stated that there is no requirement in this sub-section that the commander have reasonable grounds for considering it necessary to take the action envisaged. It has also stated that there should be a requirement that a person placed in restraint or in custody be brought promptly before a judicial authority.
Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973
Sub-section 9 (2) and (3)-which are viewed by the Commission as giving rise to the same problems as arise under sub-sections 25 (1) and (2) of the Crimes ( Aircraft) Act 1963.
Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972
Sub-sections 12 (2) and (3)-which are viewed by the Commission as giving rise to the same problems as arise under sub-sections 25 (1) and (2) of the Crimes ( Aircraft) Act 1963.
The provisions which the Commission concludes may possibly be inconsistent with human rights are-
Crimes Act 1914
Section 30AB-which permits the Attorney-General to require persons to provide information or documents relating to ''unlawful associations''.

Section 30D-which makes it an offence to donate, or contribute to or receive or solicit for an ''unlawful association''. The Commission has drawn attention to the possible application of this provision to a person who does not know that an affiliated association is in law, by reason of its affiliation, an unlawful association.

Section 70-which makes it an offence for a Commonwealth officer to disclose information acquired by virtue of his office which it is his duty not to disclose. The view taken by the Commission is that this provision may go further than is justified in restricting a person's right to impart information.

The provisions reviewed in this report are important provisions of our criminal law. It is very desirable that they should in no way be inconsistent with human rights and I shall be giving close consideration to the views which the Commission has expressed.

At this stage I can say that I am inclined to accept the Commission's conclusions relating to the two provisions for searches (sub-section 82 (4) and 84A (2) of the Crimes Act 1914). It is desirable that these provisions be suitably amended, although I understand that in practice administrative arrangements already provide for searches to be conducted in the manner that the Commission has proposed.

In relation to the recommendations on sections 78 and 79 of the Crimes Act, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has furnished a report on the desirability of avoiding provisions which reverse the normal onus of proof. I presently have that report (to the preparation of which I contributed as a then member of the Committee) under consideration and I will be taking into account the views which the Commission has expressed in this regard.

I am not inclined to agree with the conclusions the Commission has expressed in relation to section 25 of the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963, nor the corresponding provisions in section 9 of the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973 and section 12 of the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972, which are all important provisions for the protection of airline passengers.

The conclusion that sub-section 25 (1) should have a requirement that the bringing of the person concerned before a judicial authority should be done '' promptly'' is of course acceptable in principle, but inclusion of this language in the sections in question would appear to add little or nothing: the recommendation does not appear to have sufficient regard to the fact that the power to hold the arrested person in custody already operates only until he '' can be brought before'' the judicial authority.

Nor would there appear to be a need for sub-section 25 (2) to be amended to require the aircraft commander to have reasonable grounds for considering it necessary to exercise his powers under the sub-section. The sub-section already requires that the commander consider the exercise of his powers ''necessary . . . in order to prevent an offence . . . or to avoid danger to the safety of the aircraft or of persons on board'' it. If the commander does consider that to be the position there should be no doubt about his ability to act.

The Commission's conclusions that sections 17 and 20B of the Crimes Act 1914 provide for ''arbitrary detention'' will need to be examined more closely. Regrettably, the Commission's report does not refer to any relevant authorities or learning on what constitutes arbitrary detention. The fact that detention during the pleasure of the Governor-General is directed by a court is not adverted to; nor is there any discussion of the possible implications of provisions for administrative review.

The Commission's comment that section 70 of the Crimes Act may go further than is justified in restricting a person's right to impart information deserves close consideration, particularly in the light of the attention that this and related sections have received in the context of the Hope Royal Commission.

It would appear, overall, that-while this report makes a useful start-a good deal more work remains to be done to identify those provisions of Commonwealth criminal law which give rise to actual or possible human rights problems.

The task would appear to be necessary not only in relation to the statutes specifically considered by the Commision, but also in relation to a number of other specific pieces of Commonwealth legislation-e.g. the Atomic Energy Act 1953 and the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971-which have given rise to spirited criticism in recent years.

I propose, accordingly, to establish early in 1984 a Task Force to fully review the human rights aspects of the Commonwealth Crimes Act and other major Commonwealth criminal legislation, in the light not only of the present Human Rights Commission Report, but also in the light of such advice as emerges from the conclusions (if any) of the Hope Royal Commission on the scope and application of section 79 of the Crimes Act and related provisions.

Departmental resources for this purpose should become available when the Task Force presently working on a legislative package involving the enactment of an Australian Bill of Rights and amendments to the Human Rights Commission Act, Racial Discrimination Act and related legislation completes, or substantially completes, that project, as I expect it will early next year.

The proposed review of Commonwealth criminal law will be fully publicised when it gets under way and submissions are formally sought, but in the meantime I would welcome submissions or comment, including reactions to the Report tabled today, from any interested groups or individuals in the community.

This is a matter to which the Senate has drawn attention in the past. At least there is some indication in the report of some sensitivity to the fact that the report is extremely late. It is a subject that has been debated in the Senate and the Estimates committees at great length. I make the point again, and specifically in relation to this report, that when we have new bodies-the Interim Council was a new body when it was operating during this period-great difficulties seem to be experienced by them in sorting out just what the Auditor -General and the Department of Finance require of them in their financial recording. Getting reports presented to the Parliament within a reasonable length of time has been a perennial problem.

I am not sure of the present procedure of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, but it is my impression that under previous conditions a report that was presented at this late date with these sorts of dates on it would have been referred to that Committee. It is up to the new Committee to decide whether it still places that sort of priority on this subject of late tabling of reports.

The report contained some interesting information which is now so dated that it is not worth commenting on. It is information that would have been interesting prior to the tabling of the report of the Museum of Australia that we received in the Senate months ago. Consequently, I do not intend to comment in any detail on the content of the report. I simply say that it is a report that would have been useful several months ago.

Given that the Museum of Australia had difficulty in getting its financial clearances from the Auditor-General, I just wonder again, as I have wondered in the case of a number of other reports, why consideration was not given to the tabling of the interim report from the museum of Australia Interim Council, minus the financial statements but containing the bulk of the information in the report which is the sort of information the Parliament and the public is entitled to have when it is current information.
