SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to make a few comments on it because in the brief time that I have had the report available to me I have not been able to find anywhere in it mention of the number of personnel employed by Telecom Australia. That causes me a little concern. However, on page 9 the report states:
99 per cent of telephone services in Australia now have access to fully automatic telephone facilities. During the year, 10,000 services were upgraded to automatic.

That pleases me very much. Coming from Western Australia I have always been conscious of the need to have adequate communications for those people who live in the outback and in the north of Western Australia, particularly in the Kimberley and the Pilbara.

I was interested to receive in the mail a copy of the report on the Kimberley microwave system which I mentioned briefly during the matter of public importance on the uranium industry. I pointed out that one of the very important areas into which Telecom is moving is the provision of solar communication systems, which will create a much needed service. Nevertheless, it concerns me that nowhere in this report have I yet been able to find what is happening to those people who will be displaced or disemployed-I think that is the buzz word at the moment-because of the transfer to automatic systems. I know that the operators at Telecom have been expressing concern to all members of Parliament for some months now that they are being put out of work. I am particularly concerned because in those country areas the majority of people who work on telephone exchanges, for instance, are women who would not normally have access to any other forms of employment.

I will take a minute or two to comment also on the pages entitled 'Occupational Safety and Health'. They establish that as an industry Telecom is becoming vitally concerned with occupational safety and health. As I have pointed out, it is a major part of this Government's concern that there are adequate safety provisions for people employed in industry. It is interesting to note that the report states:

At the close of 1982-83, two years into our second five year accident reduction programme, Telecom achieved a lost time on duty accident frequency rate of 27.0 accidents per million man hours worked. This is by far our best performance. This current trend indicates that we have high hopes of achieving our target accident frequency rate of 20.0 by June 1986.

The administrators of Telecom are to be commended on that. I am also interested in the number of suggestions that were submitted by Telecom staff during 1982-83 which totalled 458. Of these, 72 were adopted and awards totalling $8,185 were made. The comment is also made that among those suggestions were a number which resulted in significant improvements in removing safety hazards. This will add to the occupational safety and health program that Telecom has undertaken.

I have to return to the problem that occasioned me to speak when this report was presented, that is, the concern about the employment of the telephonists, especially those in country areas. I would appreciate-I am sure that the administrators at Telecom read the Hansard-if someone could inform me at some time what is happening to those people who will be displaced and who have absolutely no opportunity in the isolated areas, particularly in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland, of obtaining other employment opportunities in their townships.

DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF THE CRIMES ACT 1914 AND OTHER CRIMES LEGISLATION OF THE COMMONWEALTH

PROCTEXT.PARA: Human Rights Commission Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This appears to be a most important report of the Human Rights Commission. It is accompanied by the text of a statement on the report by the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans), which was submitted to me only about an hour ago. This is very much in breach of the conventions of this chamber whereby the Opposition should be given adequate notice of statements of this kind. It is a very bad practice, one that seems to be growing, that ministerial statements are made in conjunction with the presentation of a report. It may be justified if the statement is a fairly minor one dealing, perhaps, with some factual matters but where there is a major report, as this is, and a major response to it is required, I think it is completely inadequate that it be dealt with in this way. Clearly, this is a matter that should be debated by the Senate at an early date and I hope that an opportunity will be given to do so. I have moved that the Senate take note of the paper in the hope that the debate will be adjourned to an early date and an adequate debate can take place.

I have had little opportunity of studying the Human Rights Commission report, but I have had the opportunity to look at it. It is a very important report because it contains a review of a great many criminal law provisions of the Commonwealth such as the Crimes Act, the Crimes at Sea Act, the Crimes ( Protection of Aircraft) Act, the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act, the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act, the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act and several other crimes Acts of the Commonwealth. It has considered them in accordance with its function of examining enactments that may be inconsistent with or contrary to any human rights and reported to the Attorney-General the results of any such examination. The examination which the Human Rights Commission made of these very important statutes of the Commonwealth has revealed the inconsistency of a number of provisions of these statutes with the international covenant. The Attorney-General has acknowledged that there will need to be an early review of these matters to determine whether amendments are required.

In its summary the Human Rights Commission has noted six main areas of concern. They are: Firstly, the detention of certain prisoners at the Governor-General's pleasure; secondly, the procedure for dealing with children and young persons who offend against Commonwealth law; thirdly, offences relating to unlawful associations; fourthly, disclosure of official information by Commonwealth officers; fifthly, reverse onus of proof and averment provisions; and sixthly, procedures for arrest, detention and trial of persons charged with criminal offences. They are of major concern. I think we are certainly indebted to the Human Rights Commission for its very thoughtful review and report. It is clearly in line with the object that the Fraser Government had in establishing the Human Rights Commission that it should tackle major questions of this kind in the light of its charter and should report to the Government and the Parliament, but that the decision on such matters should be made by the Parliament and not by some extraparliamentary or judicial body. I congratulate the Commission on the very careful and thoughtful report it made which, as I said, merits and demands very close consideration and debate in this Parliament and by the Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so that the number of members of the House of Representatives may be increased without necessarily increasing the number of senators.
Bill presented by Senator Macklin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

It is with great humility that I wish to bring before the Parliament of Australia today, a Bill which has had very distinguished support in this Parliament over a great period of time since it was first introduced by one of this nation's greatest parliamentarians on the 11th November, 1965.

This is a Bill of immense importance but of not great complexity in itself. It is designed to break the nexus-a term which we have all come to understand- created by section 24 of the Commonwealth Constitution. Section 24 states-and I want to state this matter with all possible clearness because I think that is vital to an understanding of it-

The House of Representatives shall be composed of members directly chosen by the people of the Commonwealth, and the number of such members shall be, as nearly as practicable, twice the number of the senators.
With these words, the then Prime Minister of Australia, and founder of the Liberal Party, Sir Robert Menzies, first introduced this Bill.
In concluding his speech he stated that:

I profoundly hope and I deeply believe that when this [Bill] is adequately explained to the people of Australia they will say ''Yes'' and they will change this rule and thereby make a tremendous contribution to making this Parliament an effective agent of the popular will.

Sir Robert was supported in his speech by the next speaker, the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Calwell, who stated that 'We regard it is vitally important to the well-being of the people and the welfare of the nation and the health of democracy that they [the two Constitution Alteration Bills being debated] should be carried. On their merits they deserve overwhelming endorsement'.

The Bill passed both houses on the 2nd December 1965 but the matter was not put to the people within the required period of time and so was re-introduced by the then Prime Minister, Mr Harold Holt on 1 March 1967. The Bill was substantially the same as that passed in 1965 except in that the minimum number of people to be represented by each House of Representatives seat was increased from 80,000 to 85,000 people. In concluding his speech, Mr Holt stated that if the proposals contained in the Bill were approved by the people 'this will constitute a significant advance in the efficient working of our parliamentary system.'

The next speaker was none other than that great statesman, the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Gough Whitlam. In his opening remarks Mr Whitlam stated that 'I can assure honourable members and all our fellow citizens that my Party, in the Parliament and outside the Parliament, will support this Bill and the referendum without reservation, equivocation or qualification.'
Amongst other notable speakers supporting the Bill at that time was the then Minister for the Interior, and now Leader of the National Party, Mr Doug Anthony .

Speaking in the House of Representatives he stated that 'The weight of work and the volume of legislation that has come before the House and is on the statue book has grown tremendously. This is why we believe that the size of this chamber (the House of Representatives) particularly needs to be increased. How are we to do it? It has been fully explained that there is a link between the two chambers-the nexus which prevents us from increasing the size of this chamber without increasing the size of the Senate by half the number. This has been looked at closely and it is thought that the Senate can continue to do a satisfactory job in protecting the rights of the States if it is kept at the present level of ten senators to each State. However the duty of preparing legislation and of looking after individual electorates has increased and there is a need to increase the size of this House.

The clean and satisfactory way of increasing the size of the House of Representatives is to break the nexus with the Senate. To do this we must hold a referendum to permit us to alter the Constitution. I have always supported the view that the nexus should be broken.'
I, for one, hope that Mr Anthony still holds that view and that he is able to convince other members of the coalition parties to back him up on this matter.

It would appear then, from the Hansard record, that there was strong emotional support from the Labor, Liberal and Country Parties on this matter on the two previous occasions when it was debated in Parliament. The arguments so ably put by Mr Anthony which applied in 1965 and 1967 still apply now. We are faced with a situation that in order to adequately represent people in the people's house, we must increase the number of representatives in that place, but in order to do so we are currently forced by the Constitution to also increase the number of Senators, an expense which is completely unwarranted at a time of limited budgetary resources, and at a time when the Senate has so ably demonstrated its ability to 'do a satisfactory job in protecting the rights of States' without an increase in its size.

The Australian Democrats are proposing this Bill at this time in an attempt to resolve the predicament which the Parliament now faces in regard to the need to increase its numbers in the House of Representatives at a time when any increase in the number of Parliamentarians is likely to be electorally unpopular.
In sponsoring this Bill we seek to both allow an increase in the number of members in the lower house and to limit the powers of the Parliament in the extent to which it can increase its size.

Constitutionally, we can enlarge the membership of the House of Representatives indefinitely and at will. The Constitution imposes no restriction on the numbers . In fact, it is to the contrary, as it insists that if the numbers in the House of Representatives are increased then we must also increase the numbers in the Senate in the ration of one to two. Under the proposal now before us, that burdensome necessity would be ended.
And the Bill goes further.

It proposes, for the first time in our history that there shall be a restriction placed on the size of the House of Representatives, by establishing that there will be 'not less than' 85,000 people for each seat. That is 85,000 men, women and children-whether they be voters or not. It could, at the discretion of Parliament be higher than that-90,000, 100,000 or even more; but it cannot be less than 85,000. At present there is no such restriction. Let me emphasise the re-emphasise that currently there is nothing in the Constitution to prevent us from deciding that there shall be one seat for every 30 or 40 thousand people, or whichever figure we might choose. As long as we also simultaneously and proportionately increase the Senate we can make the other house as large as we like. I do not think anybody wishes to do that. If this proposal is carried, we shall not be able to do it.

As Mr Calwell said in 1965: 'It is not those who support this proposal who want an extravagant increase in the number of Parliamentarians; it is, rather those who oppose it who would commit Australia in the quite near future to an excessive, extravagant and unwarranted increase of both senators and members of the House of Representatives. This is the inescapable consequence of the opposition of the people to whom I have referred, if their opposition is successful.'

Let us who still have some sense of responsibility to the people who elect us, rather than to the creation of more jobs for the boys and girls, show some leadership and put our support behind this Bill now.

The other issue which must be discussed is the effect of increasing the numbers in the Senate from 64 to 76, a proposal currently being considered by the Labor and National Parties, one can only imagine, for vested interests.

The matter was, I believe, ably addressed by Sir Robert Menzies when he first introduced the Bill in 1965 and I would like, with the Senate's indulgence to include the relevant part of that speech so that Senators can read at their leisure what that honourable parliamentarian had to say on the issue.

'Suppose that the Senate were increased in number to 72 . . . That would mean 12 senators from each State, six to be elected at each election. Under the present system for Senate elections-and nobody has been able to suggest a better system-the election of six senators from each State would almost guarantee in every State the election of three Government senators and three Opposition senators and so we would produce a deadlocked Senate, with every motion and every amendment defeated. I remind honourable members that section 23 of the Constitution states-

Questions arising in the Senate shall be determined by a majority of votes, and each senator shall have one vote. The President shall in all cases be entitled to a vote; and when the votes are equal the question shall pass in the negative.

I have always rather liked that phrase-'the question shall pass in the negative '. What it means is that the question will not be passed at all but will be resolved in the negative. That is the position in the Senate. A deadlocked Senate would not be any good to a government in this House, elected by the people, because nobody could pass a resolution and nobody could pass an amendment. Therefore, if there is to be a Senate in which a clear majority becomes possible, the numbers of the Senate would need to be such under the existing Constitution that an odd number would be elected every three years. Having mentioned the present odd number of 5, I must, therefore, go on to the next odd number of 7. If 7 were to be elected every three years there would be a Senate of 84 members and under the Constitution as it now stands, the House of Representatives would have 168 members . . . Nobody pretends for a moment that we want 168 members in the House of Representatives. Most people, realising the duties of members of the Parliament and the enormous and growing population that must be represented, would say: 'We ought to have 130 or 135 or whatever it may be, but we do not want 168'. I want people to understand that, under the Constitution as it is now, if this referendum were defeated, we could not increase the number of members in this House to fewer than 168 if at the same time we were to increase the membership of the Senate to an extent that made that institution workable.

This seems to me, and I think to all of us, to be quite clear. It follows from this that, as long as the present section 24 remains, the membership of this House must stand still or vary by perhaps only one or two, unless a massive increase is made in the numbers in the Senate.'

Honourable Senators will realise that in 1965 we did not have representation in this place from either the A.C.T. or the Northern Territory so that when Sir Robert refers to 72 and 84 we need to add another 4 and make appropriate adjustments to the corresponding House of Representatives figures. The Democrats strongly support Sir Robert's arguments believing that on current voting figures the result would be more or less the same today.

Perhaps it was an omen of history that this Bill should have been first introduced to Parliament on the 11th November; that the only Parliamentary Political Party to oppose the Bill at the time (and later in 1967) was the D.L.P .; and that the 26th Parliament, the Parliament which eventually put this matter to the people, was opened by the then Chief Justice of Australia, Sir Garfield Barwick. Perhaps it was an omen of history that the D.L.P., the party which exactly 10 years after the Bill was first introduced was to bring about the 1975 constitutional crisis in this country, was successful in getting the people of Australia to defeat this proposal. It is now time to rectify the mistakes of the past by supporting this proposal and going to the people with a united Parliamentary party support for this timely and imaginative Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Hamer) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend section 57 of the Constitution to provide that a dissolution of both Houses of the Parliament shall not take place by reason that the Senate has twice rejected, failed to pass or unacceptably amended a proposed law, if more than three months has elapsed after the Senate so treated that proposed law.
Bill presented by Senator Hamer, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of my proposed amendment to the Constitution is to bring the deadlock power back to its original, and still proper, purpose. It may be of interest that there was no double dissolution power in the 1891 Constitution, and it was only inserted in the 1897 Constitution after a prolonged campaign, primarily by Victorian delegates. The purpose was quite clear. It was to provide a mechanism by which a vital piece of government legislation which was vetoed by the Senate could somehow be put to the people for their decision. The original proposal was that this should be done by means of referendum, but ultimately it was agreed that it should be done by a double dissolution of both Houses of Parliament, after which, if the Senate was still obstructive, there should be a joint sitting of both Houses of Parliament.

For the first 70 years of our constitutional history this provision was little used-only twice in fact, in 1914 and 1951, but in the last 10 years it has been used 3 times-in 1974, 75 and 83, and the way things are developing it will, in my view, continue to be used very frequently, possibly going as far as to have a double dissolution every time there is an election for the House of Representatives. This would destroy the Senate as the continuing body envisaged by the Constitution.

The reason for this development is obvious. Prime Ministers feel that they may have a better chance of winning control of the Senate in a double dissolution than in a half Senate election and it has become almost customary to put up to the Senate a Bill known to be unacceptable and put it up again 3 months after it has been rejected and thereafter the Government has the trigger so it may have a double dissolution at any time the Prime Minister chooses.

This is, I believe, very de-stabilising for our whole political system. Worse still, I have heard no arguments to justify it. It is a gross distortion of the original purpose of Section 57 of the Constitution which I repeat was for the very narrow purpose of allowing a deadlock between the two Houses on a particular piece of legislation to be resolved by the people as a whole. It has reached the absurd situation that only one of the 64 present Senators-you Mr President-has ever served the full 6 year term.

What my amendment would do would be to provide that if the government had the grounds for a double dissolution because of deadlock over a particular piece of legislation, its power to have a double dissolution would lapse if it were not exercised within 3 months of gaining power. This would bring Section 57 back to its original purpose of resolving a dispute over a particular piece of legislation and prevent its being used in the grossly improper way it has been used in recent years. In 1983 for instance, the last election was ordered because of incurable deadlock between the two Houses, but most of the Bills concerned were about a year old, and we had no intention of re-introducing most of them even if we won the election. I don't think this sort of thing is a proper use of Section 57 of the Constitution and my amendment is aimed to prevent it happening again.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 8 September 1983.
Clause 47 (Proceedings in absence of parties).

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, could you give me some indication of where we are up to?
—Clause 47, and you have a motion to leave out proposed section 98A and to insert a new section.

—It has been some time since we debated this legislation. I do not know quite how long it has been, but is it any wonder that in picking up the threads after so many stops and starts there should be a bit of confusion.
—We are on the home stretch now.
—Senator Evans says we are on the home stretch.
—Not if Senator Walters has anything to do with it.
—Senator Haines is not quite right in saying not if I have anything to do with it. I have been very brief in my comments, and interjections like that will only make the debate linger on.
—Is that a threat or a promise?

—Both. I have already spoken on this clause of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983. I had outlined my concerns on the effect of divorce by post on the psychology of people approaching marriage. In 10 years time our children will have no concept of what it means to be married for life. If we put through an amendment that enables them, after being separated for 12 months, to fill in a form, send it in and at some later time receive a letter saying: 'Dear Mr or Mrs So and So, your divorce went through on such and such a date and you are now divorced', then the coming generations will have no idea of what the terms ' marriage for life' or 'a stable marriage' mean. As we have indicated all the way through this debate, the figures for divorce are going up at such a high rate that surely this Parliament needs to do something about it. Making the climate so easy that people will not think much about the marriage is, I believe a great disservice to the coming generations. I will have more to say about this later, no doubt. I know that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has already gone half way by not allowing parents to procure divorce by this method and I thank him for that. As far as I am concerned, that does not go far enough. As I have already indicated, and I have circulated my amendment, I want the whole procedure to be taken more seriously. I do not think that this is the way the Parliament should go about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Chairman, in view of the fact that the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 is an important piece of legislation and that, like me, a number of honourable senators did not believe that this would come on before 12.45 today, I draw your attention to the state of the Committee. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is debating an amendment moved by Senator Walters to the amendments moved by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to clause 47 which, in shorthand, has been described as the divorce by post clause. The amendment that has been moved by Senator Walters has some merit, but there may be honourable senators who may not wish to support it, but may wish, in fact, to vote against the proposal advanced by Senator Evans. My view about the proposal- having regard to the fact that Senator Evans has accepted the proposition that there should be attendance in court where children are involved-is, nevertheless , that I find myself against the proposition that has been advanced because I believe the issue is one of the nature of marriage and the educative role of legislation.

Marriage celebrants are bound under the provisions of legislation to furnish to the parties, when they have given the prescribed statutory notice of their intention to marry, form 14A referred to in section 42 (5A) of the Marriage Act. This form contains the words:
Marriage and family life have been basic to the strength of our society for a long time.
The Parliament in the Family Law Act has placed great stress on their importance . . .

The form then goes on to quote section 43 of the Family Law Act. Those injunctions become meaningless if the Parliament now adopts the amendments to proposed new section 98A contained in the Attorney-General's proposition. Australians contemplating marriage would be entitled to express confusion, if not alarm, if great stress were placed on their legal responsibilities prior to marriage with the knowledge that by proposed new section 98A their mutual rights and responsibilities could be terminated in what might be considered a perfunctory and inconsistent approach if the amendments to proposed new section 98A are adopted.
Marriage in Australia is a matter of public importance. Rituals are observed and, indeed, are required by legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I do not like to interrupt you in the course of your argument, but there seems to be some confusion as it is some time since the Committee last considered this legislation. I should make it clear that the two amendments moved by the Attorney-General to proposed new section 98A were adopted by the Committee. So that is history. Senator Walters then, by leave, moved for the omission of the whole proposed new section 98A and for the substitution of a new section. So the Attorney-General's amendments have already been adopted by the Committee.
—But the clause will be subject to being voted out?
—That is correct. Senator Walters, by leave, moved an amendment to delete the whole proposed new section 98A and to substitute a new one. That is what we are now debating.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I am anticipating that Senator Evans' s amendment will not be adopted.
—Senator Evans's amendments have been adopted.
—But with the deletion of the whole of clause 47 they will not be.
—Yes. It is an unusual procedure, but Senator Walters did it by leave of the Committee.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Marriage in Australia is a matter of public importance. Rituals by legislation, indeed, are observed prior to marriage by the couples themselves to demonstrate and acknowledge this fact. Engagements are announced; banns used often to be read, but not so often now. The banns are sometimes now read as external evidence of the forthcoming marriage. There are other external features such as the exchange and wearing of rings; they are a constant public reminder to the community at large of a couple 's commitment to each other and, indeed, to marriage as an institution. Both in church and in civil ceremonies the presence of an authorised celebrant and the presence of witnesses to the ceremony and to the contract are required by law. Celebrants are bound to emphasise the voluntary, exclusive and permanent nature of the contract in the words that they address to the couple during the ceremony .

SPEECH.PARA: What Parliament is now asked to do is to reverse the public character of marriage and to abandon any safeguards where parties take the far more important and far more consequential step of seeking a civil dissolution of marriage. This step demands a public recognition that the parties have given recognition and deliberation to the effects of their terminating a marriage, at least equal to that which they gave upon their entering into the marriage. The public order and common good of society demand that the couple are aware of their continuing responsibilities to each other. They had obviously entered into legal commitments to each other. They need to separate with dignity and with respect for each other and for their ongoing legal undertakings.

Quite frequently one spouse earnestly desires that divorce proceedings be defended. However, that spouse is also very well aware of, and frequently disenchanted with, the legal process when he or she realises only to well that there is no further recourse open to him or her once a mere 12 months separation can be demonstrated. Proposed new section 98A can become yet another unremitting weapon with which to bludgeon a spouse into submission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, really!

—Senator Missen obviously does not understand the educative effect of legislation passed by this Parliament. In fact, proposed new section 98A makes provision for disillusionment amongst a large number of people, particularly those who would dearly love to see the divorce not take place and would like it to be defended. The proposal under proposed new section 98A, the divorce by post proposal, can further weaken the resolve of one of the parties to attempt reconciliation. Under this proposal, paper rather than people, becomes important. Mutual trust and respect can be further undermined. I am saying this largely in prospect; it can be undermined.

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence is clear that interviews conducted with wives seeking to improve and sustain the marriage or to separate with dignity and without recrimination are double the number conducted with husbands who present for counselling. In 1981-82 the approved counselling organisations conducted 47,010 joint interviews , 52,597 wife alone interviews but only 23,967 husband alone interviews. Many of those wives may well be the victims of our legislation and appreciate only too well who are the victims and the long term casualties of the family law legislation. The proposals by the Attorney-General which are before us would further increase the tendency towards justifiable grievance already being experienced by those spouses who seek the protection of the law and for the ultimate strength of society, to which I referred in my opening remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the Hansard report and have seen the point I had reached on 8 September. I find that there is one more point I should like to make. I had come to the point at which I was saying that the opposition to my motion had been based on the ground that the Government's proposal would be much cheaper. Indeed, the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act that brought in the first recommendation of divorce by post said:

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue is one of costs, both to the State and to the parties involved.

I refer to Senator Gareth Evans's own letter, which he sent to all honourable senators and honourable members, on the divorce by post amendment. I shall quote part of a paragraph on page 2. The other part of it refers to couples with children, and I shall omit that because that matter has been overcome. He said:

First-number one-there will be significant cost savings for those parties who do not wish to be present or to be represented at undefended divorce hearings. Secondly, there should be a considerable saving of court time . . .

So the people who are for this divorce by post are mainly concerned with costs, both to the people involved and to the state. Whilst I agree that cost has some relevance in most of the things that we do in our lives, I believe that cost should not have the major relevance in this area. The decision as to whether one gets divorced or otherwise is a serious one and it should not be based on costs alone. The Government makes it possible for people to file for divorce and, indeed, at present to be defended in divorce cases, for those who cannot afford that. But the proposition that there should be no cost at all to the state or to the people because they want to get a divorce as quickly and as easily as possible has no grounds. Under my amendment there would be no need for legal representation. There would be no need for legal costs. The people would just have to appear before the judge on their own, with their own statements that they have been separated for the required time, and answer the questions that the judge puts to them. Under my amendment there would be no need for there to be legal representation, and therefore the only additional financial cost to the couple involved would be the fares to the court. The savings of court time in this regard would be acknowledged. There would be savings of court time under divorce by post, but certainly not to the individuals involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clause that the Government seeks to retain in the Family Law Amendment Bill, new section 98A of the Act, as it will be, is designed simply to enable regulations to be made to give the Family Court a discretion, in certain really very limited circumstances , to determine undefended divorce proceedings without the necessity for the parties or their legal representatives attending a court hearing. It has been labelled 'divorce by post'. Perhaps a less tendentious description would be ' divorce on the papers'. But the implication is clear, in either event, as to what is involved. I do not think that it has been sufficiently appreciated by most people who have contributed to this debate, certainly not outside the Parliament, that what is proposed is very little different from the situation that prevails at present. The parties are not required to be present in court at the moment but need only be represented by their legal advisers. In fact, in undefended divorce proceedings this is required only of one party-namely, the applicant. I know that this is not a misapprehension shared by other senators in this place, but it is certainly shared by very many people in the community at large-the belief that as the situation stands the parties must be physically present at the time that the dissolution is accomplished. That is not so. Of course, the effect of Senator Walters's proposed amendment would be to make it so, because she proposes-I quote her amendment-that:

SPEECH.PARA: At the date fixed for the hearing of proceedings for dissolution of marriage, both parties to the marriage shall attend the court, unless the court, in its discretion, determines that the attendance of either or both parties is not practical.

But the situation as it stands certainly does not require the attendance of either of the parties in any of these situations. The circumstances in which the Family Court, under this proposal, would be able to exercise the discretion to grant the dissolution on the papers, the affidavits before it, are these. I indicate them because they constitute significant safeguards against the cavalier use or misuse of this particular procedural proposal.

First, the proceedings have to be of an undefended kind, not contested by either party. Secondly, one of the parties has to have positively requested the court to determine the proceedings in the absence of the other party. Thirdly, the other party, after having been given proper notice of the intention to conduct the dissolution proceeding in this way, has to have not advised the court of his or her intention to be willing to be present. So we have to have a situation in which it is an undefended case, one of the parties specifically wants the matter to be dealt with in this way, and the other party, after having been told about this, has gone along with that state of affairs. The benefits that flow from this are essentially those in the letter of mine that was read out by Senator Walters. So far as the parties are concerned, there will be savings in terms of personal convenience. Senator Walters may not rate that very highly, given the significance that she and Senator Harradine ascribe to the dissolution proceeding, but the convenience factor must be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be quite costly.

—More particularly, I move beyond convenience to cost, so far as the parties are concerned, because there are many instances in which it is not the case that both parties are resident in the metropolitan area where the particular registry is located and parties may have to come from interstate or the country or elsewhere, and it is a matter, applying Senator Walters's criteria, as to whether the court would regard that as constituting an impracticality for the purposes of the operation of her proposed clause. Certainly she seems to ignore completely the fact that for very many people in the community attendance at a court in this way would involve the loss of a day' s wages and represent quite a significant cost penalty to the individuals in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The other consideration-Senator Walters clearly acknowledged this-is the considerable saving of court time, which would enable the more difficult contested proceedings relating to children and property to be heard and determined more speedily. To the extent that the opposition to this had been based on concerns about the welfare of children, then of course that matter has now been amply taken into account, I would have thought, by the amendment that has already been moved by me and accepted by the Senate which confines the availability of this procedure to cases where no children are involved. That, of course, is an additional criterion which has to be satisfied and I should have listed it earlier on. That, of course, as I have indicated a number times earlier in this debate, on the figures to which we have become accustomed, means that something like 40 per cent only of dissolutions would become eligible, even at the threshold, for this procedure because it is the case that something like 60 per cent of marriages that are being dissolved do, regrettably, involve children under the age of 18 years. So it is only in a very limited set of circumstances that this amendment is proposed to apply and it will, undoubtedly, produce the benefits that I have indicated.

What do the criticisms of this boil down to? Basically, they seem to be twofold . One of them, and it has not been very strenuously canvassed in this debate-it certainly has been in the popular reaction to this proposal-is the suggestion that divorces will somehow be easier to obtain under the proposed procedure. But whatever the particular procedure that is adopted under this amendment, and that is still to be spelt out in regulations, the Family Court will still have to be satisfied on the basis of evidence before it that the ground for granting a divorce has been established and that there is no reasonable likelihood that cohabitation will be resumed. The evidence on which the Family Court relies right now is overwhelmingly documentary evidence in the form of affidavits. It is on the basis of that evidence that the court does now act in the overwhelming majority of cases and will continue to act in the case of the divorce on the papers procedure. In the event that the court is left in any doubt as to whether the proper grounds had been made out, there is provision for requisitions to be made and for further requests to the parties for further information. So there is simply no foundation whatsoever for that particular kind of concern.

If we take that out as being without foundation and if we take out the concern that somehow the interests of children are not going to be sufficiently taken into account in a hearing not involving the presence of the parties physically or their representatives, all that one is really left with is the proposal which waxed so large in both Senator Walters's and Senator Harradine's contributions to this debate and that is the objection really based on considerations of symbolism-the symbolic significance in supposedly devaluing a marriage further, they say, by a procedure of this particular kind. It is said that given the seriousness attaching to the termination of marriage, both parties should be present in court when the decree is pronounced. This is not, of course, a requirement under the existing law, I repeat, but it would be the requirement if Senator Walters's amendment were to carry the day. I think it has to be said, and said over and over again, that to--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not.

—I will say it only once but I will put a sort of squared sign on it. To approach the problem in this way is to misconceive wildly what goes on in the Family Court at the moment, to ascribe a far greater degree of ritualism and symbolic significance, gravitas and pietas and all the rest of it than actually exist. It is not in denigration of those who conduct the Family Court proceedings or anyone else to say that the dissolution hearings, as they operate at the moment, represent nothing so much as a highly efficient sausage machine, with the dissolutions going through at the rate, on average-I had a brief experience of this process at work and I suspect that proceedings were rather elongated for my benefit-of one and a half or two minutes. That may or may not mean a great deal to the parties if they happen to be there at the moment, as they are not required to be. I doubt it. I suspect that the requirement of 12 months separation that is necessary to establish irretrievable breakdown of marriage is of far greater importance than a brief courtroom appearance in bringing home to parties and to intending divorcees the consequences of a divorce. It is a matter of impression and impressions will differ on this particular subject. But I would hope that we do not have too much sentimental claptrap talked on this particular matter. We do recognise on this side of the Senate that divorce is a serious business. I think everybody who has ever been associated with the operation of the legal system in this respect acknowledges that fact. Let us appreciate the very limited scope of the amendment that is now being sought. Let us appreciate the advantages that flow from it and let us accept, without further demur, the particular proposition that has been put forward by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 September 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of speaking today, in this debate on the first reading of a money Bill during which senators can raise any particular subject which concerns them, about a matter which I believe is a very serious problem not only in our capital cities but also in the outback of Australia. I refer to glue and petrol sniffing. Honourable senators may have noted that in the last few months there has been quite a lot of media coverage regarding petrol and glue sniffing despite, apparently, some type of official policy of silence. I can well imagine that the authorities most conversant with this matter and who have the statistics on petrol and glue sniffing at their fingertips would know the serious problem that exists. Because of the wish to have this mantle of silence on this matter, I can only assume that the authorities believe that the problem is so immense that they cannot handle it. They seem to have their heads in the sand. I hope not. But in any case I believe that action is most necessary now to bring about some understanding of the problem and to alleviate it.

SPEECH.PARA: This problem is a serious one in many Australian communities. Children from all social classes are involved. It is prevalent in the cities, the towns and the country. It is not a new problem. In fact in the Northern Territory it has apparently been around since the Second World War when troops sniffed glue and petrol to get some kick. But it has become increasingly worse over the last few years. Between May 1974 and February 1979 there were some 20 deaths from petrol and glue sniffing. There have been a number of fatalities this year. The products that are abused are petrol, glue, gas lighter fuel, pain relief sprays used in sport, typists correction fluid and thinners. Fatalities from the use of all of these products have occurred during the last eight months of this year.

The sniffing problem, as I have already mentioned, has been a very serious one in Aboriginal settlements in the Northern Territory. Over the last month I have covered most settlements in the Northern Territory. Indeed, I have covered several thousand miles. I have been concerned to see that the practice of petrol sniffing has been extended. It is not being confined to a particular area but is actually spreading. I have known petrol sniffing to exist in certain Aboriginal settlements for many years but now I find that the practice is being extended. As I say, it happens not only in Aboriginal areas but also in towns, involving pupils at schools. This serious problem is probably brought about by boredom, loneliness, unhappiness, problems of escapism, peer group pressures and the like . It has very serious consequences for the children on Aboriginal settlements and in the towns. I know of personal injury and illness involving Aboriginal people, as well as accidents, threats to police, increased violence and the destroying of buildings. It is a major problem in dry areas where there is no alcohol, but it is a problem also where alcohol is available. Petrol is cheaper and more easily obtained-petrol can be stolen.

I have noted, too, from my visit only last week to a couple of settlements in Arnhem Land that there has been an attempt to introduce a vile type of additive to the petrol in an endeavour to stop people sniffing it. But there is a means of overcoming this, and that is by separating the additive from the petrol. I will not indicate how that is done in a public speech, but the additive is not a success. It is mainly petrol that is sniffed but there is also the problem of aerosols and cleaning fluids which are easily obtained at any shop. The problem is becoming more widespread in Australia as more children discover it.

I believe that the Senate should take up this matter. I seek the support of the Senate in taking action to eliminate the problem. A wealth of material is available on the issue, and I draw honourable senators' attention to an organisation called SOS-Save our Sons. This organisation was formed in Australia ; it is a working party comprising parents who have lost children. They say that considerable information is available regarding petrol sniffing. This working party covers very many organisations and it is my intention to have incorporated in Hansard a letter from that organisation and also a description of the work of SOS, its aims and a petition for which signatures are being collected at present .
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
19th September 1983 The Honourable Senator Kilgariff
C/o Parliament House,
Canberra A.C.T. 2600.

Dear Senator Kilgariff, Thank you for expressing an interest in the work of S.O. S. We have amassed a wealth of material on the subject of 'sniffing' through the resources of organisations such as the Australian Consumers Association, Aboriginal Training and Cultural Institute, N.S.W. Drug and Alcohol Authority and National Press. We are unfortunately not in a position to photocopy all of this material for you-you see, we are just two ordinary parents who have limited financial resources.

We are however enclosing lists of the material currently available for your information and would be happy to photocopy any specific articles, or sections on particular topics (e.g. Aboriginal sniffing, treatment ideas, legislation, etc.) provided you could arrange photocopy facilities here in Sydney (or payment in lieu thereof).

For your information we are also enclosing a brief history of S.O.S. which, as you can see, started following the deaths of our son and other local children. We have obtained press clippings from just one media source which detail many deaths since 1975, and of course these are only reported sniffing deaths-largely in the Sydney area.

The currently abused products are pain relief sprays (as used in sports), butane gas lighter fuel and lighter fluid, petrol and typist correction fluid and its thinners. Fatalities have occurred from all of these products within the last eight months.

With regard to petrol sniffing in Aboriginal Communities as you are no doubt aware the N.T. Drug and Alcohol Authority organised a major conference in 1982 and produced a report (see 1.2.1). A much more detailed study of the problem was conducted in South Australia (see 1.6.1). And finally the Aboriginal Training and Cultural Institute (based in Sydney), has produced three booklets aimed specifically at isolated Aboriginal Communities. Copies of these are enclosed.
We believe that there is a need for action in three areas-Legislation, Education and Treatment.

We have formed a working party comprising ourselves (parents who have lost children), a representative from the Australian Consumers Association, the Aboriginal Training and Cultural Institute, and WHOS (We Help Ourselves). The working party is currently preparing information leaflets designed to be aimed at specific audiences (police, parents seeking information, politicians, media ( guidelines) and professionals offering treatment services, etc.
We are unable to give a date when these pamphlets will become available as we are currently without means for printing them.

As a result of our radio and television appearances, which of course breached the official policy of silence, we are also in possession of over eight hundred letters, from all over Australia. They came from three categories of people:
(a) parents who have children who are 'sniffing' and who are seeking help from us;
(b) teachers and social workers who have come across the problem and are seeking information and advice from us;
(c) many, many concerned people who have seen, read or heard about us on the media and want to help or are requesting more information.

Finally we are intending to prepare a detailed research report which extracts major information available overseas and places it within the Australian context as seen from our own experience. (Again we have no definite production date-nor, as yet any idea of whether we will be able to obtain any support in printing and distributing it).

Senator, we are determined that the subject of 'sniffing' must be brought out of the closet and handled in a sensible, responsible manner and that parents and professionals be made fully aware that the current policy of silence and inaction should not continue.
If you need any further information or photocopies of news articles, letters received etc, please contact us again.
Yours faithfully, JAN OSWALD. S.O.S.
SUGGESTED WAYS IN WHICH YOU CAN HELP US
Become a member of S.O.S. and (give us power in numbers).
Approach and/or write to your local member of Parliament and seek assistance for the S.O.S. aims.
Inform the appropriate people about S.O.S. and its aims.
Set up your own self help groups (in consultation with your local Drug and Alcohol authority).
S.O.S.

A network of concerned parents which aims to bring to an end the increasing common habit of deliberate inhaling (''sniffing'') of intoxicating substances ( from consumer products) which has caused illnessess and irreversible long term effects with many sad cases resulting in the deaths of their children.
P.O. Box 134.Marrickville, N.S.W. 2204.
AIMS

1. To educate the community as to the serious dangers of the deliberate inhaling of intoxicating substances from consumer products. To do so in such a way so as to not arouse interest in such experimentation.
2. To raise public awareness as to the growth of this serious problem.
3. Conscience raising of manufacturers and retailers. Urging them to take the responsibility for correcting this dangerous situation, by proper marketing with safety instructions.
4. To lobby for the elimination of dangerous products from sale to minors.
5. To lobby for relevant Health authorities to become responsible for the safety of children in relation to such dangerous products.
6. To lobby for new legislation for stricter product control.
7. To become a referral service for those experiencing the consequences of this problem and for those interested in helping others.
8. To become an umbrella organisation for self-help groups and individuals who are interested in eliminating this danger.

9. To be a supportive network for those faced with this problem both directly and indirectly. To inspire the setting up of self-help groups aimed at helping individuals to overcome dependency on these dangerous substances and to those who have their loved ones participating in this.
10. To give the opportunity for those interested in this problem to become involved in the aims of S.O.S., either as members or indirectly.
PETITION TO BE PRESENTED TO COMMONWEALTH MINISTER AND STATE MINISTERS FOR HEALTH AND EDUCATION
We the undersigned, do hereby declare our support in respect of representations to be made to the various Ministers for Health and Education, seeking the following:
1. The re-scheduling of all aerosol pain relief sprays containing fluorocarbons and/or hydrocarbons and any derivative thereof to a schedule 2.
2. The restriction of sales to minors of pain relief sprays, products containing trichloroethane, thinners, glues that contain toxic chemicals, acetones, lighter fluids and other dangerous toxins.
3. That a more effective legal approach to the labelling and packaging of the above-mentioned is sought.
4. That controls be placed upon manufacturers and retailers in respect of the manufacture and sale of the items referred to above.
5. That a compulsory government backed and funded Health and Drug education programme be instituted in all schools as soon as possible, and must include, Volatile Substance Abuse.
6. The abolition of fluorocarbons in aerosol cans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps honourable senators have heard of Jan Oswald, one of the organisers of SOS, who is endeavouring to have this problem rectified. In bringing her plea to the Senate I ask that this problem of petrol sniffing be taken seriously by the Senate. Later I will come back to the Senate with a further proposal, for I believe it is most necessary that we investigate the matter. Honourable senators will gain much more information on the petrol and glue sniffing problems from the letter of Jan Oswald, who is the President of the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, I did feel that the problem of petrol and glue sniffing was confined mainly to the outback, to those people in isolated areas where I guess remoteness, loneliness and boredom have created a situation on which this problem feeds. But I note in the files given to me by the SOS organisation that there are very many pleas from people all around Australia-from parents, from school teachers and from people seeking information on what they can do to assist our youth in breaking the practice of glue and petrol sniffing. Glue and petrol sniffing can bring about permanent illness, irreparable damage to the body and particularly to the brain. Our young people can be destroyed by this practice which they pick up from others; they can be mere vegetables for the rest of their lives. As I have indicated, there is evidence of severe illness in these young people and also deaths have occurred. I believe it is timely for the Senate to take up the matter. I look forward too to Federal and State health authorities moving to attack the problem. As I have said before, to quite a degree the authorities seem to have thrown a blanket of silence over this matter . Do they think that making the matter more public will lead to more glue and petrol sniffing? Is that their attitude? All I can say is that the practice is so widespread now that their fear that it will be further spread by publicity no longer applies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity during this first reading of the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1983 to draw attention to a problem which was the subject of an excellent article in the National Times of 27 May of this year, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the number of young Australian women dying from cervical cancer has taken a sudden sharp increase.

The great tragedy of this is that carcinoma of the cervix is a substantially preventable disease but until very recently its cause and incidence have been matters largely of conjecture. Over the last three decades increasing use of oral contraceptives and a consequent decrease in the use of barrier methods of contraception has meant that the sexually active of both sexes are more liable to sexually transmissable diseases such as the herpes virus, gonorrhoea and non- specific urethritis.

Recent work at the Westmead Hospital, as recounted in the National Times article to which I referred earlier, implicates the genital wart or papilloma virus as a cause of carcinoma of the cervix, having demonstrated that cervical tumours have actually contained DNA and protein from that virus. Such tumours develop slowly and the woman with genital warts may be completely unaware of their presence unless or until she has a thorough examination and a cervical smear. Screening programs exist in all main cities and careful health authorities everywhere should remind women to have regular tests.

The conventional wisdom has been that the woman at risk is one whose sexual activity commenced at an early age and who has frequently changed partners. It is manifestly unfair that women who become victims of carcinoma of the cervix are at least by inference blamed firstly for being promiscuous and secondly for failing to take the precautions which medical authorities believe could practically eliminate the disease. The bad old double standard still flourishes, as indefensible as ever, especially in the light of recent evidence which suggests that the epidemiological approach which I earlier described is too narrow.

A paper entitled 'Carcinoma of the Cervix: Occupational Risks of Husbands and Wives and Possible Preventive Strategies', by Jean Robinson, published in the proceedings of the Ninth Study Group of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists in October 1981, suggests that an examination of social and occupational risks may offer more opportunities for preventative action and may also provide clues for unanswered questions as to why some early lesions progress and others do not and why some apparently low risk women become victims . While previously the search, as described in the National Times article, had been for a virally transmitted carcinogen in organisms such as herpes simplex and the wart virus, it is now thought that the agent may be purely chemical. The obvious choice would be a heavily metallic ion picked up as a by-product of ordinary contamination from an unhygienic man.

A study of smears from almost 300,000 women in Manchester from 1965 to 1972 found a high correlation of mortality rates from cervical cancer and certain occupations of husbands. Wives of fishermen, deck and engine room ratings, and barge and boatmen were heavily over-represented in the sample, with the added acknowledged risk of having husbands whose jobs entail long absence from home. Miners' wives had a higher incidence than other women of the same social class as defined by the British Registrar-General. Other high risk women in England and Wales were married to forge and foundry workers, metal furnacemen, steel riggers-who themselves suffer disproportionately from carcinoma of the scrotum, probably from exposure to mineral oils-glass and ceramic process workers, chemical production and process workers, plasterers, brick layers, metallurgists and chemists.

Robinson acknowledges the difficulty in distinguishing between the risks which may arise from the woman's own occupation and that of her husband, for example in textile towns where many women work in the mills, and there is clearly 'some factor increasing the risk of cervical cancer', to quote a 1955 study. Her purpose, she says, 'is to raise questions which have not hitherto been asked, to avoid possible real injustice to women whose deaths are at present attributed to their own promiscuity, when other causes have not been examined'.

The crusade against this disease has concentrated on screening rather than prevention, a policy now being questioned by women themselves. Regardless of the health care system, those at greatest risk are the least likely to submit to regular tests, and to be effective every woman during her childbearing years should attend for a smear, pelvic and breast examination at regular intervals of 12 months.

Robinson believes that carcinoma of the cervix is preventable and advocates a number of simple measures. Health education should include genital hygiene, especially washing before intercourse. The use of talc in the genital area should be avoided by both sexes. Barrier contraceptives having been associated with reduced risk, boys should be educated in the importance of using condoms rather than expecting their partners to be on the pill. I am told that users of condoms in Australia should be warned against using the green condoms which the magazine Choice has demonstrated to have a lower bursting point, making them totally ineffective, if not downright dangerous. In view of the reduced incidence of cervical cancer in women with vasectomised partners, where a choice is to be made about sterilisation male sterilisation appears to be preferable to female especially when the male is exposed to metals, tars or other chemicals. Women taking oral contraceptives should be encouraged to attend a clinic annually at most to have breast and pelvic examination and a papanicolaou smear. Cervical cancer is a potentially lethal disease but if pre-cancerous cells are detected early local treatment can be 100 per cent effective.

My principal point, however, is this: If the occupation of a woman or her sexual partner increases cervical cancer risks, safety in the work place takes on a new dimension. Safety legislation is designed to protect the worker, and in dirty occupations it is only the lungs which are assumed to need protection. It seems highly probable that women-young women-have died for want of simple preventative measures. Precaution takes on a new meaning. To require of males the liberal application of soap and water and the use of condoms is surely not unreasonable and offers a far greater scope for mass preventive measures than permanent virginity or taking of the veil, which one might have previously deduced was the only sure way of avoiding carcinoma of the cervix.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity on the first reading of the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill to make some comments in relation to two cases which are currently before the courts. I will not, of course, be commenting on the substance of the cases but rather on the Commonwealth Government's obligations in regard to these cases. The first case I wish to raise is that of Bird v. the Commonwealth of Australia. This case is being funded by the Legal Aid Office in Queensland as a test case to define the rights of Australian nuclear veterans. The legal assistance granted to the plaintiff extends only to the plaintiff's own costs and does not currently extend to any costs awarded against him by the court. In actions such as this costs are likely to be large and, because new legal ground is being broken, there must undoubtedly be a substantial risk of failure. The Commonwealth has so far given no undertaking not to act upon an order for costs against the plaintiff. Unless it does so, the rights of the Australian nuclear veterans will not realistically be able to be fully ventilated in court.

SPEECH.PARA: The law is uncertain as to whether or not the Crown can be liable to a serviceman, assuming, of course, that the service man or woman can establish all necessary elements of negligence on the part of the Crown. This raises the possibility that the parties may spend several years prosecuting this action and exhausting avenues of appeal only to find that, even if the plaintiff can establish all the elements of his claim, as a matter of law the Commonwealth may not be liable. This opens up an area that is of concern to all Service personnel , both past and present. A procedure exists whereby this question could be determined at a preliminary stage without the additional costs of a full case, as is currently being undertaken.

I believe that one avenue for avoiding the problem that the Australian Legal Aid Office and the Attorney-General's Department have might well be to take to the court a case stated involving servicemen and related matters peculiarly pertinent to the case of the Australian nuclear veterans. If this were done, probably a limited amount of money would be involved and the Commonwealth would have some justifiable basis on which to predict the outcome as to costs and what they amount to. This course of action may be open to the Government if it feels unable at this stage to agree to pay all costs which may be awarded against the plaintiff in pursuance of a claim following on from a case stated. I believe that the current situation is that the Commonwealth is unreasonably forcing the plaintiff to incur substantial potential liability in the event that he is unsuccessful. The situation, of course, is that if the Commonwealth is unsuccessful it is in no real sense concerned about the cost.

A further point in relation to nuclear veterans which I wish to raise before I go on to the second case concerns the problem of the nuclear veterans who are currently dying of cancer. Currently there is no step under way to preserve their evidence. I think that if the Bird test case ultimately resolves that the Commonwealth is liable to the nuclear veterans, it will be necessary in each subsequent case to prove that the veteran concerned was exposed to radiation and that he suffered injury as a result of that exposure-evidence would have to be obtained as to the extent of the disability suffered by the veteran-so that these matters may be reflected in the quantum of damages which the court may wish to award. These matters are ones of direct evidence and not ones of legal principle.

If, in the pursuance of the case to ultimate success, and in other cases following, many of the dependants of those nuclear veterans are deprived of the ability to mount a successful action in the absence of evidence, a procedure currently exists-it has been used in associated cases-under the rules of the court for the taking of evidence on commission before trial from a crucial witness who is in danger of dying. I believe the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) ought to provide assistance at this time to all such veterans who wish to avail themselves of such a possibility.

The other case I wish to discuss is that of Fulton v. the Commonwealth of Australia. The problem in this case is slightly different. I believe the problem raises a very real possibility of a conflict of interest on the part of the Commonwealth. This action is currently funded by the legal aid section of the Attorney-General's Department. However, when the current operating solicitors for the plaintiff took over the case in May 1982 they were issued with specific instructions from the Attorney-General's Department that nothing further was to be done in the prosecution of the case without specific instructions from the Attorney-General's Department. Since that time there have been excessively lengthy delays in the Attorney-General's Department taking instructions and communicating them to the legal advisers of Fulton.

In looking at what is currently going on, one could very well draw the inference that the Attorney-General's Department is not now merely operating as a financier but is seeking to involve itself much more closely in the conduct of this action. Of course, the surrounding possibility is that the royal commission is inquiring into the very items that Fulton is raising. Fulton, of course, is raising them in relation to service in Vietnam. The Government may very well feel that because the royal commission is pursuing this matter there is no further need to provide funds to Fulton to pursue his case through the courts. However, I believe that under the law any plaintiff ought to have the right to pursue a claim regardless of what other methods are being taken within the community at large, even if they be of the standing of a royal commission. I do not believe that the royal commission looking into this area in any way impinges on the rights of that plaintiff to pursue his case.

However, a plaintiff cannot pursue his case without instructions from the Attorney-General. A plaintiff cannot pursue his case without legal aid. So currently such a person is in a really most invidious situation. Not only that, but of course, many other people are not able to apply for legal aid in relation to this item because it has been granted already by way of a test case to Fulton in his case against the Commonwealth. Not only is one plaintiff being severely disadvantaged before the law but also all other prospective plaintiffs in this area have been unable to proceed. In addition, the Commonwealth has failed to give an undertaking that it will not plead the relevant statute of limitations as a purely technical defence regarding this matter. I believe it is of serious concern that such an undertaking ought to be given on the part of the Commonwealth.

I believe the cases which I have mentioned are important. They are extremely important to the veteran community in Australia. They raise issues of law and issues of justice which are, I believe, crying out for resolution. The Government is to be commended for acting in relation to the Vietnam veterans in establishing a royal commission. However, I believe the current epidemiological studies, other statistical studies and the royal commission in no way ought to prevent an individual in the community from pursuing, through the courts, what he considers to be a justifiable claim. The fact that those people have been granted legal aid, I think, suggests that the Commonwealth at that time was willing to pursue such claims and to support such activity through the courts.

However, last year and this year the Commonwealth hedged around those proceedings with technical barriers of such an insurmountable kind as really to constitute giving with one hand and taking away with the other. I think that surely the time has come when the Commonwealth should allow both these cases to proceed. It is within the power of the Commonwealth, through its legal aid system, to allow such cases to proceed to their conclusion so that we can test before the courts the very real principles that are involved in the Bird case and in the Fulton case.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 1.18 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Acting Minister for Health, relates to a recent report by the Australian Consumers Association on the marketing of breast milk substitutes in Australia and, in particular, to the criticisms made in the report of the way in which manufacturers and distributors in the infant food industry have been promoting and selling their products. Is it correct, as alleged in this report, that the new Australian code introduced in May 1983 was drawn up by the Government in consultation with major manufacturers and that the Australian Consumers Association and other consumer groups were not included in the negotiations? Is it also correct that, because of significant loopholes and omissions in the code, all the major manufacturers have failed to comply with the international code of marketing adopted at the World Health Assembly in 1981? In the light of these alleged violations and the concern that I have previously expressed in this chamber about the foodstuffs produced for consumption by babies and young children, I ask the Minister: Firstly, why has the Government decided to base Australia's new code of marketing on voluntary regulation by industry rather than legislation? Secondly, will consideration be given by the Government to government regulation in the area of infant nutrition and to a revision of the Australian code in an effort to implement fully the guidelines of the World Health Assembly?
—I am afraid I do not have the details which Senator Missen requires in his question. However, I will see whether I can obtain an answer before the end of Question Time.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen recent reports suggesting that the Federal Government should decrease its personal income tax revenue by $5 billion per annum? Can the Minister say what effect this sort of policy would have on both Federal revenue raising and Federal policy planning, as well as on the revenues of the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a report in the Age of last Monday that the Leader of the Opposition had said that the next Liberal government would cut $5 billion off personal income tax. Senator Bolkus rightly draws attention to the consequences for the recipients of Commonwealth money, including the States, of a cut of that magnitude in personal income tax. If income tax were to be cut by $5 billion and other taxes were not to be increased, all defence spending would have to be eliminated. Total payments to the States would have to be cut by 42 per cent if no other changes were made to either income or expenditure. Alternatively, pensions, unemployment benefits and family allowances could be cut by 30 per cent. That would mean a reduction of $22 a week in income for single under 18 unemployed people. For married unemployed people it would mean a cut of $44 a week. Until the Leader of the Opposition offers a better explanation, we must assume that that is what he is proposing: To take $22 a week away from the single unemployed and $44 a week away from the married unemployed, to cut age pensions by 30 per cent, to eliminate defence spending or to cut total payments to the States by 42 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us consider the direct effects of the tax sharing arrangements on State revenue. There is a direct linkage, I remind the Senate, between the collections of personal income tax and the tax sharing grants made to the States. The States get 21 per cent of personal income tax. If the promise of the Leader of the Opposition were actually to be implemented, it follows that tax sharing payments to the States would automatically be cut by 12 per cent and they would be subject to 80 per cent of the other cuts I mentioned also. But if we concentrate on the tax sharing and go through State by State, the effects of that sort of cut in personal income tax would be that the State of Queensland, for example, would lose $217m--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. Clearly, this is just a debate. There is no semblance of an answer to the question. A purely hypothetical series of figures is being trotted out, relating to a single line that was supposedly uttered by the Leader of the Opposition. I ask you to ask the Minister to confine his remarks to matters that are within his departmental responsibility.

—I listened to the question asked by Senator Bolkus and I have listened to the answer by Senator Walsh. The answer so far is relevant to the question asked. Nonetheless, I ask the Minister to confine his answer as much as he possibly can.

—As always, Mr President, your ruling is correct. Mr Peacock promised that the next Liberal government would cut personal income tax by $5 billion. Senator Bolkus asked me, among other things, what would be the effects on payments to the States under the tax sharing arrangements of a cut of that magnitude in personal income tax. I have just told the Senate that the effect on the State of Queensland would be to reduce the payments under personal tax sharing by more than $200m. More than $200m would be cut from the payments to the State of Queensland if indeed the promise given last weekend by the Leader of the Opposition were ever to be implemented by a Liberal government. There is no way that cuts of that magnitude could be avoided unless the personal tax sharing arrangements were changed.
