For all the other States-I am quite willing to table or have incorporated in Hansard the relevant document if any member of the Opposition would like it-one could deduct in round figures 12 per cent from the payments they received this year if the Leader of the Opposition's promise were actually to be put into operation.

—Does the Attorney-General agree that the Commonwealth Government or Parliament has very wide authority under its constitutional powers, such as banking, overseas and interstate trade and post and telecommunications, to take action with regard to organised crime and in particular trafficking in drugs? Furthermore, is not Australia a party to an international convention relating to drug trafficking? In view of the Government's determination to utilise fully Commonwealth power in areas which it sees as being of national significance-I instance his answer to my question the other day-does the Attorney agree that the Commonwealth could play a much more active role in combating the involvement of organised crime in drug trafficking?

—I am indebted for the opportunity to note Senator Durack's conversion on the road to some kind of Damascus and that he does acknowledge that there are areas of both Commonwealth constitutional capacity to act and Commonwealth obligation to act in areas which perhaps hitherto have been thought to be beyond the traditional ambit of the Commonwealth's concern. Yes, there is indeed an excellent case for the Commonwealth to act in the area of drug related crime, as indeed there is in the area of organised crime generally. It is for that reason that the Government is considering very closely and very actively the establishment of an appropriate agency to deal with both those matters.

—Can the Minister for Resources and Energy say when the urgently needed country town water supply projects, to be funded under the community employment program in Queensland, will commence? I further ask the Minister: Is there some delay in finalising the list of projects? If so, what is the reason for such a delay in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is no, I am not able to say when the list of country towns in Queensland will be finalised. A delay has been caused by the Government of Queensland. It has stated, in a burst of pre- election politicking, that it will not consider until 18 November-assuming the present Government in Queensland is still in power at that time, which is an unlikely assumption-the joint selection by the Commonwealth Government and the State Government of water supply projects for country towns in Queensland which are to be funded under the Commonwealth-wide $20m special allowance in the community employment program. As a result of that action by the Queensland Government, jobs which are urgently needed are being denied to people and country towns which have a great need for improvement in both quality and quantity of their water supplies are having a superior water supply postponed.

ANSWER.PARA: In the meantime the Queensland Government has issued a general promise to provide $30m for local authorities throughout Queensland for roads and water supplies. This is a non-specific election-eve undertaking. But simultaneously, and far more importantly, of course, expenditure of Commonwealth money, which has already been appropriated in the Budget and which could be spent very quickly in Queensland in providing jobs and water supplies to country towns, is being delayed because of deliberate political action by the Queensland Government. It is refusing to consider, until at least 18 November, the selection of specific projects upon which that Commonwealth money would be spent .

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney- General aware of allegations by the New South Wales Minister for Corrective Services, Mr Jackson, that criminal acts have been committed by the unauthorised tapping of telephone conversations of people in that State 'including the Premier, Ministers and heads of departments' ? Will he tell us whether there is any basis to Mr Jackson's allegations or whether it is possible for him to investigate whether there is any such basis?

—I understand that when Mr Jackson first made noises to that effect to the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, the matter was investigated and the conclusion was reached that there was no foundation whatsoever for the allegations in question. However, I will, in the light of the question, double check and ensure there are no loose ends in that respect. It is certainly my understanding that there was no foundation whatsoever established for that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President, as a presiding officer of the Parliament. I know you are aware of the importance of the contribution made by women in this Parliament. You will also be aware that two women made an initial contribution in this chamber and in the other place. I refer to Dame Dorothy Tangney, who served in the Senate for 23 years, and Dame Enid Lyons, who served in the other place from 1943 to 1951. Portraits of both women are hanging in King's Hall with plaques stating their terms of service and the fact that they were the first to serve here, and both portraits, at present, hang behind pillars at the rear of King's Hall.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware that there are members of the Opposition who feel that that is a woman's place but I know that the Government does not feel that way. Will you, Mr President, as a presiding officer of this Parliament, ensure that the portraits of the two women who played such an important and historic role in this Parliament and in the nation are at long last allowed to see the light of day and be seen by the enlightened people who come to visit this Parliament?

—The long established practice has been, and still is, for the portraits of former Prime Ministers and Speakers of the House of Representatives to be displayed on the House of Representatives side of King's Hall and in the lobbies of the House of Representatives and for portraits of former Governors- General and Presidents of the Senate to be displayed on the Senate side of King' s Hall and in the Senate lobbies. Representations were made recently to the Speaker of the House of Representatives by Miss Fisher, the daughter of the former and late Prime Minister of Australia, suggesting that the portrait of Andrew Fisher be moved to a much more important place in King's Hall. Representations were put forward also to the Speaker by certain lady members of the House of Representatives suggesting that the Presiding Officers look at the present positioning of the portraits of Senator Dame Dorothy Tangney and Dame Enid Lyons. The Speaker and I have discussed the matter. The suggestion has been made that we look at the possibility of moving portraits around from time to time, probably on a sessional basis.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALLEGED CORRUPTION IN NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware that the New South Wales Commissioner of Police is being recalled to take charge of a further internal investigation into allegations of corruption in New South Wales? Does he believe that such serious matters can properly be dealt with by an internal investigation?

—Yes, I am aware that Mr Abbott, the New South Wales Commissioner, is being recalled to report further on the matters in issue of the last couple of days. In relation to the second question, my belief as to the adequacy or otherwise of investigative procedures in New South Wales is utterly irrelevant to the conduct of my portfolio as a Minister of the Commonwealth Government.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Health. My concern arises from the implementation of the policy announced in the May economic statement which aimed at reducing the price differentials between multi -branded or equivalent pharmaceutical products under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Is the Minister aware that one of the products adversely affected by this policy is imported insulin? This imported insulin is 99.9 per cent pure, far purer than locally-produced insulin, and is therefore of vital importance to those dependent on it. Is it the case that if the imported insulin were removed from the PBS its price would rise dramatically? If so, is the Minister aware that this measure can lead only to increased economic hardship for many thousands of Australians who suffer from diabetes? Will the Minister alleviate their anxiety by informing the Senate of Government's intentions in respect of imported insulin and its standing in the PBS?

—Yes, as Senator Richardson said, the policy to change the pharmaceutical benefits scheme where there are multi-listed and equivalent items on the list with great price differentials did, at first sight, seem to affect the insulins, in particular, the imported insulins, the Danish insulins, which are widely used in this country. Insulins issued by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories are considerably cheaper than the Danish insulins. The implementation of such a policy would result in a considerable increase for the Danish product. Several questions arise. The first one was alluded to by Senator Richardson. Are the Danish insulins, the imported insulins, and the CSL insulins , really equivalent substances? The second question asked is whether the difference in price between the Danish insulins and the CSL insulins is justified as the Danish insulins are considerably more expensive than the CSL insulins. Discussions have been going on between the Department of Health and the importers and manufacturers of Danish insulins. It is for that reason that Dr Blewett, before he left for overseas, announced that the Danish insulins were not being removed from the list of pharmaceutical benefits. Discussions are continuing concerning whether they are actually equivalent and just what arrangements can be arrived at on this matter. No decision will be taken on price relativity for the Danish insulins until the question of whether current users of these products can be satisfactorily transferred to other insulins is satisfied, so people using those insulins need have no concern at all at the moment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and follows the apparent inconsistency in the answers he has given to Senator Durack and Senator Lajovic today, where he said initially that he thought there was an excellent case for the Commonwealth to act with respect to organised crime, and, to Senator Lajovic, that in his opinion the State's investigations did not bear on his duties as Attorney-General. I preface my question by expressing the concern of the Opposition in this chamber about the seemingly endless succession of allegations concerning criminal activity in New South Wales, and our belief that unless appropriate Government action is taken by the State, or in the event of failure by the State, the Commonwealth, it may be necessary for the Senate to use whatever powers it has in this area. I ask the Attorney-General: Does he acknowledge that the Commonwealth has an interest in allegations which have been made about the New South Wales prison system and telephone tapping because of the presence in State gaols of offenders against Commonwealth laws and because of his own responsibilities concerning telephone interceptions? I ask: Will the Commonwealth Government urge the New South Wales Government to institute an immediate judicial inquiry into these allegations? I ask him: If the State will not so act, will he consider using the powers at his disposal-the powers he has described so widely in this place-to establish a Commonwealth royal commission into these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no inconsistency in the positions I have espoused today. The Commonwealth has a degree of legislative power in relation to organised crime should it choose to exercise it under the heads of power that were indicated by Senator Durack, whose question was put specifically, it will be recalled, in the context of narcotics law enforcement. It can be said in reply to that: First, the Commonwealth has to a considerable extent exercised its legislative power in respect to narcotics law enforcement; but secondly, it has not done so in the area of organised crime generally, although arguably it might have the capacity to do so at some stage in the future should it choose to exercise in an adventurous way its powers in relation to banking, insurance and other matters of those kinds. Given the way in which those powers have been exercised legislatively at the moment there is no capacity under any existing law for the Commonwealth to intrude into matters of purely State criminal law administration. It has not been suggested in any of the commentary I have heard today--
—Do not narcotics offenders offend against a Federal Act?

—Only insofar as imported narcotics are concerned, as Senator Chipp would be well aware as a former Minister for Customs. Entirely domestic or home grown offences are not a matter for Commonwealth jurisdiction at the moment. I do not understand any of the allegations that have been made in recent days to have concerned narcotics offenders in the sense in which Senator Durack would suggest that there is some capacity or obligation on the Commonwealth to do more than it has done, which is, as was stated by Mr Beazley in the context of a narcotics investigation, to find certain evidence coming to light with respect to the possible commission of an entirely different kind of crime as purely a matter for New South Wales administration. In this situation the Commonwealth's power and duty extends no further than to refer that matter back to the New South Wales authorities. So there is a consistent thread through what I have stated.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no exercise of the legislative power such as creates any obligation or power for the Commonwealth to act in an executive capacity at the moment in respect of the matters that have been raised. There may be in the future, should the Commonwealth choose to exercise that legislative power, a capacity to investigate further certain matters of this kind. But until that occurs-it may occur in the context of the establishment of a national crime authority or something of that kind-in light of the basic principles under which the Federal system operates and which the other side is constantly urging us to adopt, there is no reason, justification or rationale whatsoever for us to pursue the various courses that are pressed upon us by either Senator Durack or Senator Chaney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Attorney- General failed to address the specific questions which I asked him about whether the Commonwealth Government would urge the New South Wales Government to institute an immediate judicial inquiry into these allegations. He also failed to answer my question whether, if the State would not so act, he would consider using the powers at his disposal to establish a Commonwealth royal commission. There is nothing in his answer which suggests to me that there is a lack of power in his hands or in the hands of the Commonwealth Government to establish such a royal commission should the State refuse to do its duty.
—Centralism.

—Apart from the obvious irony to which Senator Walsh has just referred I think the answer is simply this: As to the urging of a certain course of conduct upon New South Wales, it was apparent from the answer given by Mr Beazley the other night that the New South Wales Government was indeed urged at the instance of the Prime Minister and the then Special Minister of State, Mr Young, to follow up the particular suggestive matters that had come to the notice of the Commonwealth law enforcement authorities. It is a matter for the New South Wales Government as to how it chooses to follow that up. My understanding is that the investigations have not been concluded in New South Wales and that indeed is the basis on which Mr Abbott has been asked to come back and produce a written report. Until such time as the investigations are concluded to the manifest satisfaction of the New South Wales Government it would be entirely inappropriate for the Commonwealth even to give consideration to the course of action which Senator Chaney has suggested.

—My question to the Minister representing the Treasurer refers to Commonwealth-State financial relations and in particular Commonwealth Government payments to Tasmania. I ask: Is the Commonwealth still receiving proposals from Tasmanian Government Ministers for the Commonwealth to fund new programs in Tasmania or to increase the funding of existing programs, or has the situation changed to be in line with Mr Gray's announcement last weekend referring to Federal-State financial arrangements that the begging bowl days must come to an end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was advised earlier this week of discussions held, I think, on 23 September between Commonwealth and State officials in Tasmania at which, I was advised, the Tasmanian officials on behalf of the Premier demanded that the Commonwealth provide funds for 8,800 years of employment at a per annum cost of, I think, $42,000, the total cost being something like $350m. In a more general sense I have noted in the Press comments of the Tasmanian Premier which were made at the Liberal Party conference over the weekend. He was reported in the Age as having said:

ANSWER.PARA: The party must acknowledge that the future lies with demassification, with the breaking down of Government into smaller and more responsive units closer to the local level . . .

He was also reported as saying that the Tasmanian Government had coped 'robustly with an artificially created centre of Federal government largely insulated from the harsh realities of the market economy which affects the rest of Australia'. Any coherent thoughts which are buried in that gobbledegook which I have just quoted would, I think, have to be interpreted as a support for what was called new federalism by the previous Prime Minister, prior to and for a short time after he became Prime Minister. The central thrust of it was that the governments which spent money were to be held equally responsible for raising the funds that they spent. That indeed is a philosophical proposition which would attract a good deal of support, I believe, from across political party boundaries. I observe, however, that it was never done by the previous Prime Minister. I do not believe that it would be done by Mr Gray or that he expected it to be taken seriously unless he had a sudden rush of blood to the head before the Liberal Party conference. If such a policy were to be applied and the States were to be held responsible for raising all the revenue that they spend, the effects for Tasmania of course would be quite catastrophic because the per capita payments estimates to Tasmania for this financial year are $1,855 as against an average for the Commonwealth of just under $1,200. In other words, $ 655 per capita is currently distributed from the other States to Tasmania.

If Mr Gray wishes seriously to pursue the implicit support for the principles of new federalism as robustly expounded by the former Prime Minister in 1975 and for a couple of months in 1976, I do not believe the Commonwealth would have any objection to his pursuing that policy. No formal notice has been served on the Commonwealth that the Tasmanian Premier is requesting that the present arrangements, which redistribute income on a per capita basis quite heavily in favour of Tasmania through the Commonwealth, be terminated. Indeed, all the actions of the Tasmanian Premier suggest that his real objective, as distinct from the rhetoric which gushes from his mouth at Liberal Party conferences, is in the opposite direction.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General a question similar to others he has been asked today. I sympathise with the legal difficulties he experiences in appointing a Federal royal commission to inquire into the activities of a State. I point out that if police and law enforcement authorities prosecute and imprison people who have been convicted of Federal offences and allegations of corruption are levelled against either the police or the people who are responsible for imprisonment, surely it does come within Federal jurisdiction. Thus, I ask the Attorney a question about the fresh allegations of corruption in New South Wales. In doing so, I make it absolutely clear that the Democrats support the thrust of Senator Chaney's question, particularly that part which referred to possible action by the Senate. Four weeks ago-this can be found on page 514 of the Hansard of 8 September-I pointed out that several strange happenings concerning Mr Abraham Saffron and others which had occurred in New South Wales had been exposed by the National Times. I then asked the Attorney- General whether he was prepared to establish a royal commission into police and political corruption in Australia. I now ask the Attorney-General again whether he is prepared to establish such an inquiry, not just into the matters of immediate concern but also into allegations of corruption against previous State administrations in New South Wales, if a suitable State judicial inquiry is not set up.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite apart from questions of political comity in the Federal system-I am not talking about it in the sense of partisan comity-and the whole question of Federal-State relations and the proper relationship of the Federal Government to the States, which is a vexed and difficult one, there are very real legal difficulties about the course Senator Chipp has suggested. It may well be that the Commonwealth has executive power to inquire into anything it chooses in the sense of conducting an inquiry which generates suggestions or recommendations as to appropriate courses of action. However, the legal difficulty which arises for the Commonwealth in this area is if it chooses to exercise any coercive or compulsive powers in relation to that inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure Senator Chipp would appreciate that on matters as sensitive as this we are unlikely to generate very much evidence of a hard or useful kind except by the exercise of coercive or compulsive powers. It may be, as Senator Durack was suggesting earlier, that by a patchwork quilt of reliance upon the banking, insurance and corporation powers and matters of that kind one could, one way or another, stitch together the wherewithal for some inquiry of this kind to involve itself in at least a limited area of inquiry. After careful consideration of the earlier matter raised by Senator Chipp and, indeed, the whole question of how best to deal with organised crime and official corruption in this country, I have come to the personal view, the Government has come to the view, and one hopes that in due course the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party will come to the view, that the best way of approaching this is through the establishment of a proper national investigative authority, a national crime authority, which depends for its successful operation not on the coercive exercise of such a patchwork quilt of Commonwealth powers as could be put together but rather on the co-operative--

TALK.START.PARA: —You sold that down the river, in this chamber.

—That is not quite true. Senator Chaney ought not to believe anything he reads in the newspapers. He ought to take a leaf out of the book of Senator Withers in that respect. I think he will find in due course that is not the case. I have taken the view and, as I indicated, the Government has taken the view-it is perfectly evident from the speeches of the Prime Minister and the policy stated by the Party that this is at least the Government's view- that the best way to approach these questions is through the establishment of a properly constructed investigative body, an intelligence gathering body, call it a crimes authority or a crimes commission if you like, which will operate on a co-operative basis with the States. Precisely how we put such a body together in terms of its composition, functions, powers and, overwhelmingly important, the safeguards on the exercise of those powers, is a matter of obvious policy difficulty. It has exercised a great many minds in this country for quite a period, as was evident in the conference in this chamber in July. It will no doubt go on causing a considerable degree of controversy for a good deal of distance into the future.
—It always founders on the question of precious States' rights.

—I believe that that, in short, is the way forward in this area. I readily acknowledge that there is a case for systematic investigation and monitoring of organised crime and official corruption at whatever level, but I believe, and I believe the Government believes, that the best way forward is the way I have suggested.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It concerns the problems many self-help groups for the adult unemployed in South Australia are having in obtaining the agreement of Commonwealth Employment Service managers to pin up notices regarding their activities in CES offices. Can the Minister explain why the CES is prevented from advertising voluntary and welfare type activities in its offices? Does the Minister agree that groups such as the self-help programs for the adult unemployed are worthy of more sympathetic treatment by the CES? Will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, look into the situation and, if necessary, consider changing the Commonwealth Employment Service Act to overcome the difficulties currently being experienced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Foreman was kind enough to give me advance notice of this question. I simply state that requests similar to that implicit in Senator Foreman's question have been made on a number of occasions in the past. In fact, a review was conducted into this matter in December 1982 by the previous Government. The present policy on the display of materials in CES offices restricts display to information which is government produced or sponsored, and to information regarding CES services, facilities and things of that kind, such as career guidance, job training, unemployment benefits, the community youth support scheme and so on. When the policy was examined in December 1982 the review identified a number of difficulties with the proposal to lift these restrictions on information approved for display.

ANSWER.PARA: The review was told of a considerable list of difficulties which would make it impossible to lift the restrictions. It referred to such difficulties as limited display space on boards and the like in CES offices, the fear that there would be substantially more requests for display space and the list goes on and on. It all seems pretty bureaucratic to me, and I must say that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is of the same mind. He has directed his Department to have a fresh investigation into the possibility of relaxing these guidelines. That investigation is currently under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the Hawke Government's intention to extend parliamentary superannuation benefits to de facto spouses of members of parliament, does the Government intend that the declaration of pecuniary interests by Ministers and members of this Parliament which applies to their families should similarly be extended to include de facto spouses?

—It was stated explicitly in the announcement in relation to the pecuniary interests of Ministers and the hoped-for future declarations of statements of pecuniary interests of members of parliament that Ministers and members would be requested to adjust their statements of pecuniary interests from time to time as circumstances arose. The legislation to which Senator Reid refers is a circumstance which may require adjustment in some cases. I am sure that Ministers will attend to that and I hope that members of parliament will do so in due course.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WOMEN: SENIOR POSITIONS IN PUBLIC SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs provide figures on the representation of women in senior positions in his Department, as against their representation amongst all departmental employees? Does he agree that women's level of representation in these senior positions is far from satisfactory? What steps has he taken to attempt to redress the inequality?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of women occupying positions in the Public Service has occupied some attention on the part of the Government. We are committed to a principle of establishing a more equitable degree of representation. As one who sat in on Estimates committees just recently, in the autumn session as well as the spring session, I was struck by the fact that there were very few women occupying senior positions, or even middle management positions, in the various departments with which I was associated on Estimates Committee F-the Department of Administrative Services, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Territories and Local Government, the Department of Transport, and the Department of Aviation. So the Government has expressed a view that there should be some dramatic improvement in the level of representation of women in the senior positions in the Public Service.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that about 57 per cent of those working in the Department of Veterans' Affairs are women, yet in regard to senior positions, only 17 per cent are at or above Class 9 level, which represents about one in six. Obviously great attention needs to be paid to this matter in reaching a much more equitable distribution of women in senior positions in the Public Service. As for my own Department, I have attended two management seminars this year. There has been an appreciable increase in the presence of women at such seminars. As some very senior positions in my Department will be falling vacant very shortly, it is certainly my intention, after having discussed the matter with the Secretary to my Department, to see that some emphasis in selection is made that will improve the representation of women in senior positions in my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. When is it expected that the Queensland Government will be paid the shortfall amount of $21.2m due to it as a result of the Medicare funding arrangements? The Queensland Government requested $36m and to date only $15m has been allocated in the Budget by the Federal Government. Why is Queensland not being provided with compensation equal to that for the other States? Is it because Queensland has maintained a free hospital system? Can the Minister assure the people of Queensland that they will receive the rightful amount due to them, $36m, and not only the $15m allocated in the Budget, which would mean that Queensland was indeed being shortchanged?

—Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question is based on a premise which is hers-that the claim by the Premier of Queensland and his colleagues for $36m is a fair and correct one. That is a claim which would not be accepted by many people who look at the situation rationally. There have been negotiations between the Government of Queensland and the Commonwealth Government about the amount of money which should be paid to Queensland as a result of the introduction of Medicare. I always find it interesting that someone like Senator Bjelke-Petersen can sit over there and praise the free hospital service in Queensland when all her colleagues around her condemn such an introduction as contributing to overservicing, et cetera. However, I suppose that she can work that out with her colleagues. As I do not keep in my head the exact details of the negotiations between the Australian Government and the Queensland Government , I shall get for Senator Bjelke-Petersen the explanation, and which I am sure she has had many times, in any case, which sets out the basis for the compensation for Queensland concerning Medicare and free hospitals. I shall provide it for her and for the Senate for, I think, the third, fourth or fifth time.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I have received a number of queries about the current position of college-based education for nurses. The people asking about this are as concerned as I am that such education for nurses, currently at the end of a pilot study stage, be continued and extended. What is the current position? What steps will be taken to implement this policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position on nurse education is that we accept the arguments that it ought to be transferred to colleges. We accept those arguments not only because they have been advocated so persuasively by the various organisations representing nurses but also because we share with them the hope that changing and upgrading the means of training nurses will lead to greater recognition of the contribution that nurses make to hospital teams and will lead to their participation on a more equal footing with doctors in those teams. So we are in accord with the objective of the Royal Australian Nursing Federation to upgrade nurse education by transferring it to colleges.

ANSWER.PARA: What I have done in order to realise this commitment is to ask the Tertiary Education Commission to report to me on options for implementing the report of the Sax Committee of Officials on Medical Manpower Supply-the Sax Committee was the committee which made the recommendations about transferring nurse education to colleges-and to bring down that report in time for planning for the next triennium in tertiary education; that is, the triennium beginning 1985. It is not the case, as some people seem to have assumed, that I have asked the Tertiary Education Commission to reopen the question of the training of nurses; it is, rather, to report on options for implementation of the Sax Committee's recommendations. I am consulting various nurses organisations throughout Australia. I have a couple of meetings with different organisations scheduled within the next month. I look forward to their participation and co-operation in developing the means by which we can transfer nurse education to the colleges, as they wish.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In recent answers to Senator Chipp and Senator Mason, the Minister has repeatedly stated that:

QUESTION.PARA: A nuclear war is in fact unlikely-
And that:
Global nuclear war is assessed as remote.

Can the Minister explain on what basis the Government makes this assessment? Is the Minister aware that the prestigious Bulletin of Atomic Scientists' Bulletin Clock, a symbol of the threat of the nuclear doomsday hovering over mankind, now stands at four minutes to midnight, the closest it has been since 1945?

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question, all my recent references to the remoteness of global nuclear war stress that the basis for this judgment by the Government rested largely on the constraints imposed on both super-powers by mutual deterrence. Both super-powers manifestly have no illusions whatever about the catastrophic consequences of nuclear conflict for their own countries and the rest of the world. The Government's assessment in this respect followed careful study of all available information, including the views of its senior advisers. The assessment presumes the continuing durability of nuclear deterrence consequent upon broad nuclear parity and the fear of retaliatory devastation and the maintenance and development of consultative mechanisms between the super-powers. As to the second part of the question, yes, I am aware, or have become aware--
—How can you have consultation with only three minutes warning?

—If Senator Chipp takes the view that the kind of disarmament negotiations with which I am presently proceeding are not worth pursuing for that reason, he is entitled to that view, but it is not one that will be shared, I believe, by other honourable senators. I am aware that the front cover of the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists displays a clock which is the Bulletin's symbol of the threat of nuclear doomsday hovering over mankind. It has become a very familiar symbol of this concern, which is shared, obviously, by everyone around the world. The hands are currently shown at four minutes to midnight, where they have remained since they were last moved 2 1/2 years ago, in January 1981. I note, however, that when the position was reassessed in January 1982 the Bulletin's editor noted the development then of several positive trends which could, he said, ultimately provide good reasons for moving the hands further away from midnight and he urged that those trends be encouraged. All I can say is that this is precisely the Government's view. The Government's disarmament policies, including as they do the commitment to the process of international negotiations and consultations on this subject, are designed to further that objective and reduce the risks of nuclear war.

—Is the Acting Minister for Health aware that the present medical insurance arrangements discriminate against patients receiving private psychiatric treatment by placing limits on reimbursement of fees? Will such patients continue to be discriminated against under Medicare and, in particular, will the provision limiting the cost to the patient for prolonged treatment apply equally to all patients, whatever the nature of their illness?

—Yes, I am aware of the difficulty facing those patients receiving private psychiatric treatment under the existing health insurance programs. I am unsure of the details of what changes will be made on the introduction of Medicare, particularly in the private health area. I will get the answer for Senator Zakharov as soon as I can.

—Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs prepared to do anything for the more than 300 Victorian country students of tertiary institutions whose hostels are being closed by the Cain Labor Government?

—This matter has been brought to my attention by one of my parliamentary colleagues, but as yet I have not seen any representations from Mr Fordham, the Victorian Minister for Education, to this effect. It may well be that he has written to me but, as the Senate will be aware, there has been a mail strike in Canberra and it could well be that--
—It has nothing to do with the mail strike.
—I am very surprised at these expressions of--
—Just answer the question.

—I am answering the question. I have not yet seen any representations from Mr Fordham on this matter, although I do not wish to imply by that that he has not attempted to make any. Until I do, I cannot really comment on what arrangements he has in mind for the continuation of these hostels. I point out to the honourable senator that the matter of accommodation for tertiary students is currently being reviewed by the Tertiary Education Commission. Many needs and many serious problems exist with regard to the provision of low cost accommodation for tertiary students.
—In which year will that review be completed?

—I think I might answer that interjection by Senator Chaney, who is interested in the year in which the review will be completed. It will be completed in this year and it will certainly be completed in time for me to make appropriate recommendations in my Budget submissions for next year. The Federal Government, having as it does a strategy of increasing participation in higher education-in particular increasing participation by previously disadvantaged groups-is very aware of the need to have available low cost accommodation for tertiary students. So naturally we are most concerned to hear that some such accommodation is in jeopardy. I will certainly be giving the matter close attention.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Arising out of what the Minister has said, actually in answer to the interjection by Senator Chaney, does that mean that there will certainly be nothing done for these students during 1984 but that she will be bringing down something for them in the 1984 Budget, possibly to apply in 1985?
—No, it does not mean that. It means that I will address the problem of these particular hostels when it is presented to me in detail.

—Is the Acting Minister for Health aware that if Mr Peacock's plan to dismantle Medicare is implemented when the Liberals next get into office , Australia will have had eight major changes to its health system in 30 years? As the Liberal Party of Australia will not be in a position to announce its alternative health scheme until next April, will the Minister allow officers of his Department to be available to assist the Opposition in the formulation of its policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware that Mr Peacock has announced that his government -if there ever is a Peacock government, and one can hardly imagine that there will be after statements like that-will dismantle the Medicare arrangements which have been brought in by the present Government. I suppose, if one can go on the record of the previous Government, that is unlikely to happen, as Mr Fraser made it a prominent part of his election campaign in 1975 that 'we will retain Medibank' and then proceeded, as Senator Ray says, to introduce five different health schemes between 1975 until his political demise this year. The present Opposition has announced that it will have its new health scheme ready by next April. If that is so, it will be the first health policy that it has had in opposition. One can imagine the agony of someone like former Prime Minister Gorton who in 1969, realising the disastrous situation of the Australian health insurance scheme, instigated an inquiry and then attempted to bring in changes of the type that were eventually brought in under Medibank. One can imagine his agony, watching the party that he once led spend its last 10 years or more in government thrashing around trying to develop a policy and then, having come into opposition, announcing that its only policy was to dismantle the existing policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I have represented the health portfolio for the Australian Labor Party in this place since 1976. I have been through endless debates. I have heard Senator Baume and others in this place talk about introducing health insurance on the basis of community ratings; introducing levies, and saying that levies are bad things and getting rid of them; regulating the health insurance funds and then wanting to deregulate the health insurance funds. I suppose the best thing we could do would be to get officers of the Department of Health to help the Opposition in formulating its policy. But I doubt whether it will want them. It did not take any notice of them in the years it was in government, from 1975 to 1983; I do not see why it should take any notice of them now, nor do I see why the people of this country should take any notice of any utterances of Mr Peacock or anyone else on the Opposition side on matters of health policy or health insurance policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is in three parts, is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Firstly, in view of the hostility poured on the airline pilots by the Government while the pilots were on strike, why is none being levelled against the employees of Australia Post, whose actions are just as selfish but far more damaging and inconvenient to business and family alike? Secondly, what support will the Government provide to those pilots who were endeavouring to maintain the service for which they were engaged by putting the survival of their employer and the requirements of their customers first, if action from any source is taken against them? Finally, when will the Government take the actions necessary to get the mail delivered?

—I do not know whether it is implicit in Senator Archer's question that he thinks governments should go about picking winners and losers in industrial disputes, and compensate the losers and chastise the winners or something of that kind.
—You do in uranium mines. You may as well in industrial disputes.
—Senator Chaney has drawn the brilliant analogy with uranium mining, which I thought might have eluded even him as a graphic example of an analogy to the industrial relations area.
—You pick winners and losers there without any qualms at all.
—And at the races-one picks winners and losers at the races.
—Some of your people pick very big winners, apparently.

—We are talking about industrial relations. I understand that steps have been taken by the Minister for Communications in relation to the postal dispute. It is anticipated that, as a result of those steps, that matter will be resolved very quickly. As to whether we should help air pilots-I take it the honourable senator means pilots from East-West Airlines and the like-I do not believe there is any need to do that; I believe they can look after themselves. But certainly, as I indicated in answer to a question yesterday, there are very serious differences of opinion amongst the air pilots about the course of action that has been advocated by their executive. I believe that those differences of opinion will grow as air pilots generally become aware of the long series of negotiations which the Government has had with them regarding this matter and the generally totally anti-social position which they have adopted in relation to this dispute.

—I address my question to the Acting Minister for Health. Is the Minister able to report on Government plans to publicise the possible harmful effects of the drug diethylstilboestrol, a synthetic oestrogen widely prescribed to pregnant women in Australia from 1941 to 1971 to prevent miscarriage? In view of the concern about the long term effects of DES on the daughters of women prescribed this drug, can the Minister give an assurance that the Federal Government will monitor this situation and give the States assistance in bringing this potentially serious health matter to public attention?

—Yes, I am aware of the potential long term effects of DES on the daughters of women who used that drug in the 1940s and 1950s and I am aware that the unusual carcinoma which can develop in such people is very distressing and is a very difficult one to treat. I well remember a former senator, Senator Melzer, asking many questions on this subject. From memory, I understand that the Department of Health was monitoring the matter but I cannot say for certain that it is doing so now. I will find out the details from the Department of Health and get the answers that Senator Reynolds requires. Certainly, on a personal basis, I believe that such monitoring is essential in order for the early detection of the disease where possible and its adequate treatment when detected.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the possibility of the Australian Government initiating prisoner exchange schemes with Thailand and other such countries where Australian prisoners, both male and female, are being held for long sentences on mainly drug related convictions. Has the Government considered conducting bilateral and multilateral discussions with other countries to establish voluntary repatriation of Australian prisoners abroad? If it has, what action has been taken? Further, has the Government consulted with the State governments on the possibility of transferring prisoners out of Australian prisons to their home countries and providing accommodation in State prisons for Australians returned from overseas? Finally, does the Minister have any additional information on the international prisoner transfer scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be that I can supply a more detailed answer in writing to Senator Kilgariff and I certainly undertake to do so, but broadly the position is this: The question of international prisoner transfers is something of a long-standing chestnut. The matter is before the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, where, as no doubt Senator Durack will recall, it has been residing for some considerable time. The difficulty so far as the Commonwealth is concerned in engaging in bilateral or multilateral international negotiations is that we do not ourselves have control over the prison system within Australia . That is a matter for State governments. The States are constitutionally obliged to house Commonwealth prisoners but the Commonwealth itself has no gaols to which it could readily resort to accommodate prisoners who are the subject of transfers to Australia under any international scheme. Therein lies a considerable problem which can be resolved only by consultation and, hopefully, longer term agreement with the States. Those consultations have been taking place. However, the momentum is not as rapid as I would have wished and I have been endeavouring to stimulate it.

ANSWER.PARA: Against that background I will endeavour to prepare a progress report, as it were, for the honourable senator and let him know precisely where things are. I am wholly sympathetic to the aspirations which lie behind his question but, translating that into reality, particularly again in the situation where there is an imbalance between Australian prisoners housed abroad and overseas prisoners in Australia with consequent potential financial disadvantage involved , the difficulties cannot be underestimated of bringing about anything sensible in the short to medium term in that respect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to an answer I gave to a question asked by Senator Missen earlier in Question Time concerning the code of standard for the production of breast milk substitutes in Australia. I am informed by the Department of Health that the code referred to is a code of practice for industry to adhere to as part of overall action towards the implementation of the World Health Organisation International Code for Marketing Breast Milk Substitutes. The Australian Industry Code of Practice requires all infant breast milk substitutes to meet at least the standard of the Codex Alimentarious which is recognised as a world standard for quite a range of food products.

QUESTION.PARA: The Department of Health chaired a working party, consisting of representatives of infant formula manufacturers, the Australian Dairy Corporation and the Department of Primary Industry, which developed the code of practice accepted in June 1983. That obviously means there was no consumer representation on that working party. In view of the fact that the Australian standard is at the level of at least one international standard, consumers have some protection, but in addition the National Health and Medical Research Council is developing a food standard which will require infant formulas to have a higher nutritional content than that provided in the current standard. I will seek the further details asked for by Senator Missen and get the replies to him as soon as possible.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report 1982
Debate resumed from 4 October 1983, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the report of the Film Censorship Board was tabled I moved that the Senate take note of the paper to enable some consideration and debate of it if honourable senators were minded to do so. There was no opportunity to consider the report before it was tabled. In view of the widespread interest in this matter I thought it desirable that the Senate have such an opportunity. We have now had the opportunity of reading the report and it is an interesting and valuable document. I think it is worth noting that only comparatively recently has the Parliament had the opportunity of receiving a report on the activities of the Film Censorship Board. The present Chief Censor is to be congratulated on the pioneering work that she has done in making this report available. As I said, the making available to the Parliament of such a report was instituted only recently, I think in the last two or three years but certainly since the appointment of the present Chief Censor. It contains quite a lot of interesting statistics as to the reasons for the various classifications that the Board gives to films.

SPEECH.PARA: The report reveals the valuable work that the Board does and the success it has had in broadly giving effect to community standards in this very sensitive area. It is worth noting that there have been considerably fewer complaints about the classification of films during 1982-the period covered by the report-than in previous years. I think the combination of the regard that the Board has for community standards and the availability of appeal to the Films Board of Review has worked very well.

One of the problems that the Board is faced with and which is revealed in the report is the great increase in its work as a result of technological developments and in particular videotapes. One of the matters that has been of concern is the explosion in the use of videotapes and how best to deal with them because they do not come within the ordinary joint Federal-State classification of film legislation. The Board is obliged to register imported videotapes.

I am pleased it was agreed at the recent meeting of Federal and State Ministers responsible for censorship that their ought to be a joint Federal-State scheme in relation to videotapes and that the Film Censorship Board should be given the responsibility of classifying such tapes broadly in accordance with the same classification system that is adopted for cinema films but with an additional X category. Certainly the objective is still to retain control over highly objectionable matter such as child pornography, drug abuse, extreme violence and cruelty, terrorism and so on. I think that the recent decision by the Ministers is a sound one. I am very pleased that use will continue to be made of the very high qualifications and experience of members of the Films Board of Review to give effect to this decision. I hope that the decision will be brought into operation without undue delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up the same theme that was followed by Senator Durack. I commend the work that the Film Censorship Board has done on the censorship and classification of films. However , as Senator Durack said, censorship and classification currently applies only to films and videotapes intended for public viewing. Videotapes for private sale and hire are not classified. As a result, people may hire tapes which they may then find offensive. The Film Censorship Board's views on videotape censorship and classification were expressed at the convention of the Motion Picture Exhibitors' Association of Queensland last year by Ms Janet Strickland, the Chief Censor of the Board. Ms Strickland said at that time that all videotapes for sale and hire should be registered and classified by the Board. She also said that a comprehensive classification system for videos should have an X rating to include some currently prohibited material. She said that in her eyes this classification would meet public demand for consumer advice, provide an avenue of appeal for importers and distributors, enable consumers to make their own decisions on what they see and avoid unintentional exposure to offensive material. It would also provide more effective control over matters such as child pornography, drug abuse, acts of extreme violence, terrorism and all those matters that are offensive to many people in Australia, particularly children and youth to whom these tapes are readily available. I would strongly commend the Board's views on videotape classification and censorship. I urge the Federal and State governments to adopt such a system for the sale and hire of videotapes .

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that many people in Australia are concerned that children are able to hire unsuitable tapes very easily from local video hire shops. I do not think we should classify all video hire shops as being in the category of making such videos readily available. However, of course, some shops will sell and hire any type of tape for gain. As I indicated, many people have shown extreme concern in regard to this matter. The Catholic Womens League convention was held in Darwin some three or four months ago. Some 400 delegates representing thousands of women throughout Australia discussed international and national matters at the gathering. One of the matters that they discussed, of course, was the sale and hire of videotapes. They passed a motion requesting that authority take action in regard to this problem. With this in mind, I would ask the Government to review the censorship legislation relating to videotapes and to pick up the expressed view of the Chief Censor of the Film Censorship Board, Ms Strickland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate very briefly. The general matters about which I wish to address my remarks concern not only the principles of film censorship but also the question of imports and prohibited imports. A good deal of concern has been expressed, as indicated by Senator Kilgariff, about the videotape issue. Indeed, concern has been expressed about the real meaning of what the Film Censorship Board describes on page 3 of its report as its understanding of its functions within the framework of its statutory responsibilities. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Board aims at reflecting the plurality of community standards which exist in Australia.
With this in mind I would like to refer to the Board's comments relating to videotapes set out on pages 15 to 16 of the report. The Board states:

Although certain short-term procedural decisions relating to the treatment of videotapes for sale/hire were taken in 1982 . . . broader questions relating to the appropriate controls for this material remained unresolved. The Board detailed certain views. It then went on to say:

The Film Censorship Board's view, embodied in an address delivered by the Chief Censor to the Convention of the Motion Picture Exhibitors' Association of Queensland held in Surfers Paradise in July 1982, is that-
That view is then listed. The second point made by the Board in this context included the following statement:

. . . further implement the Federal Government's philosophy that adults have the right to make their own decisions regarding the material they read, hear or see, but that people generally should be protected from exposure to material that may be offensive-or, in the case of children, harmful-to them-
The Board also said:
. . . provide more effective control over material that depicts such matters as, for example, child pornography, bestiality, drug abuse, and acts of extreme violence, cruelty or terrorism.

I should have thought that, bringing all those things together, the latter types of video films particularly would have had no place at all in Australia or anywhere else for that matter. I wonder whether bestiality and child pornography are really appropriate classifications or whether I have misunderstood what the Board was aiming at when it talked about its aim of reflecting the plurality of community standards which exist in Australia. I trust that I have misinterpreted that comment, but I wonder whether I have. I would be very concerned if my interpretation of what the Board is saying is correct. I have not had the opportunity of discussing the matter with either the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) or members of the Film Censorship Board. Therefore, I would suggest at this stage that that is a possible interpretation of anybody reading the document. I think that every member of the Senate and every person in Australia would consider that videos or even films relating to child pornography , bestiality, drug abuse and acts of extreme violence, cruelty or terrorism have no place in Australia. The Board made a comment on page 15 of the report concerning videotapes. The report states:
Videotapes intended for sale/hire would be allowed entry into Australia under amended Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.
The Board spoke of a view which is held, but it did not say who holds that view. Perhaps for completeness one should mention this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—I rise to join briefly in this debate and support the remarks that have already been made. I understand that, regarding the censorship of video films, there is now agreement between the States and the Commonwealth that the matter needs to be looked at. It is not enough to have censorship of video films that are for public exhibition. This was brought to my attention some weeks ago when a mother, who is a friend of mine, telephoned me and said that she had hired a video recorder for the weekend because the family wanted to see a film it had missed. They did that, and her two lads asked whether they could hire some more films. She said that that was all right and the boys got a couple more films. They used their discretion, as young male juveniles will, and the result horrified their parents. This lady telephoned me the next morning and complained about the incident. That really brought to my attention the fact that there is no censorship of such films. I can only add to the remarks-

—That is the point I was about to make. These are allowed in under the existing Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations when those regulations prohibited them. Have a word with some of the Customs officers. It is not being properly policed.

—I thank Senator Harradine. I am sure we are all on the one wave length. The idea is that there ought not be a classification for some of these films, that they just be banned entirely and not allowed into the public arena at all. I add those brief remarks in support all that has been said. I hope something can be done about it very shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say quickly, in response to at least some of the remarks that have been made on the report of the Film Censorship Board, that it deals only with the calendar year 1982. Since the change of government a number of matters referred to in the report have been addressed by the present Government. There are many reforms-
—They were well under consideration before.

—Many things were under consideration by the previous Government and very little visible achievement was actually recorded. I think the honourable senator will find that the situation is changing rather rapidly in that respect, as in many others. I think it is unfortunate that the speakers, at least the ones I have heard, who have contributed to this debate, with the possible exception of Senator Collard, have not referred to the tabling statement that was meant to be circulated simultaneously with the report that answers, I think, some of the questions that have arisen in the debate and which were addressed specifically to indicate to honourable senators what progress had taken place on matters that were the subject of comment by the Chairman of the Film Censorship Board.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of at least two of those matters, let me simply say this: The videotape question has been the subject of extended discussion, as Senator Durack will no doubt recall, over a long period by the Ministers responsible for censorship. In July this year hard agreement was actually reached on what was going to happen about this. Agreement was reached on a new uniform system of videotape censorship classifications and accompanying point of sale controls to ensure that there was some sensible control over what is a burgeoning market. There is a lack of any kind of sensible control over it at the moment which is causing quite reasonable and understandable concern in many sections of the community.

The elements in that proposed new uniform system of classification can be summarised in six points. Firstly imported videotapes for home use are to be no longer subject to compulsory registration by the Film Censorship Board. Secondly , videotapes for sale or hire are to be classified by the Film Censorship Board at the request of the importer, the distributor or the retailer. Thirdly, the classification standards to be applied for videotapes are to be the same as for cinemas, namely, G, NRC-although possibly the PG rating will substitute for that in due course-M and R, with a further category, X, to be added for stronger material which would be refused cinema showing. Only child pornography, terrorism and perhaps some other classes of similarly very extreme material would be refused classification altogether. Fourthly, the States and the Australian Capital Territory, or the Commonwealth Parliament by means of an ordinance, are to pass laws imposing appropriate point of sale restrictions for R and X classified material, in particular to ensure that there is no sale of such material to minors. Fifthly, the existence of a classification is to be a complete defence for retailers against prosecution under State obscenity laws. That is, of course, the encouragement to retailers and distributors to get into the classification system. Sixthly, classification recommendations by the Film Censorship Board are to be subject to review by the Commonwealth Films Board of Review.

That system is now being put into legislative form, as I understand it, in every jurisdiction in Australia. So far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned, revisions are proceeding, and I hope will be in place by the end of this year, to the Australian Capital Territory Objectionable Publications Ordinance which will clarify and rationalise the censorship law generally as well as specifically in relation to videotapes. We are looking forward to appropriate complementary State legislation and the whole administrative system being in place by early next year. This matter has been the subject of some favourable comment, I believe, editorially and elsewhere in the media, including by people in the industry who were worried about the way in which it was getting under control.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just made a favourable comment on it.

—Bless you, Senator Durack. I am sorry that I missed it because it would be a unique phenomenon in this chamber. It is one that I wish I had been here to observe. That matter is under way. DEBATE.TITLE: AGE PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT INCOME SYSTEMS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate notes- (a) the widespread disquiet in the community amongst those who are nearing the age of retirement and present age-pension recipients; and
(b) that Ministers in the Hawke Government have a confusion of views on vital questions affecting pre-retirees and age-pensioners such as:
(i) whether to replace income-testing by means-testing of age pensions,
(ii) the harsher application of income-testing to age pensions, and
(iii) the taxation of superannuation payments; and
calls on the Government to immediately state its policy on these matters.
(2) That the Senate- (a) recognises the proposed fundamental changes that the Government is making to Australia's retirement income systems;
(b) acknowledges that the Government has received a number of reports on these proposed changes from a number of committees, including:
(i) the joint ACTU/CAI/Government Official Working Group on the proposed superannuation changes, and
(ii) a working party of public servants from the Departments of Treasury, Finance, Social Security, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Veterans' Affairs;
(c) is of the opinion that there should be the widest possible informed debate on the Government's proposed changes; and
(d) calls on the Government to release and make public all reports it has received relating to its retirement income policy changes.

Since coming to office the Government has made three major changes in the area of retirement incomes. Firstly, there was the introduction of the income test for pensioners over 70 years of age; secondly, there were changes to arrangements for the taxation of lump sum superannuation payments; and, thirdly, there was the announcement of a proposed assets test which will come into effect next year. These changes have all been characterised by an ad hoc, piecemeal and ill-thought out approach. Their introduction has been by way of a two-bite process-firstly, in the May mini-Budget which included the superannuation changes and the over-70s income test; and, secondly, in the August Budget, which included the proposed assets test. Clearly, this was not part of any comprehensive policy but was, in fact, two different policies. The first two changes were justified on the grounds of stopping double-dipping. Yet people engaging in that practice under the old superannuation pension rules would be caught out by an assets test. The assets test introduced in the August Budget supersedes those earlier measures. Obviously this amounts to an overall grab for taxes.

If the Government had a comprehensive policy, why were the changes introduced separately? That is a simple question. We look to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) to answer it. If the Government had intended an assets test all along, why did it introduce in May an income test for over-70s pensioners? An assets test clearly overrides such an income test. The income test was intended to operate for one year before the assets test was effected. Obviously this is a costly waste of money. In fact, during the hearing of Estimates Committee B it was revealed that the cost of making the changes which were announced in May amounted to more than $3m. Two hundred and twenty staff had to be hired to process pensioners' questionnaires and 55 permanent staff will be required to administer the income test. All that would have been completely unnecessary had an assets test been intended and put in place in May. If an assets test was intended, I ask why the Minister for Veterans' Affairs ( Senator Gietzelt) stated at the Victorian conference of the Returned Services League:

Before I explain to you some of the rorts which are occurring under the system, I would like to give a few assurances. At my electorate office in Caringbah in Sydney there have been many calls from ex-service personnel alarmed by Press reports which suggest we are about to introduce an assets test on pension recipients.
This is not what I am talking about at all.
I further quote:
I am seeking further information about just how widespread are the abuses of the kind I have already discovered, and what we can do to modify the income test on pensions to prevent such abuse.

This must rate as one of the most despicable deceptions ever perpetrated on the Australian public. Can the Minister deny his own words? If not, how does he match them with the Budget action just six weeks later? I am sure that the answer will become clearer a little later as we examine a few other events that have occurred. It became clear, from the examination by Estimates Committee B, that the Government did not have any overall retirement income policy. Answers from officials and from the Minister revealed that on 30 March, 25 days after being elected, the Government established a working group of officials to examine policies on retirement. Included in the report which it handed down, a report dealing with issues relating to occupational superannuation and the age pension system, was the reintroduction of an assets test. That was submitted to the Government on 1 May 1983. It is obvious that the mini-Budget changes of 19 May flowed from that committee. But what did it recommend about assets testing? If it recommended in favour, why was not that too done in the May mini-Budget? I think it is relevant to refer to a quotation from Senator Grimes which appeared in the Bulletin of 10 May 1983. He said:
'Reform of the system involves examining the taxation laws, welfare payments and the economic ramifications. One thing we are wary of, is nibbling away on a piecemeal basis at the structure.'

This is a two-bite method. The Government nibbled away rather than face up to the fundamental issue. Nine weeks after the mini-Budget the Government established a second smaller working group specifically to examine the assets test issue. It consisted of staff from the Department of Social Security, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It was established on 27 July and submitted its report on 11 August.

The establishment of that second group raises two very important questions. First, if an assets test was intended all along, why did the Government wait until nine weeks after the mini-Budget and barely three weeks before the August Budget to start sorting out the details? Secondly, if an assets test was not thought to be a serious option earlier, what prompted the about-face? The answer to the first question is difficult, but the indecent haste with which the working group dealt with the test-15 days, including two weekends-is reflected in the anomalies and inequities in the Australian Labor Party's assets test. This has been thoroughly condemned in the community, as has been evidenced by newspaper reports and complaints from the community generally. Boats, antiques and works of art have been exempted from the assets test while other small capital items have not. It is as a consequence of this indecent haste that the Government is now being forced to look at its exemption provisions, in particular those relating to farms and holiday homes. But by what criteria of equity does the Government exempt a holiday house on wheels-for example, a caravan-and a holiday house on water-for example a boat-of any value at all while holiday houses on land, however modest, are not to be exempted? On what grounds of equity are sophisticated forms of investment like antiques to be exempt while traditional forms such as savings accounts are to be allowed to contain only small amounts of exempt money? Is it coincidence that paintings and antiques are to be exempted from the test and that, according to the statements of Ministers' pecuniary interests, both the Treasurer (Mr Keating), a well known antique dealer, and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) have collections of paintings, antiques and objets d'art valued at more than $5,000? While not suggesting that these items be hit, I simply ask whether these Ministers excluded themselves from all discussions on exemptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your profession? Is it something to do with family trusts?

—I simply ask the question: Were they present during the discussions in Cabinet as to the exemption of those items? Clearly one other factor is involved here, and that is the pressure from the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance as distinct from the Department of Social Security. In relation to the second group which I mentioned earlier that was established to examine the issue of asset testing, there are two possible answers to the question of what prompted the Government to change its mind on the issue and establish a working group to look at its implementation. The Government was forced into the option as a result of its dealings with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry on the superannuation issue, a matter which I will come to in a moment. Or did members of the Ministry use the nine weeks following the mini-Budget to build up support for such a test for purely ideological reasons? Looking at what happened during those nine weeks, it is important to recall the words of the then leader of the ALP, Mr Hayden, during the Lowe by-election in 1982. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The argument about millionaires receiving pensions is a cruel and emotive device to cover up the Government's real intention . . . to justify ripping the pension off ordinary people with modest savings they have worked for all their lives.

Yet during the winter recess this is precisely the argument Senator Gietzelt, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, used when he went about the country. In an address to the State Conference of the Returned Services League in Melbourne on 6 July Senator Gietzelt said:
. . . people with hundreds of thousands of dollars, even some millionaires . . . were receiving a service pension.

He repeated those claims many times during the winter break. But what were Mr Hayden's views about that, and, more importantly, what are the views of the Minister for Social Security? According to a recent article in the Australian Pensioner, he was asked in an interview whether he thought there were many millionaire pensioners, and he replied:
Not the vast numbers that many people think.

Was that line directed at his colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who at one stage promised to name all these people in the Senate, notwithstanding that he is bound by confidentiality under the repatriation legislation which he has sworn to administer faithfully? Is it the case, as some suggest, that the Minister for Social Security took a back seat to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in this matter? This may explain some of the confusion on the question of asset testing that occurred during the meeting of Senate Estimates Committee B. Many questions have arisen over funds directed to the Department of Social Security under Division 312 in the Estimates which relate to 'Special funds for expenditure in relation to Government programs at the direction of the Minister for Finance, $53,000,000'. The Assistant Director-General of the Department stated that the information that $20m would be allocated to the Department of Social Security under this fund had been communicated by the Department of Finance 'in broad terms subsequent to the introduction of the Budget'. The Director-General of the Department stated:
The exact amount decided, no doubt, was the decision taken by the Department of Finance in its judgments of the circumstances.

It seems that the Department of Finance, which was not a member of the second working group on assets testing, was calling the shots on the issue. It is obvious that there is only one inescapable conclusion-that the Department of Social Security was distancing itself from these funding decisions.

During the time between the mini-Budget and the August Budget the Government was involved in attempting to sort out the superannuation mess. Its original announcement of 19 May contained a number of anomalies. These changes discriminated against the self-employed and introduced a de facto death tax. They discriminated against members of the armed forces.
