Lump sums received as benefits by people in the armed services for buying houses or starting businesses were to be taxed to the extent of about one-third. A number of other matters still remain to be clarified by the Government. What changes are to be made to the Life Insurance Act? What return will be determined for annuities? What other categories of contractual termination payments will be included in this item? Are life insurance payments payable upon death, or surrender policies , still to be included? These superannuation changes were made against the background of the fact that on 15 April it was reported that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had assured the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions that tax on superannuation payments would not be increased. This was at the time the first working group was specifically examining that matter. Thirty-four days later the tax increased sixfold. That is the sort of honesty or lack of it that we have come to expect from the Government over the last six months.

On 31 May 1983, the Treasurer supposedly clarified the changes and their intent . Then, as the matter still continued to attract controversy, the Government established a joint working group composed of representatives of the ACTU, the Confederation of Australian Industry and government officials to examine certain aspects of the changes. As a result of that report, the Government announced further changes to its original proposals on 7 August. A number of issues were still ignored. Service personnel were still not exempted. The introduction of approved deposit funds offered no obvious advantages for the self-employed. What processes will be entered into to provide a decent return on annuities?

In the midst of this controversy, the Minister for Finance intervened and revealed that on the latest available figures for 1980 and 1981 of people receiving lump sums only one per cent received more than $100,000. In fact, 92 per cent got less than $20,000, while 75 per cent of that number got less than $ 5,000. Surely that makes a mockery of earlier arguments about cutting down the tall poppies within the community. More importantly than that, it shows up the stupidity of trying to introduce a system of annuities when three-quarters of those who received lump sums could only buy a pittance in the form of an annuity by investing sums of less than $5,000. That is absolutely crazy and the Government stands condemned on that ground alone.

As in relation to the assets test issue, it is clear that the Government acted with haste and without an understanding of the need to adopt an overall approach to retirement income policy in order to avoid creating confusion, concern and hardship amongst the retired. In fact, the Government's actions have caused widespread concern and confusion. That is a fact and the Government cannot get away from it. An attempt to suggest that all would be well within the pensioner community was tried by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr John Brown) last month. That resulted in a disastrous meeting at the Parramatta Town Hall. Local pensioners were incredulous at the claims by the Minister that the Government had sorted out all the problems of the pensioner community. As a consequence of the Government's ad hoc approach I moved to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare the matter of the existing retirement income system with particular reference to any changes necessary to ensure equitable and comprehensive income security for Australians. Despite Government opposition the motion was successfully carried, and the Committee is expected to report in early August 1984.

It is imperative that prior to the introduction by the Government of its two proposed measures it release to the Parliament copies of the reports of the following: The first working group on retirement policy established by the Government on 30 March 1983; the second working group on the assets test issue established on 27 July 1983; and the joint working group of the ACTU, the CAI and Government officials on proposed superannuation changes announced by the Treasurer in the mini-Budget. It is only through those reports that the Government can actually prove that it has all along had a logical, consistent retirement income policy. No other evidence is apparent. If the Government again refuses to release these reports, I will try to find out ways of obtaining them under the Freedom of Information Act. The Opposition's move gained support at a meeting of pensioners held at the Melbourne Town Hall on 20 September when the following motions were carried:
1. That a Senate Committee provide an in-depth review of all matters relating to income security; and
2. That until this Committee tables its report, no legislation be passed by the Senate relating to changes in retirement tax or social security legislation, particularly asset and means testing.

No ALP members were present at that rally. At the same time as the Opposition established the Senate Committee inquiry to take a comprehensive look at retirement income, we announced that we rejected the Government's ad hoc approach and that we would repeal Labor's proposed asset test and superannuation legislation as part of an overall approach that we would take.

In adopting the present piecemeal approach the Government has shown a complete lack of knowledge and/or understanding of the fundamentals in the retirement income area. In a recent interview Senator Grimes rejected the view that most double dipping resulted from the incentives associated with the pensioner health benefit card. I must say that all my contacts and investigations show a different picture. In fact, the attachment of the card to the full pension is obviously a very major incentive for people to seek the pension. Rather than rubbish the Opposition's proposals, the Government should examine fundamental questions such as these so that it can establish whether access to the card is a major factor in people seeking to arrange their affairs to take advantage of the pension benefit. I quote also another statement made by Senator Grimes on 9 May 1979 when he described as nonsense a suggestion that an ALP government would impose a means test on the over-70 pensioners. I wonder how Senator Grimes will explain that today. Eighteen months ago the then Leader of the ALP said that the assets test would be '. . . another kick in the teeth for aged and retired citizens . . .', and that its introduction would be:
. . . another example of the Government's persistent determination to hammer ordinary people into the ground-to force the burden . . . to be borne by those least able to pay . . .

It appears that when the ALP threw out Bill Hayden it threw out concern and compassion for ordinary Australians. The Australian Labor Party has done a complete about face on this matter. We should note this and remember it for the next election. The record of the Government in making changes in the retirement income field is disastrous and borders on the deliberately negligent. It could not possibly have caused more concern and confusion amongst those in the community. It has all the hallmarks of shooting from the hip or an 'announce now , work it all out later' approach in this very important area.

The Government's actions in backtracking time and again on its pre-election commitments are plainly outrageous. The actions of the Ministers concerned in the obfuscatory statements on this issue leading up to the August Budget are absolutely contemptible. They deserve to be condemned. Perhaps Senator Grimes is merely the hapless ball-carrier for this party's ideologues in this area. Clearly, he has been manipulated by Senator Gietzelt whose ideological predilections are well known. In a recent article in the Age on Senator Grimes and the assets test, Kate Legge reported:

There are several unanswered questions about the proposed assets test which Senator Grimes, the consummate politician, has so far been able to fudge; for example, the cost of changes to administer the test . . .

Fudging seems to have become a staple for Labor politicians throughout the country but Senator Grimes, along with Jack Wright, the Deputy Premier in my State, seem to be grand masters of the art. From the announcement of the assets test he has weaved and dodged trying not to commit himself to specifics, despite the specifics contained in the Treasurer's Budget Speech. As a consequence, he has caused considerable anxiety and distress. The extent of that distress and concern was brought home to the Minister at this week's pensioner rally in Sydney. We cannot, or should not, accuse Senator Grimes of deception, dissembling or fudging for, as we all know, he is an honourable man. But 18 months ago Senator Grimes accused the former Government of creating uncertainty and speculation amongst people about to retire. He said:
There has been considerable anxiety and uncertainty among people who have arranged their affairs under the old rules as to just what is happening.

When these same concerns are raised today the Minister washes his hands and says that discussions with his Department are continuing and leaves it at that. He refuses to address the question but, Micawber-like, puts it off in the hope that some miracle will occur to extricate him from his predicament. He must act to clear up confusion and deal with his colleagues, who are pressing him to take action he does not want to take. If he fails to do this, he must wear the name used to describe people who pretend concern and virtue one day--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you reading all this stuff? You know it all.
—I am reading it.
—You do not have to read it.

—Thank you very much. As to those people who change from one day to the next, from pretending virtue one day and then taking some other action the next day, there is obviously one name for their action, and that is hyprocrisy. That is the name of the present Government. It is the name that it is showing to the people. That is why it will stand condemned in the eyes of the people at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude with one final remark from the Minister, which was quoted in the Bulletin of 10 May. It will probably go down as his epitaph, but it is clearly an example of his confused thinking in this area. The Bulletin said:

Apart from the fact that any government that tried to reduce the pension would, in the words of Social Security Minister Senator Don Grimes, 'be shot at dawn', the pension is not exactly over-generous.

Clearly, the Government's actions have been against the interests and, I believe , the views of Senator Grimes in this matter. He has so often and for so long been on the public record as defending a system which is fair and just for all pensioners, and yet he has been forced to carry the ball for a government which is trying to force alternative actions on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner's motion is most timely because there is great concern in the community at present and, indeed, confusion. I am sure that Senator Grimes would not laugh at that comment today. He faced the people at Sydney Town Hall, and he would be very thick-skinned and dumb if he did not understand their concern. The fact that he is so amused now makes me wonder whether those comments are not applicable. In this country we have a very proud history in social welfare. It was in 1908 that the Deakin coalition Government first brought in a scheme for invalid and age pensions. That is quite a record. We were the first of the major Western countries to do so following Germany, New Zealand and the United Kingdom, so we have a very proud history. Successive governments have added to these benefits and have improved them, enabling our elderly citizens to plan. Governments have not cut the benefits drastically. They have added to them as time has gone on. I admit that the whole matter needs examination, but is this new Government looking at it as a whole? It is very obviously not doing that. It is again tampering with things in an ad hoc fashion. That is why in Sydney Town Hall last week Senator Grimes faced what the newspapers called the grey wrath of the pension community. I do not think that Senator Grimes would dare to face those people in the Town Hall with the mirth with which he has faced this motion today.

SPEECH.PARA: For proof of the ad hoc situation that the Government has developed in this matter, we can trace it back. It was in the mini-Budget in May, following the release of a report of a working party, that the Government brought in two changes to the social welfare system. One was a tax on superannuation and the other an income test on the over-70s-two rather disastrous changes for people planning their retirement. If we consider the composition of that working party, it might become a little clearer why I am saying that the approach is ad hoc. The officers who constituted the working party were from the Treasury, which chaired it, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Finance, the Australian Taxation Office, and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat. Note that I said the Department of Finance. So in the mini-Budget we had these two grave decisions. Three months later we had another decision. It was the Budget. The Government brought down an assets test. That test cut right across the mini-Budget decision on the income test for the over-70s. That Budget decision was taken after a further working committee had been set up. Looking at the people on that working committee, we find that there is one important group missing. The committee consisted of officers of the Department of Social Security, and again the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet; the Department of Veterans' Affairs was brought in, and the Department of Finance was thrown out, and I think that that is perhaps the crux of the matter.

The first committee was asked to look at issues relating to occupational superannuation and the age pension system, including the reintroduction of an assets test. We have to make assumptions, because we have not been given the reports, but obviously that committee came down as opposed to an assets test, and as a result the mini-Budget had only the two decisions; or it might have come down in favour of an assets test but the Government of the day thought it too difficult to bring in. However, we have now another committee coming up. How many days was it given? It was given 15 days, including two weekends, to come up with another report. Is it any wonder that it came up with an assets test of the variety that it did?

Let us look at the assets test that it proposed. It is all right for a pensioner to have his own home, at any price at all. It is all right for a pensioner to have a car, of any value. It is all right for him to have a yacht of any value. It is all right for him to have a home full of antiques, of any quality at all. It is all right for him to have his walls covered with works of art. It is all right to store jewellery, which, with the price of gold as it is today is a very good investment. It is all very well to make all those investments, but it is not all very well for a pensioner not to make that sort of choice, but to have his own home and perhaps a seaside cottage, because then the assets test starts biting. It is no wonder that that committee came up with this ridiculous assets test, with all its anomalies, when it had only 15 days in which to look at the matter.

Let us look at the over-70s income test. That starts on 1 November. The superannuation decision and these other two decisions were taken in the mini- Budget. We do not know any of the detail yet. We have had several explanations of what that superannuation should come to. The over-70s test is the most cruel decision the Government has made because it is attacking the most vulnerable in our community. It is attacking those people, as I have said before, who cannot organise their own finances, whose relatives, often their children, have organised their finances about accommodation they can afford, with what the Government pension was giving them. At the age of 80-plus, these people will have to alter their accommodation arrangements because the Government has chosen to take back some of the pension. It seems to me that it is a quite incredible situation because, while that means test starts on 1 November, the assets test comes in later next year. So for 12 months only we will have a situation where by the Government is grabbing back from the most vulnerable people in our community money that it feels can be better spent.

Let us look at what we were told at the Estimates committee hearings about the costs involved. This is the area I am particularly interested in. What is the Government saving on this over-70s income test? Senator Messner and I enquired about the cost of the over-70s income test and we were told that it would be about $3.2m. We were told that the cost of printing the questionnaire to be sent out to pensioners would be $1,756. There was a provision of $200,000 to cover the cost of posting the questionnaires to pensioners. This included return postage. We were told that it was anticipated that an additional 220 staff would be required, at a cost of $3.2m for 1983-84, to process the questionnaires returned from pensioners over 70 years of age. It will cost the Government $3.2m for 12 months to bring in this over-70s income test. So what on earth will the Government get out of it in view of its Budget measures and the introduction of the assets test?

Perhaps we ought to look at the promises that this Government has made. I believe those promises are very important. I will come to them in a few minutes. Perhaps we should first look at what the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said because that is terribly important. The Prime Minister said in his speech in the Budget debate that he would not be touching pensions at all, he would not be touching the pensioners' cheques. As Senator Messner said, we find that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, at the Victorian conference of the Returned Services League said that he was not talking about the introduction of an assets test, he was just talking about the rorts that went on. Such deceit is incredible. He indicated to the people at that conference that he was not going to bring in an assets test at all, he was just informing them of the various rorts. But then all of that changed and we had the mini-Budget and the Budget coming overriding the over-70s income test.

At the Estimates Committee hearings we were told how much this assets test was going to cost. We had officers from the Department of Social Security appearing before us in Estimates Committee B, telling us that they really did not know much about it. They thought it would cost about $20m out of the $53m in special funds for expenditure in relation to Government programs at the direction of the Minister for Finance. They thought it would cost about $20m but they really did not know much about it. After being asked a few more questions they decided to back off altogether and said that they would have to come up with the figures for us at a later date because they did not have them with them and they really did not know a great deal about the matter. This brings me to the two committees set up by the Government. The Department of Finance obviously did not trust the Department of Social Security with the $20m because the Department of Social Security could not come up with details of what it wanted to spend the $20m on. How could it? The Minister still does not know. The Minister still keeps saying that he is looking at the matter. Indeed, at the Sydney Town Hall he told the pensoners that he still had not made up his mind and that he would have to have a look at the holiday home situation. So how could the Department of Social Security come up with any logical figure for the Estimates Committee? So we see that there has been a sleight of hand undertaken and we have the Department of Finance keeping its foot on the $20m and saying that the Department of Social Security will have to justify the spending of that $20m. That $20m has never appeared in the estimates before. It is the first time, and as a committee we were unable to get the answers that we were seeking from the officers.

Why were these three decisions, that is, the means test on the over-70s, the tax on the superannuation and the assets test, taken in such an ad hoc way? I would say that the whole thing was spurred on by ideology. Let us look at a few comments. The present Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, before the Lowe by-election-honourable senators will remember the Lowe by-election in 1982-said:

The argument about millionaires receiving pensions is a cruel and emotive device to cover up the Government's real intention . . . to justify ripping the pension off ordinary people with modest savings they have worked for all their lives.

I wonder how Mr Hayden's comments apply now and how other Ministers feel about them. Senator Gietzelt, in his address to the State conference of the RSL in Melbourne as recently as 6 July, said that there are millionaires everywhere. He said:
. . . people with hundreds of thousands of dollars, even some millionaires, receiving a service pension.
Mr Hayden tells us that that is not true, that it is a cruel device to say that there are millionaires in the pension system.

We just do not know much at all about superannuation, except that a promise is being broken. On 15 April, the Australian Council of Trade Unions was promised by Mr Hawke that there would be no tax on superannuation. The airline pilots were also told that there would be no tax on superannuation. Mr Hawke told the ACTU that on 15 April; but 34 days later he increased the tax on superannuation six-fold. After all the protests and all the yells and screams about inequities from the ACTU, we suddenly had another statement on superannuation from the Government. On 31 May, changes were made. But the ACTU was still not happy and nor were the people of Australia. So a joint ACTU-Confederation of Australian Industry committee was set up and as a result of the recommendations of that committee, more changes were made. On 7 August a further number of changes were announced. We still do not know the details. We still do not know all there is to know about the superannuation situation. We do know from the latest available figures for 1980-81 that only one per cent of people who receive superannuation receive more than $100,000; we know that 92 per cent receive less than $20,000 and we know that three-quarters of those people receive less than $5,000. We were told by the Government that this superannuation tax was really just to cut the wealthy to bits. Three-quraters of the 92 per cent get less than $5,000. Is that really hitting at the heart of the wealth? As I say, we still do not know a thing about the detail of it.

Let us look at Senator Messner's earlier motion, because I believe that that is possibly what will save this Government. He moved a motion to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare the following matter:
Existing retirement income systems, with particular reference to any changes which may be necessary to ensure equitable and comprehensive income security for Australians of retirement age.

The Government did not want that motion to be passed, but the Senate in its wisdom allowed it to pass. As a result, the Committee will see whether it can overhaul the whole of the retirement system of this country. We need the three reports to which reference has been made. If we do not get them, I do not believe honourable senators will be able to vote successfully on the legislation that is to come before us. I ask Senator Grimes whether he will release those three reports. As Senator Messner has said, they ought to be available to us and I am quite sure that Senator Evans would insist, as the Attorney-General and because of his great support for freedom of information, that they come to the Opposition.

I said I would come back to the promises that were made and not honoured. I know the Government is getting a bit sick of hearing about all the promises it has made that have not been honoured, but let us see what the Australian Labor Party policy speech said. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said that he would lift to $5,893 the tax threshold for pensioners. That has not happened. Indeed, because of the additional sales tax that has been instituted in the Budget, pensioners will pay more tax, not less. Because of that sales tax there is no way that pensioners will not pay more. The second broken promise was that there would be immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million taxpayers, with the greatest tax cuts going to those on the lowest incomes. A lot of those very low income people also receive part pensions, and again the pensioners will not be getting the tax cuts they were promised but, because of the sales tax to which I have referred, will be paying additional taxes. Mr Hawke also said:

We are committed to raising over a period of three years the basic pension from 22 per cent of average male earnings . . . to 25 per cent. Once we reach that goal we will maintain that 25 per cent proportion by indexation until it is impossible to take the pension higher.
That again has not been honoured. To date the Government has simply applied normal indexation rises to pensions. It has not attempted to make up the 22 to 25 per cent in any way. Mr Hawke also said:
Pensions will be adjusted on the basis of the immediately prior six months CPI movement to cut the present lag from four months to one month.
That is another promise that has not been honoured. How long need I go on?

TALK.START.PARA: —How long have we been in Government?

—The Government has put down its first Budget but it has not abided by any of the promises that it made in its policy speech and I cannot understand why Senator Grimes, at least, is not saying something about it.
—I will in a moment; if you will sit down I will be up.

—The honourable senator finds it amusing. I am sure the pensioners are not finding it amusing and I am quite sure that there will be many more Sydney Town Hall meetings for the Minister to face in the period ahead of him. If Senator Grimes does not give us the reports that we are asking for, if they are not made available, that will underline the ad hoc ideology and the rush job that was done with these three main decisions. Senator Grimes does know a fair bit about social welfare. I have been on a committee with him and he knows darned well that the most important things pensioners want-it is why they will go into double dipping-are the fringe benefits. The most important thing they want is the health card, yet the Minister in an interview denied that this was a fact. I know that that is not his thinking. He is brighter than that; he really does understand it. I do not understand why he is allowing this to happen . It is his portfolio and he is completely responsible for it. He cannot get out of it on the grounds that he 'would like to but can't'. He has caused tremendous confusion and concern amongst the elderly in this country and I feel that he, personally, owes the pensioner population an explanation, not only of his actions but also of those of his Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing can indicate to the Senate more the poverty of ideas and the poverty of policy of members of the Opposition than the two speeches we have just heard on this matter, particularly the speech from Senator Walters. One can only describe it as pathetic. One can only describe the effort that she put into preparing her speech as pathetic, especially for someone who wanted to make some impact in this debate. If anyone in this place deserves a prize, both Senator Walters and Senator Messner deserve it for having the cheek, first of all in Senator Messner 's case, to put down a motion demanding the reports that he has demanded and, secondly, in Senator Walters's case for spending so much of her very brief speech requesting these reports, demanding them and threatening to use the freedom of information provisions et cetera. In all the years of the previous Government, from 1975 to 1983, Cabinet documents were produced by working parties of the type that produced some of the documents that this Government used in considering its policy. We had reports produced by strange committees made up of government back benchers, such as Mr Spender, Mr Sainsbury and Mr Hodges, accompanied by a few other back benchers, on which the Government allegedly based its policy decisions. How many of those reports ever saw the light of day in this place? What would the answer have been from Senator Chaney, or Senator Messner when he was a Minister, if we had had the gall to come in here and demand Cabinet documents? The answer would have been the same as the answer I gave in the Estimates committee hearings. They are Cabinet documents and Cabinet documents are not as a rule released, but I will consider with my Cabinet colleagues whether they should be released.

SPEECH.PARA: To come in here and demand documents of this type, in the light of the record of the previous Government, is an absolute cheek and we should just laugh at it. The only report that received the light of day was the Spender report, and that fell off the back of a truck. We asked for the Hodges report and we asked for the Sainsbury report. After the Spender report was circulated throughout the length and breadth of this land we still asked: 'Could not the Senate have an official look at it?' Senator Chaney said: 'No, we do not release working documents like that. What sort of an affair would it be if governments came into this place and released documents like that on which we based policy?' The problem facing Senator Messner and Senator Walters is simply this: They were members of a party which was in Government from 1975 until 1983. In all of that time, with all of the resources available to government, they could not produce a comprehensive retirement policy in this country. Senator Messner has admitted that in this place. We now have the news that they will not be able to produce a comprehensive policy by next year.

In order, as they thought, to embarrass the Government and in order to get someone else to do their work for them, they came into this place and moved that the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare look at a comprehensive retirement policy. They did so because they were in trouble. They were facing a government which had produced comprehensive retirement programs. They were in trouble. They knew they could not produce the goods themselves so they thought they would get a Senate Committee to do it. Now they have the gall to come in here and say that not only do they want the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare to do it but they also want the Cabinet documents-documents which they would never have released when they were in government-to produce the facts and figures and undertake the inquiry for them. They do not want to do the work themselves; they want the Senate to do it for them and they even have the gall to want the Cabinet to do it for them.

I think the most disgraceful thing we heard this afternoon was Senator Messner' s comment about Mr Keating. It is disgraceful to suggest that the assets test was designed in a way to protect Mr Keating because Mr Keating has an interest in some antiques. Senator Messner was an accountant. Am I to get up in this place--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order.
—The honourable senator will sit down.

—I take a point of order. I want to draw the Minister's attention to the fact that I made no such remark. What I did was to seek an assurance that the two Ministers concerned did not take part in Cabinet discussions on this matter.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Senator Messner came into this place and imputed improper motives to Mr Keating and this Government. Senator Messner was an accountant. Part of his job as an accountant was to take part in tax evasion schemes. Part of his job as an accountant was to have people avoid paying their proper tax. Did he ever excuse himself from any party meeting concerning tax evasion? Did he excuse himself from this Senate during the tax evasion and tax avoidance debate? No, he did not. He got up there and defended tax dodgers. He defended tax dodgers in this place to the extent that the Government lost some $500m in revenue. He did so in order to protect the people who used to pay his salary before he came into this place and who probably pay part of it now. He had the gall to get up in this place and say that I was a hypocrite. Apparently the use of that word is now accepted in the Parliament as he was not pulled up when he made that remark. He was not stopped from doing so. I think if one wants to look at hypocrites--
—Order! I point out at this stage that in fact Senator Messner did not call you a hypocrite. He alleged hypocrisy at the Government which I understand is in order.

—I am sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President, but that was his second comment. His first comment was that Senator Grimes was indulging in hypocrisy. One who indulges in hypocrisy is a hypocrite. Let us look at what is hypocrisy. Let us look at the words of Senator Walters. Senator Walters got up and bleated about what she saw as the unfair treatment of people over 70 years of age. She described them as the most vulnerable group in the community. She said it was a terrible thing to introduce an incomes test in this area. What did the previous Government do? The previous Government introduced an incomes test on increases in the over-70s pension. The clear intention was to allow that pension to be eroded by inflation. When that happened, what did Senator Walters do? She did nothing. What did Senator Walters say in the debates in this place when this was happening? She said nothing. If the Senate wants an example of hypocrisy I refer it to the Hansard record of Senator Walters's speech today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner has charged the Government with having confused views on vital questions affecting pre-retirees and aged pensions. That is apparently the gist of his charge. I put it to the Senate that in fact there is still, and there has been for a long time, a great confusion of views among members of the Opposition . It was members of the Opposition, when in Government, who presided over the evolution of the retirement income system which is acknowledged by anyone who looks at it, including Ministers of the previous Government, to be inequitable and ineffective in meeting its objectives. We have a system which allows those who can acquire large asset holdings and large cash holdings to enter into contrived schemes so as to avoid an incomes test whereas those on fixed superannuation payments and fixed incomes are subject to an incomes test. The retirement income of the latter group is reduced. We have a system which allows the leeching out of in excess of $2,000m in superannuation tax concessions and lump sum concessions. That system allows the leaking of an estimated $250m to $ 300m in the contrived schemes to which I have just referred. Such a system inevitably results in any government, be it Labor, Liberal or National, being severely limited in its capacity to increase the base rate of pension which goes to those who largely have no extra income and to increase the benefits which are available to those who need housing, to increase the benefits to those who need special accommodation and to increase the benefits and services available in the community generally. The previous Government presided over a system which directed excessive benefits to a minority, the already well off superannuitants such as the airline pilots whose protest collapsed so ingloriously yesterday. The previous Government failed to make any realistic efforts to prevent these people gaining access to age pensions meant to be directed to people in need. It failed to give any positive encouragement to people who wished to provide for a regular and secure income after retirement.

The system that evolved under the previous Government in fact positively discriminated against people taking a superannuation pension and annuity and provided a staggering artificial distortion, such that Australia became unique in the world towards taking lump sum superannuation benefits. All the inquiries, including the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry, pointed out that a national superannuation scheme could not be introduced while we allowed the sorts of distortions about which I have been speaking.

The distortion in the tax system was exacerbated when the previous Government changed the means test to an incomes test. This opened up widespread opportunities for the avoidance with which we are familiar. People with substantial assets were able to invest through artificial schemes and trusts and the like so as to still gain a considerable pension entitlement-often the maximum pension entitlement. From the day the assets test was removed we had a burgeoning industry of contrived investments to the disadvantage of low income people in the community. Successive Liberal Ministers for Social Security recognised this. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Chaney recognised it. They talked about the need for a needs-based welfare system. At one stage they even made a pathetic effort to do something about it. In the 1982 Budget Senator Chaney announced what was going to be a crackdown on income rigging arrangements to avoid the pensions income test. Nothing ever happened. At the time the then Government made the announcement we pointed out that it had no idea what it was going to do and no idea how to do it. A couple of months later the then Government withdrew from the area.

If one really wants to cause anxiety among people and problems for pensioners that is the way to go about it. This Government knows what it is doing and it knows how to achieve it. We want to do so in consultation with the people concerned and with the organisations which represent them. All our actions have a clear and consistent rationale. We want to provide a secure adequate retirement income to those who need it. We are concerned that those who manifestly do not need it should not receive it.

Despite the coalition Government's rhetoric about assisting those in need, it actually tolerated and sometimes even promoted a system of superannuation tax concessions which squandered billions of dollars on those who quite manifestly were not in need. On the latest Treasury estimate that action cost $2.5 billion. The Government's lump sum tax proposals, in a moderate and responsible way, have started to make modest inroads into this huge system of so-called middle and upper class welfare. These, along with other measures which were announced in the May statement, will provide a positive inducement for people to provide a continuing secure retirement income for themselves in the form of a superannuation pensioner annuity. The measures are welcomed by large sections of the insurance industry. They are welcomed by those sections of industry which have wanted to provide this sort of measure so that people could retire in a secure and reasonable way and yet not distort the taxation and welfare systems.

I remind the Senate that the other measures which we are introducing are the removal of the legislative barriers, which have effectively prevented life offices and superannuation funds from selling annuities, and the removal of the double taxation of annuities in the hands of life offices as well as individuals . We are reviewing the present arrangements under which the return of a capital component of such a pension is taken into account in the age pension income test , a review now being continued in the context of the proposed introduction of an assets component to that test. We are canvassing the possible introduction of new types of securities, including indexed bonds, which could assist life offices and superannuation funds to meet the needs of retired people for secure and regular incomes. We are exempting from tax entirely, including the existing tax of 5 per cent of the amount, lump sum superannuation payments which are rolled over into such new schemes. We are exempting from tax entirely, again including the existing tax on 5 per cent of the amount, lump sum superannuation payments which are used to buy pensions. We are exempting from tax entirely that part of the lump sum which represents the return of the employee's own contributions unless they have already attracted a tax deduction. Taken together , these measures will enable many Australians to plan for their retirement with far greater confidence than they can at the moment.

The arrangements enabling those changing jobs to roll over lump sum superannuation payments into new schemes, or to buy deferred pensions without paying any tax, will facilitate the preservation of accrued benefits and thus represent a significant step towards improving portability. The Government will be giving further consideration to measures to encourage portability after our discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and interested parties and in the light of the report of the Task Force on Occupational Superannuation which was tabled recently by the Treasurer. Each dollar that the Government forgoes in superannuation tax concessions, which accrue primarily to better off employees, is a dollar not available to improve basic age pension entitlements. Each dollar of pension paid to those with considerable income or assets is a dollar not available to the great bulk of ordinary pensioners who are not well off and who have not got the facilities that others have. These ordinary pensioners will not be adversely affected by changes to the over-70s pension or the introduction of a pension assets test. In fact, some of them will be better off as a result of the introduction of that test.

In the light of this, the Opposition has accused us of confusion. How confused, I put it to the Senate, was its policy which allowed wealthy retirees to exploit , or even cheat on, our pension system? How confused was its policy on the over- 70s pension, or how hypocritical was it, when, instead of honestly showing what its intention was, what its policy was, in fact, aimed at allowing the value of that pension to be whittled away by inflation? How confused was its policy of directing assistance to those in need by a pension income test that was never indexed and was not increased until its last year of Government, while rich superannuitants, including former members of that Government, were able to take their money and run? That is confusion. That is the policy of confusion and anxiety. The Labor Government repudiates this.

We have seen some extraordinary changes from honourable senators opposite. We have seen the former Minister for Social Security doing a dramatic reversal in his attitude to pension policy. He is reported as telling the Liberal Party Federal Council on Saturday that a needs-based welfare system could hurt Liberal voters. He said nothing about Labor voters. He said nothing about ordinary Australians. I note that that Council was so impressed by Senator Chaney's words and by the less than unanimous policy of the parliamentary Party on the repeal of the assets test that it passed a motion directly contrary to that policy. The Council said:
This council expresses its support for a needs-based social welfare system and therefore believes that welfare benefits should be payable subject to a means test.

That is a direct quote from Monday's Sydney Morning Herald. I have not heard anyone on the other side deny the report. If we want to clear up some confusion we had better ask the Liberal Party just what its policy is on the means test. Senator Chaney is further reported as saying that the system over which he presided for two and a half years:
. . . also needs tidying up and improving to remove that sort of illogicality which is a very heavy burden on many of the sort of people that I think the Liberal Party is about . . .

Certainly it is illogical, but the Liberal Party and National Party had all those years from 1975 to 1983 to do something about it. They failed to act. They failed to maintain the pension in relation to average earnings. The current rhetoric is a clear indication of their disinterest and their hollowness. At the same conference, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, said that he supported the means test resolution but he did not support the Labor Government' s foreshadowed assets test.

Apparently Mr Peacock and Senator Walters believe that ordinary items of private possession in the home, such as antiques and the odd painting-not antiques and paintings that a person deals in-should be included in a means test . This would involve valuers going into every home. It would involve valuers going into people's homes to value their private possessions. As much as some of us on this side would like to see the result of a valuer going into Senator Walters's home and getting the valuation of everything in it, in the light of the poverty stricken State in which she lives we do not believe the people of this country would wear it, nor do we believe that they should. I think that one of the problems with the confusion that Senator Walters talks about is contributed to considerably by Senator Walters and her ilk. After all, it was Senator Walters's office in Hobart which informed people who rang in that people would lose their pension if they had $1,500 or $2,400 in the bank. That was a disgraceful and lying statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it deliberate?
—Of course it was deliberate; it had to be deliberate.
—I thought she might be too thick to understand it.

—I know that Senator Walters is not very bright, but even Senator Walters is a bit brighter than that. She is willing deliberately to sow confusion in the community about this. Senator Walters came in here yesterday, I gather-she repeated it again today-and talked about the meeting that was held in the Town Hall in Sydney on Tuesday. It was in fact one of the best meetings I have been to. I understand Senator Chaney also enjoyed going to the Sydney Town Hall and being lambasted by people, some of whom were pensioners and some of whom were not. Senator Walters apparently said that I came sneaking back here with my tail between my legs after that meeting because of the abuse, et cetera, that I was supposed to have received.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I should like to say that I am not that thick-skinned, but anyone who has had to put up with the stuff that Senator Walters, Senator Messner and particularly Senator Lajovic carry on with in this place, does not have much to worry about if he goes to a meeting of elderly people in the community. Secondly , after the meeting I stayed in the hall for half an hour talking to and discussing this matter with them. There were some people who were very annoyed. The lady who had two houses worth $100,000 in Sydney, a holiday home in Cairns, a holiday home in Noosa, and three blocks of land on the north coast of Queensland was very annoyed that she would not receive a full pension, but she did not impress many of the people around her. Most of the people there who were willing to discuss the matter and to talk about it understood the situation and realised that something had to be done, and they were concerned about the details.

However, Senator Messner does not go to meetings like that. He goes to meetings in Melbourne arranged by the Australian Retired Persons Association. These are people who have exploited the income test, exploited the retired people in this country for their own gain, and have manipulated the system both of the friendly societies and the income test in such a way as to provide for themselves a very comfortable living and very comfortable working conditions under the guise of assisting retired people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet there were a few accountants.

—There were a few accountants there; Senator Giles is right. Now what has happened to them? They bleat. Some of them are articulate. They are wealthy, and they can organise and hold meetings such as the meeting Senator Messner talked about. They are the meetings that Senator Messner will go to. They are the meetings at which he will turn up and try to sow confusion and discontent. What he would really like to do, and what they would like him to do, is get up and give some idea of what he thinks would be a reasonable retirement policy in this country, what he thinks should be done about the people who are poor and do not have homes, and what should be done to afford a greater redistribution of income in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: These notices of motion brought forward by Senator Messner are typical of the sorts of motions that he brings forward. They frequently get support. They may get support today, but what they are about is attacking and nitpicking at a government which in six or seven months in office has taken positive steps towards creating a coherent retirement policy for people in this country, a policy which I point out has been supported widely by those in the community who know what a difficult situation we will face in the future with an aging population and what a difficult situation we will face if we allow the present distortions of the taxation and welfare systems to proceed.

This Government's policy, by reforming the superannuation taxation system, reforming the assets test, reforming the parliamentary pensions scheme, is paving the way to the development of a contributory superannuation scheme in this country in line with schemes in most Western democracies. Such a scheme will provide for people what superannuation is supposed to provide, that is, a regular protected retirement income which will give people the right to contribute towards their retirement and have those contributions protected. It will give people the right to carry that protection when they change jobs. It will give people the sort of security that people in some of those Western social democracies have, and will result in the capacity of government to provide basic benefits at an adequate level and to provide the community services that are so lacking in our social security system, and in our economic system generally.

It is for this reason that we persist with our policies. It is for this reason that the polls, despite the screams of Senator Messner and Senator Walters, demonstrate that the electorate, the community, accepts what the Federal Labor Government is doing. We are doing things because we know they are right and we are doing things to develop a better system in this country. We are not doing things with an eye on an election next year or the year after, in the way the previous Prime Minister did. We are not inhibited in our policy making by the fact that some people, of course, will not like change, that some people will resist change. We are developing our policies with the aim of helping our fellow citizens to have a fairer and more equitable society. We will persist in doing that despite the narking and the nitpicking of those opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will not delay the Senate for long but I want to comment on one or two remarks made by Senator Grimes. First and foremost, I must explain to him that I have not practised as an accountant since I entered Parliament nor have I had any serious involvement in accounting operations since then. I hope that he might accept that as an explanation for some of the actions he was attributing to me. Secondly, in regard to the confusion that has been generated in this community as a result of his Government's actions, I believe he would have done far better to have stood up here on 19 May when the mini-Budget was brought down and explained to people precisely what it was that he had in mind for a national superannuation scheme, rather than to keep justifying his approach by taking individual cases of proclaimed self-made millionaires or very wealthy people and using those as the fall guys for justifying his particular policy motions. It is pretty clear that that point has got through to the community generally. If he has a policy, we on this side of the fence would like very much to understand it better.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pretty sure that nobody outside the Senate understands what the Government is on about. Clearly there is a need for us to see and judge for ourselves-the Standing Committee on Social Welfare particularly needs to do this-the documents which we seek as a result of the motions which are before the Senate. I hope that the motions gain the support of the Australian Democrats in such a way as to enable us to put more pressure on the Government to reveal information which is vital to our understanding of its approach in trying to solve the retirement income problem. From that point of view I hope that all honourable senators on this side will join with us to defeat the Government on these motions, and I look forward to the day when the Government will release these documents for our personal perusal.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:
That intervening business be postponed until after consideration of Government Business, order of the day No. 1 relating to the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983.
(Quorum formed).
Consideration resumed.
Clause 47 (Proceedings in absence of parties).

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, what happens in the event of Senator Walters's amendment being defeated? Is proposed new section 98A then resubmitted to the Committee?

—If Senator Walters's amendment is defeated I will put it to the Committee that clause 47, as amended by the two amendments of the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans), be agreed to. The immediate question is that Senator Walters's amendment be agreed to, in other words, that the words proposed to be omitted be omitted.

—For the benefit of honourable senators, the Committee has been considering this question which, in shorthand, is the divorce by post question. Consideration of that matter had virtually concluded by the time that the sitting was suspended for lunch. I am concerned that all senators be aware of the fact that the Committee will now vote on this matter which has had widespread public attention. I know it is very difficult to follow a debate such as this when it comes in between other matters of General Business and Government Business, but I thought I should rise to say that I thought we had virtually concluded the major debate on this item.

—I thank Senator Harradine. I am quite sure that he knew that Senator Evans had, I suppose, rubbished me so much that I had to get up and have another go. Quite seriously, I was very sorry to hear Senator Evans say that all Senator Harradine and I were interested in was the symbolism of marriage. That is not true. If that is all that he has got out of the debate, then obviously either I am a very poor debater or he has just turned off and not listened. I think he said that I thought it was a symbolic gesture and that it was sentimental claptrap, to use his words. Both those statements are as far from what I am talking about as they could possibly be. There is nothing at all symbolic about my concern for the stability of marriage; nor is there any sentimental claptrap about my concern for the stability of marriage.
—It is sincere sentimental claptrap.

—I do not care how the Attorney-General puts it. I have told him before that he is intoxicated by his own verbosity. It really does get him into a lot of trouble. He keeps talking and he gets people so irate that they get up and speak. The main point I would like to put to Senator Evans is this: He described divorce by post as someone having to hunt around for the non-defending spouse to let him or her know that the divorce is taking place. Could Senator Evans tell me how long a person has to hunt down the non-defending spouse? What period of time is allowed for a spouse to look for a non-defending spouse to let that party know that he or she is being divorced?

—Yes, the regulations make provision for the service of notices of this kind. A number of notices, of course, deal with different stages of the marriage dissolution process. I understand that the standard period that is allowed for the 'hunting down', as Senator Walters described it, of spouses is 42 days. That is not just in the context of this kind of notice which I assume would be common to the rules provided elsewhere, but for all other notices that have to be served in the course of the proceedings. The regulation in question is regulation 38 of the Family Law Regulations.

—So Senator Evans is saying that five or six weeks is sufficient if, say, a wife does not know where her husband is. He believes that would be enough time if the husband is in England or wherever he happens to be, for him to be contacted? I think it is tremendously important that the spouse knows he is being divorced.

—I fully appreciate that. Of course, this occurs only in the context of a 12 months separation and a number of earlier stages in the proceedings. One assumes that the parties have a reasonable idea of what is going on by the time they get to this stage. But in case they do not, the rule provides for a significant time lapse to take place. That applies to notices under the Act as they stand at the moment. It will be necessary to promulgate new regulations to govern the detailed procedures of this divorce on the papers procedure. I am sure the Family Court judges who will be drafting these regulations will take close account of what the honourable senator has said in attending to their task.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say that, really, it was not for the purposes described by Senator Walters that I had risen. I rose genuinely to alert people to the fact that this is a very important piece of legislation. I must say, and I do not mind whether it goes on the record, that though I have had some differences of opinion now and again with the Attorney-General I have always found him courteous and making an attempt to understand, if that is possible, what I am trying to drive at in certain aspects. I appreciate that. We do differ on this issue in a matter of approach. I believe that really what the Parliament is being asked to do at this point in time is undermine the public importance of marriage. As I said before, the parties to a marriage are told by the marriage celebrant, when they are being married, that the Parliament, in the Family Law Act places great stress on the importance of marriage and family life as the basis to the strength of our society. It is a fact of life that marriage is a matter of public importance to Australia. I believe that the proposed new section 98A, the divorce by post proposition, undermines that situation and reverses the public character of marriage. We should not forget that the law has a great educative role. Those contemplating marriage would be entitled to express confusion and alarm if great stress was placed on their legal responsibilities prior to marriage with the knowledge that under the provisions of proposed new section 98A their mutual rights and responsibilities could be terminated in what might be considered a perfunctory and inconsistent approach should proposed new section 98A be adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Walters's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated, in remarks I made I think during the second reading debate and perhaps during the early stage of consideration in the Committee of the Whole, that I have formed the view that the proposal in clause 47 of the Family Law Amendment Bill should not proceed. It is one which has given me a great deal of concern because it was a proposal that I accepted in the first place. When this Bill was introduced in the Senate it contained a similar proposal, although of course I concede that the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) has greatly reduced the ambit of the proposal. It now will not apply where there are any children under 18 years of age in the marriage and will apply only in cases of undefended divorces when there are either no children or children who have grown up. That certainly is a great improvement.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, I am concerned about the perceptions that the community has formed of the Family Law Act. I believe it has been a major social experiment and has created tensions and very deep concerns. I believe that by now going this further step and eliminating the need for any attendance at all by a party or a party's representative at the dissolution process, will be seen, and has been seen, by large sections of the community as a further weakening of the Parliament's attitude to the dissolution of marriage. We have had several debates on this issue in the Senate. Amendments have already been discussed, one of which-that moved by Senator Harradine-we will have to go back to. I moved amendments in relation to extending the period of separation and preventing the courts from taking into account the availability of pensions in assessing maintenance and property settlements. I think this is another of those key questions, the decision on which will greatly affect the future course of community attitudes to marriage and the family. I believe we should not take this further step for those reasons.

Clause 47 seemed to numbers of people-probably the majority of honourable senators in this chamber-to be a sensible practical step. I admit that it seemed such to me when it was first proposed. But I have been particularly impressed by the criticism of the clause, coming as it has from very important sections of the community, particularly religious bodies. They are expressing what I think the Attorney-General termed a somewhat symbolistic argument. That is the only argument I am concerned with, but I have been very impressed by it. I believe it would be unwise for this Parliament to take this further step. When all is said and done the process of dissolving a marriage takes up relatively little time of the Family Court. It is hard to present this clause as any major practical step to improve the workings of the Court or to better use the resources of the Court and so forth. Indeed, the Attorney's amendments have probably reduced that argument by up to about 50 per cent anyway. But even so, I still believe that even if that consideration did not apply we should not-for the very broad but, I think, very important reasons that I have mentioned-support this particular proposal for divorce on the papers as set out in this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support what has been said and to refer honourable senators to the comments that I made at about 12.20 p.m. today. In view of the time that is all I will say, but I say it with great conviction, believing that this is a retrograde step.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That clause 47, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 48 to 56-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 56A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Page 41, after clause 56, insert the following new clause:
''56A. After section 112 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted in Part XIV:
Interpretation
'112A. In this Part, ''marriage'' includes a void marriage.'.''.

The object of this amendment is to insert a new section 112A in the Act, the effect of which will be to put it beyond doubt that courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act can entertain proceedings for, in particular, injunctions in circumstances in which the marriage is void. There are other remedies available to the courts in dealing with void marriage situations, remedies which primarily arise as a practical matter in nullity proceedings. The kinds of circumstances in which marriages are rendered void are set out in section 23 of the Marriage Act; for example, in a bigamous situation where either of the parties is married to someone else at the time of the marriage; where there is a prohibited degree of affinity or blood relationship between the parties; where the consent of either one of the parties was not a real one, for reasons of mistaken identity, which can happen, or fraud or duress, or something of that kind; or where either of the parties is not of marriagable age. In all these situations, which are technically void marriages, problems can still nonetheless arise under the Family Law Act requiring the application of enforcement powers and procedures. This is simply to remedy an anomaly in the Act, the omission of a provision for the remedy, in particular, of injunction.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause 57 (Injunctions).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would I be in order, Mr Chairman, in moving amendments to clauses 57 and 58 together?
—I think that would be confusing. There are a number of amendments to clause 58, so let us clear up clause 57 first.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 42, clause 57, line 2, after 'work', insert 'or the place of education'.

This is a simple amendment. It relates to a matter that I raised in my speech at the second reading stage, that is, the protection of children while they are at school. It deals with injunctions which the Family Court may grant or orders that it may make with respect to the matter to which the court proceedings relate. It relates to the personal protection of partners to the marriage or their children and provides for injunctions restraining one party from entering or remaining in the place of residence or work of the other party or of a child of the marriage. Clearly, the majority of children of a marriage do not have a place of work, and most of those not at work are in full time education. My amendment makes allowance for the protection of these children by extending this provision to cover places of education. These may be schools or, in the cases of older children of, say, 17, they may even be tertiary institutions.

My reason for moving this amendment is based on my own experience as a counsellor working in a school. Parents do turn up at schools demanding, sometimes in a very threatening way, to talk to their children. The occurrence is common enough to have prompted education authorities to issue advice to schools on handling such situations, but the legal position of a principal or a teacher is not clear at present. Schools are advised to contact the custodial parent, but that is not always possible, and the child does not always know the legal position of custody and access. The child, too, is often most unwilling to meet those parents who have arrived at the school, or fears repercussions from the other parent, even if the child does not personally object to the contact. Even in cases in which the school knows that access has been denied, they are in a difficult position when the demanding parent is there, on the spot.

An injunction would certainly strengthen the position of the school principal, and would, I hope, deter those parents who try to circumvent the denial of access by approaching the child in the place where it spends most of its time outside the home-that is, the school. My amendment is intended to clarify the existing wording and its clear intent. It aims to give added protection to children who may be under considerable stress already and to give backing to the adults in whose temporary care children are placed while at school.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government supports the amendment for the reasons that Senator Zakharov has outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 58.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 43, clause 58, line 14, leave out 'or area', insert ', area or place'.

This is really a consequential amendment, following on my amendment to clause 57 . It clarifies the definition of place to which an injunction applies by the addition of the word 'place' to the term 'any premises or area'.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Page 43, proposed new paragraph 114AA (3) (a), lines 16 to 18, leave out the proposed paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
''(a) he shall-
(i) ensure that the person is brought before the court that authorized the arrest, or another court having jurisdiction under this Act, before the expiration of the relevant period; and

(ii) take all reasonable steps to ensure that, before the person is so brought before a court, the person on whose application the order under sub-section (1) was made is aware that the first-mentioned person has been arrested and of the court before which he is to be brought; and''.

This is a substitute amendment for the amendment of which I originally gave notice. The idea originates from recommendations which came from the Family Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia. It deals basically with the question of where someone is going to be dealt with and arrested, and in particular the other party, or presumably the party who probably has been assaulted or threatened with assault will know that the person is coming before the court and that party will therefore have an opportunity to be there and to give evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other amendments have been circulated, to clarify this matter for the Committee, Senator Missen, you are moving amendment No. 21, circulated on the consolidated list?
—That is so, Mr Chairman. In the recommendation that the Law Council made, it had this to say about this section:

SPEECH.PARA: It is suggested that the police officer, upon arresting a person, should be required to forthwith notify the applicant of the arrest and the court before which the person is to be brought.

This could then be added as a new paragraph 114AA (3) (c). It was pointed out to me that it may not always be possible to notify, so this provides that all reasonable steps shall be taken to ensure that the person is notified. As redrafted, I think that it probably has practical application.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government supports Senator Missen's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Page 44, proposed new sub-section 114AB (2), lines 25 to 33, leave out the proposed sub-section, insert the following sub-sections:

'' '(2) Where a person has instituted a proceeding or taken any other action under a prescribed law of a State or Territory in respect of a matter in respect of which he would, but for this sub-section, have been entitled to institute a proceeding under section 114 or 114AA, the person is not entitled to institute a proceeding under the section concerned in respect of that matter.

'' '(3) Any proceedings instituted by a person that are pending under section 114 at the commencement of this section in respect of a matter in respect of which the person has, before that commencement, instituted a proceeding or taken any other action under a law prescribed for the purposes of sub-section (2) are, by force of this sub-section, terminated.'.''.

The effect of this amendment is to attempt to preserve the operation of State legislation aimed at the prevention of domestic violence. Proposed new sub- section (2) of section 114AB, as it will stand if this amendment is accepted, provides in effect two things: That where a person has commenced an action in respect of a particular matter under State law, he cannot then commence an action in respect of the same matter under the Federal Family Law Act; and secondly, that if at the date that this new section comes into force there are actions pending under both Commonwealth and State law in respect of the same matter, then the action under the Commonwealth law would automatically lapse. It is a transitional provision. The proposed sub-section as drafted originally caused some confusion, particularly to certain State governments which have a great interest in this provision. It is an interest which the Government is quite happy to accommodate. Therefore, the sub-section in the form in which it was originally drafted has been redrafted so as to be split into two sub- sections, just really for the purpose of making the meaning absolutely clear. It should be noted that it is not open to the Commonwealth to legislate to prevent persons who have commenced actions under Commonwealth law subsequently commencing State actions. This would be a matter for State law, and I shall be suggesting to the various State Attorneys-General such complementary legislation .

Senator Crowley has drawn to my attention two questions that have apparently been referred to her concerning the operation of the new power of arrest provisions which are contained in this clause. I believe that it would be appropriate to put on public record the answers to those questions, which are no doubt interesting a number of people. The first question is: Which police force will execute the power of arrest orders which will be able to be granted under proposed new section 113AA? The answer to this is that both the Australian Federal Police and the State and Northern Territory police forces can execute such orders. This situation is expressly provided for in proposed new section 114AA (7).

The second question is whether persons whose marriages have been dissolved will be able to obtain personal protection injunctions under the Family Law Act. The answer to that question is: Yes, the Act, in section 4 (2), already deems the term 'party to a marriage' to include a party to a dissolved or annulled marriage. Therefore, the new power of arrest provisions will be available to a party to a marriage which has been dissolved or annulled. I hope that that clarifies some confusion and uncertainty that has existed in people's minds as to the operation of this proposed new section.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 59 and 60-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 61 (Family Law Council).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Page 45, before paragraph (1) (a), insert the following paragraphs:
''(aa) by inserting in sub-section (2) 'magistrates ,' after 'judges,';
''(ab) by inserting in sub-section (2) ', Senators, Members of the House of Representatives' after 'organizations';''.

This amendment relates to the composition of the Family Law Council which does a great deal of useful work in surveying from time to time the operations of the Act. It has made many contributions to the suggestions that have come forward in this debate. In that respect perhaps I should first read section 115 (2) of the principal Act, which states:

The Council shall consist of a Judge of the Family Court and such other judges, officers of the Australian Public Service or of the Public Service of a State, representatives of marriage counselling organizations and other persons as the Attorney-General thinks fit.

The Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act felt that there were two other sources of membership that could be added to the Family Law Council. Recommendation 53 of the Joint Committee at paragraph 7.102 states:

Accordingly the committee recommends that the membership of the Family Law Council be extended to include representations of federal parliament. This representation should be drawn from the Senate and the House of Representatives. There should also be representation of magistrates on the Council.

Dealing firstly with the matter of magistrates, magistrates do have a substantial part to play in family law matters. Many of us regret that there has not been a much quicker operation and development of the Family Court throughout the jurisdiction. But I think that the guidance and help that a magistrate of considerable experience in family law dealings could bring to the Family Law Council would make it desirable that there should be at least one magistrate on that Council. At least it should be within the capacity of the Attorney-General to appoint such a person.

So far as the parliamentary appointments are concerned, this is a matter which has been argued for some time. It comes about that we will have a review after a few years, and it is important, I think, that the Parliament should continue to be constantly aware of what are the problems. Those parliamentary representatives could make a contribution to discussions in the Family Law Council about such matters, and as well bring back to the Parliament the experience which they gained from those discussions. I believe that it is unfortunate that this recommendation was not taken up at an early stage and that there was no representation from the Parliament on the Family Law Council. It certainly was the desire and belief from evidence given to the Joint Committee that this would be a useful provision to make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst having some sympathy with the underlying thrust of what Senator Missen is saying, the Government is not disposed to accept this amendment. It has to be appreciated that section 115 of the Act as it now is does allow the Government to appoint either a magistrate or a member of parliament, as the case may be, to the Family Law Council. There is no prohibition on doing that. It simply does not require that such a person be appointed. I think there are difficulties about requiring an appointment of this kind. One is the question of getting the right balance on the particular organisation. Whilst it may be desirable for there to be lines into the Parliament, through whom should those lines be run? Should it be a Government member? Should it rather be an Opposition member, someone who has particular kinds of views? It would give rise to a degree of difficulty, I think .
—It would be one of each, would it not?

—It may be one of each, but then that is not one, it is more than one, and one of each would not include an Australian Democrat, I take it, as Senator Missen and I would readily accept. Certainly one from each party may not adequately reflect the spectrum of conservative to small 'l' Liberal views that are reflected in the Parliament. I think that, taking all of those factors into consideration, there is something to be said for not binding and restricting the Government in its appointments to the Council. I certainly take on board what Senator Missen has said, backed as it is by an explicit recommendation of the Joint Select Committee. I will certainly have regard to that when the next batch of appointments to the Family Law Council come up.
