I am not inclined to accept on behalf of the Government this amendment which would require us to adopt this particular cause. I understand that that was the attitude of the previous Government to this same proposal when it was first put.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (24) Page 45, at the end of sub-clause (1), add the following word and paragraph:
''; and (d) by omitting sub-section (9) and substituting the following sub- sections:

'(9) The Council shall, as soon as practicable after 30 June in each year, prepare and furnish to the Attorney-General a report of the operations of the Council during the year that ended on that 30 June.

'(10) The Attorney-General shall cause a copy of a report furnished to him under sub-section (9) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the receipt of the report by the Attorney- General.'.''.

What is proposed here is simply to make the reporting requirements for the Family Law Council the same as those for the Institute of Family Studies. There is no good reason why there should be different dates set for the production of such reports, and there is a considerable advantage, particularly in terms of the convenience of the Executive and legislators in considering these reports, to have them tabled and thus debated at more or less the same time each year. It is a purely administrative convenience matter, not one that would demand an amending Act of itself but rather an appropriate tidying up step to take in the course of a large scale amending Act of this kind. I commend it accordingly.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Proposed new clause 61A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Committee that I will not proceed with this amendment, which is No. (25) on the consolidated list. It is the language that is embodied in the separate Bill, the Family Law Amendment (Legal Aid Costs) Bill, which passed this Senate last night . Ultimately those provisions will find their way into the Act, but it may be that the House of Representatives will debate the other smaller Bill sooner than it will get around to debating this one. Since that was a Budget measure it was desired to put it separately. That is the reason for the withdrawal of the clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 62 (Costs).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Page 46, proposed new paragraph 117 (2A) (f), lines 13 to 16, leave out the proposed paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

''(f) whether either party to the proceedings has, in accordance with section 117C or otherwise, made an offer in writing to the other party to the proceedings to settle the proceedings and the terms of any such offer; and''.

This amendment relates to the determination of cost and what matters may be taken into account by the Family Court in determining these matters. One of the things in the Government's amendment, and this is to be found in clause 62(2A) ( f), is that what are taken into account are certain offers that are made under section 117C of the Act, specific offers which are filed in the Court. The Law Council of Australia's family law committee made a recommendation, which I do not think it has persisted with. However, I think it was a good idea and I certainly persist with it. I understand that the Government has some sympathy with it. The recommendation is:

This paragraph limits the relevance of offers made by a party to the other party, in determining the question of costs, to offers made under the proposed S .117C. It is suggested that other offers might be relevant whether or not made in accordance with the procedure established by the proposed S.117C.

The committee then proposes a form of amendment. The fact is, I think, that if various offers have been made, it is relevant and ought to be considered by the Family Court. Whether or not they fall within the specific category of the offers that are proposed under this new section or whether or not they are offers that have been made by a party to reduce the cost of proceedings, I think they ought to be known to the Court and the judge ought to be able to take them into account in determining whether or not there ought to be some order for costs. Therefore I think they fall into the same category and ought to be before the Court. That is why I have moved amendment No. (26) standing in my name.

In effect, these amendments relate to the removal of the proposal for increased publication of the proceedings of the Family Court. This matter is linked with another matter which went through rather swiftly and on which no comment was made; namely, the open courts proposal which at an earlier stage was not the subject of amendment and was carried. I, with a number of other senators and members of the House of Representatives on the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, took views critical of the proposal made by the majority of the Committee that there should be open courts. That seems to be acceptable to judges and therefore there seemed very little point in resisting that, although I think they have perhaps overlooked the importance of privacy in those proceedings.

Privacy is even more relevant in regard to the matter of publication which is now proposed. What I am trying to do in particular is cut out the increased publication which is provided under the Attorney-General's amendments to section 121 of the Family Law Act. It has been said that it will be all right, that in fact allowing the publication of certain proceedings will lead to a great deal more knowledge by people of what goes on in the courts and less suspicion of the courts. I believe there is a fair amount of nonsense in that argument. I really believe that the people who want publication of court proceedings are the people who want to take advantage of the titillating circumstances and who will go to no end of trouble to ensure that people are identified and that salacious views and salacious activities are given a great deal of prominence.

This question of publication was considered by the Family Law Council-it has generally supported an increase in publication-and in its fifth annual report in 1980-81 it drew, with some concern, attention to the necessity of looking carefully at the provisions that are made. I refer to paragraph 225 of its recommendations, although to be absolutely fair paragraph 224 states:

The Council has now adopted the view that the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee both in regard to s. 97 (1) (closed courts) and s. 121 ( restriction on publication of evidence) be implemented as soon as possible.
But in paragraph 225 it said this:

While supporting in general terms Joint Select Committee recommendation 60 that steps should be taken to relax the restrictions on publication in s. 121, provided that the names of parties or other identifying information is prohibited, the Council has resolved to recommend to the Attorney-General as follows:

(a) the legislation should operate so as to exclude from publication names of all parties and other involved persons, all names of places or addresses, and all other identifying features. This should not apply in relation to the identification of judges and legal practitioners;
(b) that particular regard should be had to the position of parties from small towns and communities where identification would be easier;
If I may say, I do not think that is satisfactorily covered in the amendments. Paragraph 225 continues:

(c) that published court lists should identify cases by application number only . The names of parties should not be used as this may allow identification if a report of the proceedings is subsequently published; and

(d) that particular regard should be had to the matter of television interviews of parties, even if not identified by name, as a person's voice and/or appearance are identifying features and the disclosure of one party's identity may well identify others involved in the proceedings; and
That is the nub of the problem here. The paragraph goes on:
(e) that power to authorise publication of a notice or report under s. 121 (5) (b) be maintained.

I know that the Government and the Attorney-General have gone to fair lengths to try to ensure that those details are not disclosed. Section 121, as proposed, says that an account of proceedings shall be taken to identify a person if:
(a) it contains any particulars of-
(i) the name, title, pseudonym or alias of the person;

Of course the point is made that it may be another person closely associated. If a person who is well known is involved in a television news coverage, and if some one who is known to be associated with that person-not necessarily a relation-goes into court and is shown going into court that may well tell everybody who he is.

Likewise, of course, we have the problem in relation to small towns and particular localities where people will know that proceedings are going on and there may be no identifying matters except the circumstances of the particular scandalous activity. The situation in which this might do the greatest damage is in relation to children whose parents are well known. They may be famous or have a particular interesting standing in the community. Those children can be quite scarified by the experience of having people know what has been going on. If the case relates, as often these cases do, to some unfortunate conduct by parties in regard to the question of whether they are suitable parents to have custody of a child, then I fear that that may be something that is identified and causes a great deal of trouble.

So far as witnesses are concerned, I think also that they may be identified and I very much doubt whether the terms in which the section has been phrased will be adequate. People who want to do so will put a carthorse through this section and will manage to get what they want. It will not be a matter of further edification and education of the community but rather of gratifying the tastes of the particulars newspapers-I do not need to describe them as all honourable senators will have them in mind-which have in the past made a lot of money out of this type of activity and interest.

I will not go to the wall over this matter; I suspect that the community, despite the fact that in the past and when we brought this Act into operation we thought that publication should not be allowed, has become convinced of the fact that there ought to be more publicity. People fear that judges may be performing rather badly behind closed doors. I do not think that publicity is going to make a difference to judges and their actions. I believe most judges perform in a judicial way and properly. There are others who, I think, behave badly on occasions. I do not think, therefore, that this change will do very much good at all. I think that this matter will be back before us if in fact we find that people succeed in getting through the restrictions that are in this proposed section. I hope that the clause is defeated, but I recognise that public opinion seems to be rather in favour of what is in the proposed section and rather against a person's privacy at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise, of course, the concerns that Senator Missen has expressed about maintaining absolutely the privacy of individuals in proceedings before the Family Court of Australia. I believe that, although he has moved his amendments with complete sincerity, he has rather over-reacted to the dangers as he has perceived them. What the amendments are essentially about is seeking to maintain absolute prohibition on the publication of any account at all of Family Court proceedings. That simply does not sit very easily with the decision in principle that the Committee has now taken in fact to allow those proceedings to be open to the public, subject to certain safeguards. If we accept the principle, which Senator Missen, of course, did not originally in the report of the Joint Committee on the Family Law Act but which he has in the debate in this chamber, that the courts themselves should be open, it really is a logical corollary of that that there should be able to be some reporting of the proceedings that take place there in order to put the spot light of public scrutiny on how the Court goes about its business to keep, as Senator Missen said, although he did not agree with the argument, judges on their toes, to keep the Court behaving properly and fairly. I believe that a degree of publication ought to be possible provided that the privacy safeguards are there and are strong. I believe that they are there and they are strong and that they will be stronger as a result of the next couple of amendments that are to be moved which will deal with, among other things, persons who may be incidentally mentioned in the course of proceedings, which was certainly an omission from the text of the amendment list as originally circulated.
—Have those amendments been circulated?
—It is not in the running sheet, but a further amendment to section 121 has been circulated separately to cover-

—It is not a surprise, because we are responding to the honourable senator's suggestion. SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator mentioned the capacity for witnesses to be identified at the moment. There are quite substantial penalties attaching to a newspaper or media organisation that went ahead nonetheless and said: 'Publish and be dammed'. Amendment (32) is consequential upon the passage of amendment (34). Amendment ( 34) prevents a registrar exercising his powers to make orders for urgent or interim maintenance where the application for the order is made on an ex parte basis. Amendment (32) is consequential upon that. The basic thrust of this series of amendments is to delegate to registrars certain powers of the Court, including in particular the power to make interim orders in all types of proceedings in which such orders are made. It has been recommended to the Government, notably by the Family Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia, that it is undesirable to have a Registrar making interim orders in proceedings where an interim order can, in fact, have some influence on what would be the final order. This is particularly so in custody proceedings and can be so in property proceedings. Accordingly, it has been recommended that the power of registrars to make substantive orders other than consent ones should be limited to urgent or interim maintenance proceedings. I have accepted this recommendation and amendment (33) will achieve that situation.

Amendment (34) will prevent a registrar making an urgent or interim maintenance order on an ex parte basis, as I mentioned a moment ago. The Law Council Committee also recommended that it should be put beyond doubt that a registrar cannot approve a maintenance agreement under section 87 as a consent order. I have also accepted this recommendation. One of the amendments, No. (33), the one that is the substance of this series-the others are really consequential upon it -implements this recommendation. This is all part of an attempt, basically, to streamline court procedure to take some of the burden in essentially routine matters off the judges and enable them get on with the business that they are best qualified and properly paid to do, and that is, resolve difficult questions of custody and property distribution.

The amendments are in substitution for the amendment to postponed new clause 4BA . On 24 August the Committee considered my amendment to the Family Law Act regarding counselling. That consideration is recorded at pages 188 to 201 of Hansard of 24 August. Considerable in principle support was expressed for the amendment and consideration was postponed to enable a redraft. It is for that purpose that I have drafted the amendments which I have just moved. The amendments take into account not only the broad questions that were raised in the Committee debate but also a number of criticisms which were levelled in varying degrees against the previous proposal. I point out that not everybody was opposed to the previous proposal, but people in the field considered that some failings were inherent in it. Those failings were that, whilst the objective of the previous amendment was attractive, its success was questionable given the fact that the counselling under the previous proposal could take place after the application for dissolution had been filed with the Family Court. It was considered that that was a failing. Another failing related to the fact that the chance of reconciliation diminishes the longer the couple is separated. That appears to be a general view held amongst practitioners in this area. The final problem with the previous amendment was that it was felt that it confused conciliation with reconciliation.

My current amendments overcome all those criticisms, as will be evidenced by a reading of them. The proposal envisages reconciliation counselling to take place well before the application for dissolution is filed. It takes into account the view that the possibility of reconciliation diminishes the longer the couple is separated, the converse of which is that the shorter the period the couple has been separated the more likely is the possibility of reconciliation. It certainly deals only with reconciliation and not conciliation. Thus, it has overcome the third hurdle in the previous amendment which confused conciliation with reconciliation.

The proposal seeks to enable a party to a marriage, who is living separately and apart from the other party, to file a notice stating that the parties to the marriage have separated and are living separately and apart. Upon receipt of that notice the amendments that I have moved will require the Principal Director of Court Counselling or the person who adminsters the counselling facilities of the Court of the State, not later than 14 days after the filing of the notice, to cause to be served on each party to the marriage a notice requiring that party to attend a reconciliation meeting with the counsellor and a reconciliation conference with the other party to the marriage and the counsellor for the purpose of considering the legal, social and financial consequences of a dissolution of the marriage and, in particular, the effects of a dissolution of the marriage on any children of the marriage and, having regard to the consequences and effects referred to, of considering the possibility of a reconciliation. Of course, those words were used in the previous debate. Another word that was used was the desirability of reconciliation. But, as I understand it, that is inherently a question for the individuals themselves. Of course, the requirement would be on the counsellor to point out the consequences of the dissolution of marriage and, having regard to those consequences and the effects , point out the need for the parties to consider a reconciliation. Whether they do so is up to them.

A major feature of this proposal is that anything that is said in these reconciliation meetings and conferences will not be admissible in any court. That is an important matter as it will allow free flow of discussion to take place. My amendments also seek an amendment of section 44 of the Family Law Act which would provide that, if there is a subsequent application for dissolution of the marriage, that shall not, without the leave of the court, be filed by a party to a marriage after the expiration of 12 months commencing at the commencement of Part II of the Family Law Amendment Act unless that party or the other party to the marriage has filed a notice of separation and a period not less than 12 months has elapsed since the filing of that notice, and unless there is filed with the application a certificate stating that the parties have, pursuant to notices served on them under section 15A (2), attended interviews and a conference for the purposes set out in paragraphs (c) and (d) of section 15A (2). Of course, there are provisions which entitle the Court to give leave for an application for dissolution to be filed where there are special circumstances notwithstanding that those procedural motions have not been undertaken. That is provided for in the amendments.

We have come to the dying stages of this long debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill. But, if we look back at what we have done, we really have done nothing, in all of the amendments that we have moved and adopted in the Parliament, to give legislative support to the institution of marriage. If honourable senators take an objective look at that, they will see that we have done absolutely nothing. On the contrary, in my view, we have undermined the institution of marraige somewhat by our vote in respect of proposed new section 98A. This is the very last opportunity we will have of giving some genuine legislative support to the institution of marriage. An opportunity like this may not occur for a considerable period.

The tragedy of divorce is quite evident. The latest figures put out by the Institute of Family Studies show that, if we assume that 1982 divorce rates apply throughout the lifetime of newly married couples, 40 per cent of all those marriages will end in divorce. That is startling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is startling by comparison with other countries-47 per cent in the United States, 38 per cent in England.

—Senator Evans says that the figure is 47 per cent in the United States and 38 per cent in England and Wales, but it is 27 per cent in New Zealand. A number of things have been said about the cost, and no doubt they will be canvassed in the debate. I have not got time now, but at a later stage, I will detail the cost of divorce in this country. Unless something is done that cost will escalate.
—The social cost, do you mean?

—I am not referring to the social cost. I am referring to the monetary cost at this stage. There has also been some suggestion, but no proof, that required reconciliation at the earliest stage is not successful. I have here the books which have been quoted. Gerald Sanctuary, for example, does not provide evidence for an assertion that required reconciliation in areas where there is no fault divorce is not beneficial. I would have thought that even those who are indissolubly wedded to the no fault divorce concept could lend themselves to supporting this proposal for reconciliation in the earliest stages so that those persons will have a chance and the devastating effects of divorce in Australia will be diminished.

—Very briefly, as Senator Harradine has said, we have spent days and days in this chamber debating legislation that will make it easier for people to get a divorce but does nothing to uphold the institution of marriage, even though the legislation states that that is its prime aim. I am appalled by the figures that have just been quoted. We have known that that is the situation, but the fact that Senator Evans can quote figures to us from other countries that are worse than ours does not mean that we in this chamber should not attempt to do something, no matter how small and no matter how much we may think it may not work. We have been told that you can lead a horse to water but you cannot make it drink, that making sure that people attend counselling services will not make them accept it. I am not saying they will; they certainly will not in a majority of cases. But if it works for a very few, if it works for just one per cent, then the country will be far better off. We have instances in other areas of the law where there is compulsory counselling. Indeed, it is included in new legislation with which we will be dealing, the sex discrimination legislation. Under that legislation the commissioner can compel people to get together. I see no problem in this, and I hope the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) will accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped that it might be possible, since we last debated this matter, to reach some kind of accommodation with Senator Harradine, but I regret to advise that that is not so . I am obliged to oppose the proposed amendment for reasons that I will spell out. Although Senator Harradine's revised compulsory counselling amendments are different in form from his previous amendments to section 14 (6), their fundamental purpose clearly remains unchanged, that is, that no person can be divorced without having counselling. I acknowledge that Senator Harradine's revised amendment provides for that counselling to take place before filing for divorce, as opposed to pre-hearing counselling, but it is, nonetheless, still compulsory counselling. The amendment is not couched in such a way that that counselling must take place right at the outset, at the time of separation or shortly thereafter, which on all evidence available to us is the only time that such counselling is likely to be practically successful in achieving reconciliation.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic scheme which Senator Harradine proposes is that an intending divorcee will be unable, without the leave of the Court, to file a divorce application unless at least 12 months have elapsed since that person or his or her spouse has filed a notice of separation in the Family Court and the intending divorcees have attended, separately and together, counselling with a marriage counsellor and certificates in evidence of this attendance are filed in the divorce application. That is the scheme of the proposal. It is clearly to require a compulsory step to be taken before the filing for the divorce, but still some considerable distance down the track from the time, as a practical matter, the marriage is first showing signs of breaking up or when the parties first separate. There is no requirement, nor could there be probably, as a practical matter, for the counselling process to be set in train any earlier than that.

While I have supported in principle the amendment originally proposed by Senator Harradine and still in many ways do because it is aimed at legislative reinforcement for the institution of marriage, the reservations about this that I have outlined before-the cost of it, its compulsory character and the likely counter-productive effect it has, and the low success rate in any event of compulsory counselling which does not take place right at the outset of a marriage crisis situation-still continue to apply. Since the debate on the proposed amendment was adjourned--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they apply?

—I will go through that with Senator Harradine in a moment, certainly as to the cost aspect of it, which ultimately comes to the crunch. Since the debate was adjourned I have received, as I believe other senators may have, numerous representations from counselling organisations and professional bodies opposing the amendment. A telephone survey which was conducted by officers of my Department of all approved marriage counselling organisations showed that they wholeheartedly opposed the amendment. They were not doing it on the basis of the cost considerations; they were doing it on the basis of the unlikelihood that it would achieve anything in the circumstances in which it was proposed to be put.
—You are talking about the previous amendment.

—Yes, but what I am saying is that, in substance, the content of that amendment has not changed. I can repeat it only so often, but there is no requirement, and Senator Harradine must acknowledge this, that counselling take place at the time the marriage is breaking up, at the time the first separation occurs, within six months of the separation having occurred. The only requirement that Senator Harradine is legislatively posing is that the counselling take place before the filing for dissolution. Of course it may be the case that the counselling takes place earlier, and if it does, well so much the better, even though it would still be compulsory in character and there is still a negative psychological factor, we are told by counselling organisations, associated with that compulsion. But it is the combination of things, the compulsion and the inability for the counselling process to bite-
—But they have not had any experience of this.
—I am sorry; Senator Harradine will have another go-
—Not of compulsory counselling as envisaged here.
—But they have for under two-year marriages.

—It is exactly the same as operates-as Senator Missen has just said-for early marriages at the moment. There are certain technical distinctions which Senator Harradine has endeavoured to accommodate and to draw. But they do not go to the substance of the counselling environment as it will occur in practice. It will be perceived as a compulsion, a compulsory step that has to be gone through before the parties can file, and it will not be required at that very early threshold state where all the literature tells us and all the experience tells us the counselling may have some success in accomplishing reconciliation. The final point that really has to move the Government, even if all the other considerations were balanced the other way-which I believe they are not-is that the resource consideration simply cannot be ignored by any responsible government.

SPEECH.PARA: An idea of the cost of the proposal can be gained by considering the increased staffing and other resources the Family Court and approved marriage counselling organisations would require to implement it. Let me go through the figures. In 1980-the last year for which we have separate section 14 (6) counselling statistics available-there were just 523 completed compulsory conferences. There is no significant percentage increase in the number of conferences under that section since that date. Under Senator Harradine's amendment which would require three counselling sessions per divorce application on the basis of some 44,000 divorces taking place each year, that would mean another 132,000 compulsory pre- divorce counselling conferences per annum would have to be provided for. Even when one compares that with the total counselling case load of the Family Court the situation is, as advised to me by the Principal Registrar of the Family Court, that Senator Harradine's amendment would increase the present case load of the counselling services and organisations by between 100 and 200 per cent. If all this counselling were to be done by the Family Court itself, the first estimate of cost that I have from the Principal Registrar of the Family Court, when we take into account--

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, it would not be, of course.
—It would not be what?
—It would not be done by the Court facilities because they say they would rather it be done by the marriage counselling organisations.

—That may be so, but we still have to find the resources. Just to give an order of magnitude of the figures that are involved, what we would be talking about here is literally tens of millions of dollars when the extra counsellors required, the support staff and the facilities to go with it are all taken into account. The estimate for approved marriage counselling organisations is that what would be required are around 140 additional full time counsellors, at least two years involved for recruitment and training of the people in question, larger counselling premises to accommodate new staff and additional subsidies for servicing remote areas. I do not endeavour to put a precise costing figure on it, but obviously the magnitude of the task that we are here talking about is absolutely phenomenal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack suggested earlier in this debate that people could pay for their counselling, they could make a substantial financial contribution and thus this cost factor would be leavened out in that way. But the reality of the matter is- I am sure Senator Durack appreciates this; it is largely simply a debating point that he is making-that not all people will be able to afford this. To the extent that one can give anything more than simply intuitive evidence of that I can say this: In 1982 the filing fee for Family Court divorce applications was remitted on the grounds of financial hardship in fully 23 per cent of cases.

The other point about this, quite apart from the raw, hardship circumstance, is that all the evidence coming to us from counselling organisations is that if counselling is to have any chance of success it has to encourage people to enter the process at a very early stage. What we are talking about in the context of a fee being payable is clearly the discouragement of that occurring. All of these things might be able to be put to one side if there is any real or overwhelming evidence that the system operating in this way, with the extra 132,000 counselling consultations each year, would do something about significantly increasing the reconciliation rate among potential divorcees. But again the evidence is simply that this will not work. In the present section 14 (6) pre- hearing counselling conference for two-year marriages the success rate is of the order of only one per cent. It may be with the variations from that--

TALK.START.PARA: —But please understand that that is a different matter.
—Okay, but even if the honourable senator doubles or triples--
—It is not a conference you are talking about under section 14 (6) at the moment.

—Senator Harradine has to relate the prospect of reconciliation success to something in the existing real world. The closest approximation we have is of compulsory counselling taking place in the context of section 14 (6). I readily acknowledge that there are procedural differences contemplated in Senator Harradine's proposal as compared with section 14 (6) as it does operate in that context. What I am putting to the Committee is that those differences are not so substantial and not so qualitatively different as could encourage one to a belief that there would be a fundamentally different rate of success flowing from this, given all the considerations I have referred to.
—But existing 14 (6) does not provide for counselling separately and together. That is a qualitative difference.

—Mr Chairman, I do not think I can add anything else useful to this debate except perhaps to say this: Too often people do see marriage counselling as a service of last resort. If anything, I believe that Senator Harradine's amendment probably encourages that view. It helps to identify marriage counselling with divorce and with the final steps of marriage breakdown . I would prefer to see counselling identified rather with the improvement of the quality of married life. With that in mind the Government has made available very substantial increases in funding to marriage counselling organisations. Counselling is crucial-reconciliation counselling, not just post-breakdown counselling. It must be encouraged. It needs to be paid for by government. The kind of ad hoc, after the event, ex-post counselling of the kind that is being proposed by Senator Harradine-for all its good intentions which I share-I believe, the Government believes and all the marriage counselling organisations we have consulted in the process of reacting to this proposal believe, simply cannot work. For that reason I suggest the amendments be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the Attorney-General has rejected Senator Harradine's amendments. In many ways I see more difficulties of a practical nature in the more elaborate amendments that are now before us than I did with the earlier amendment, which was of a more simple kind and I think may well have been of more practical application. Nevertheless the situation is, as the Attorney-General has conceded, that some real attempt has to be made to persuade people, either before or after they separate, that they should be forced to consider the question of reconciliation. Certainly the earlier that is done, the better.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand Senator Harradine's proposals that are now before us, there are some inbuilt provisions which would encourage notices to be given and for marriage counselling to take place as soon as possible after the reconciliation. It seems as though, on looking at one of the amendments, an application for dissolution cannot be filed unless a notice of separation has been filed and a period of not less than 12 months has elapsed since the filing of that notice. That amendment would seem to be encouraging people to take this step as soon as possible if they want to get the full benefit of the 12-month separation. In any event, I am not altogether satisfied with the views of the marriage counselling people. I believe that the overwhelming view of the marriage counsellors, certainly those attached to the Court, is that their role is to counsel people and conciliate differences that arise in relation to custody, property or whatever else in the divorce process, but that the object of marriage counselling seems to be to assist people through the dissolution process.

What Senator Harradine and I are driving at-and what, I think, the Attorney- General himself has conceded-is that we want to have a new approach to counselling which is to try to persuade and assist people to reconsider their decisions to separate. In effect, it should be to dissuade them from separating. If any impact is to be made in lessening the incidence of divorce in this country, some new approach of that sort has to be taken. I did not make my suggestion about the fact that people might pay for this in a debating or a frivolous sense. People should be prepared to make some contribution towards making one of the most important, if not the most important, decisions they will face up to in their lives. Assistance from marriage counselling organisations is not likely to be particularly expensive. Certainly, in a proportion of cases-it may be as high as 20 per cent-it may be able to be proved that the people concerned cannot afford to pay a filing fee. That must be a pretty generous estimate, considering the size of the filing fee, but putting that aside and assuming that the figure is that high, it still represents less than a quarter of the people who would be obtaining counselling. When we consider the amount of money people spend on all sorts of other things that they see as having some merit, having to pay a fee to a marriage counsellor, I would have thought, would not be a particularly onerous burden in view of its importance. It may well be that only a small proportion of these counselling sessions are successful, but even if it is only a small proportion, I would think that that would be--

TALK.START.PARA: —One per cent would be all right.

—Well, that figure might be a bit low. But I really think that it is far too soon to say that the marriage counselling provisions would fail. If the counsellors participating tried to make it work and after a period of experimentation it did not work, I would be prepared to--
—If you were sitting over here would you be copping this amendment? That is the real test.

—If I were sitting over there we would be a government taking a far more responsible attitude to the overall costs and outlays of government. When the Government proceeds to spend billions of dollars more than the previous Government ever dreamt of spending-and we are talking about billions of dollars- and then says that a few million dollars more would be required for this purpose , I think it ought to look again at its priorities, cut down on some of its other expenditure and allocate some funds for this purpose. This is purely a question of government priorities. It is certainly not that the Government cannot afford to implement this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to say that I oppose this amendment. I am opposed to compulsory things of this sort. It is very easy in this chamber to talk as though getting people together for counselling will bring them back together and they will not be divorced. People in this community have for the most part made up their minds by the time they separate. Divorce proceedings are not really entered into lightly by most people. Those who enter into them lightly will not be affected or helped by this provision at all. The question of cost to the Government and to individuals is important.

SPEECH.PARA: If this amendment were passed, people would be told that as taxpayers they would pay for a lot more people to be employed in doing what in most cases is unnecessary and useless work. I am sure that other counselling work could be more usefully done in relation to both ongoing counselling and after-divorce counselling with regard to children and so forth. I believe this would be essentially a waste of money by the community and would force people whose financial situation is often difficult-for example, they may have to provide two homes and the like-to spend extra money. This is not the time to require them to do something which they see as nothing but a farce and something they are required to do in order to get their divorce. Those of us who have practised in this jurisdiction know what requirements in the law in the past had to be brought to the attention of those seeking a divorce. Such things tended to be regarded as mere formalities. The amendment which I will move when we go back to clause 16 will emphasise the availability of these things and--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it will not.
—I am sorry, the amendment has been drafted to achieve that purpose.
—It will not because it deals only with conciliation.
—It deals with conciliation, and conciliation is a much wider thing.
—No, it deliberately deals with conciliation.
—That is not what we are talking about; we are talking about reconciliation.
—Senator Walters is talking about reconciliation. I am saying that conciliation throughout is a much wider concept and it covers reconciliation.
—No, it does not.

—We will wait until we get to that amendment to discuss that point. Senator Walters will have her chance to speak then. This amendment is really an attempt to put a further hurdle in the paths of people so that they may fall at the barrier. There is in Senator Harradine's proposal a provision for people to avoid the counselling if they can show there are special circumstances under which the hearings should proceed. What on earth are those special circumstances? What do they relate to? The terms are so vague and so wide that people would be put to providing various evidence and so forth to establish those circumstances.
—The judges would be able to tell.

—One cannot tell what judges might require as evidence of special circumstances. The use of the term could well give judges an opportunity to be very difficult, or to be not difficult, depending on what they regarded as special circumstances.
—You have already voted for that. You have already voted for a clause which says exactly that.
—I have not done so with regard to compulsory counselling.
—You did, and I will tell you how you did it directly.
—No, I have not voted for compulsory counselling at all.
—You have not been following the debate.

—Senator Harradine has not always followed the debate either. As I said, I have not voted for compulsory counselling. I do not believe in things of this nature being compulsory. Therefore, I think that this amendment would only serve to waste the money of the community and of persons who are already engaged in litigation in the divorce courts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Here we have a most extraordinary thing. The comments of both Senator Evans, the Attorney-General, and Senator Missen show that neither of them is aware of what we have already done in respect of compulsory reconciliation counselling in an amendment which was moved by the Attorney-General himself. I refer Senator Missen to page 2 of the revised issue of amendments, the very good document that the officers of the Senate have prepared to assist us in our following of this debate. I draw attention to the fact that this is an amendment that was moved by the Attorney-General and agreed to. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: An application for dissolution of a marriage shall not, without the leave of the court granted under sub-section (1C), be filed within the period of 2 years after the date of the marriage unless there is filed with the application a certificate in the prescribed form . . . stating that the parties to the marriage have considered a reconciliation, with the assistance of a specified person or organization, being-
and then it says who-
signed by that person or on behalf of that organisation, as the case may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the two years clause.
—Yes; but just a minute. Look at what it says there, Senator Missen. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding sub-section (1B), if the court is satisfied that there are special circumstances . . .

Senator Missen has already voted for that, so why did he raise the question as to what are special circumstances? That is a red herring, and he knows it. So much for his opposition to this amendment. I suggest that his opposition to the amendment is based on his view of marriage. If he wants that view, all right, but so far as--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is my view of marriage? What do you know about it?

—We canvassed that in a previous debate. Perhaps Senator Missen wants me to read the interjection. I will just refer honourable senators to the interjection that was made by Senator Missen in one of my speeches. That is the basis on which I have just made that remark. I do so only on the basis of what is said in this Parliament. I refer to that interjection. So that disposes of Senator Missen's opposition to this proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just say this about the matters raised by the Attorney-General. He has raised the matter of compulsion; the fact that the chance of reconciliation diminishes the longer the couple have been separated; the question of section 14 (6) of the principal Act, which is again the compulsory aspect; and, most importantly, the matter of costs. He says that he is concerned about the fact that my proposal will not ensure early enough the reconciliation procedures to be followed. I am perfectly happy to amend my amendment to provide that these shall take place within six months; but, as the Attorney-General says, nor could there be such a proposal, because obviously there are machinery difficulties, and not only in the system itself and in the approved marriage counselling organisations but with the parties themselves. Of course, one could not draw it in that way, so that disposes of that problem.

As regards 'compulsory', as I said before, there is no hard evidence whatsoever to show that compulsory conferences in a no fault situation are not beneficial. What the Marriage Guidance Council and the approved marriage counselling organisations are saying is that under the existing section 14 (6) those procedures have not been successful. In fact, they have met with very little success.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the really significant difference between yours and section 14 (6)?

—The significant difference is the fact, as the marriage counselling organisations say, that there is very little chance of a successful reconciliation without both of the parties to the marriage attending the conference. The fact remains that section 14 (6) at present does not require the attendance of both parties at a conference. This is a compulsory conference idea , and the compulsory conference idea is widespread in conflict situations within Australia. As I mentioned in my speech on the previous proposal, they are widespread in industrial relations situations and in other conflict situations, including, as has been said, the sex discrimination legislation that is coming down the track, under which compulsory conferences will be required for the resolution of disputes in that area of human conflict. As I said on the previous occasions on which we were debating this matter, if it is good enough for industrial disputes and for disputes on the whole range of personal conflicts, surely it is good enough for problems which affect the basic institution of society. If there were a chance-it is conceded that one must get them early enough-obviously there is a likelihood of success.

SPEECH.PARA: The other significant difference about the current section 14 (6) is that it is really compulsory reconciliation after the application for the divorce has been filed and before the court hears it. Certainly that is divorce talk. At that stage the married partners are so separated in their viewpoints that one of them has filed for a divorce. One of them has not threatened 'I shall divorce you', but has done it, has filed for divorce.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is a filing of a notice of separation if not a preliminary to divorce?
—That is a different situation altogether.
—It is still on the same track.

—No, it is not necessarily on the same track at all. That is the point about being wedded to the no fault divorce concept. I happen not to be wedded to it. If one is wedded to that concept, an ultimate application does not have to include anything other than that there has been a separation of 12 months. It does not have to be that someone has been abusive, adulterous or anything else. So the divorce talk and that sort of problem is not there. If a person files a notification, that person may be filing the notification because he or she is confused. I suggest that most people at that stage would be confused. Surely we must appreciate that. Of course, the Director of Court Counselling is the one who orders the parties into conference, not the approved marriage counselling organisation though, as the Attorney-General's officers themselves realise, the approved marriage counselling organisations have more show of obtaining a reconciliation because of all the situations relating to those organisations, and so on, than does the court counselling service with all its facilities. I do not know why they say that but it appears to be a generally held view. That is a basic difference between section 14 (6) which has been shown to be not successful and the proposal that I have put forward. It is an absolutely essential difference. The reconciliation counselling takes place after the application has been filed. On the one hand, this is not so. It is simply after a notice that the person has been separated and is living apart. That is when counselling takes place at the early stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The last matter is the question of costs. That has not been quantified, but what has been quantified is the very dramatic cost to the community of divorce in Australia. That cost is contained in the cost of the Federal Court apparatus, the payments made to the Australian Legal Aid Office and the payments that we talked about last night. The Attorney-General was very concerned about the increase. Payments that are made to the private legal profession for legal aid purposes in family law matters are sky rocketing and he was concerned about that . The cost to the community does not end there. In 1982 $717.4m was paid out in widow's pensions and well over half those people receiving the widow's pension were divorcees or separated wives. Again, almost 70 per cent of those people receiving the supporting parent's benefit, at a cost in 1982 of $605.9m, are separated wives or de factos, which is an increase of more than 300 per cent since 1975. As I have mentioned to the Senate, the most recent figures published by the Institute of Family Studies show that the divorce rate in Australia is now 40 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Let us finish at half-past.

—It is all very well for the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, to say let us finish at half-past. I was noting the length of his speeches. He takes the full quarter of an hour, although I can never understand why. If he took two seconds or two minutes in his reply to us and answered our questions quickly and concisely then we would get through this matter.
—Why don't you do a deal?

—I am trying to do a deal. Senator Harradine's amendment, as I see it, is one that is already enshrined in this legislation for the two year separation period. If we believe-as we all do in the Senate because it was passed-that with a marriage of two years, compulsory counselling can be undertaken and can be effective, even if it is only in a minor degree, then I believe that we are being irresponsible in not having a go. If, after a certain period, we find that this proposal does not work we can stop it. Counselling is done at a much earlier time in marriages of longer duration. If we find that this proposal does not work, then we can stop it. But at least if we give it a go for a period, we will feel that we have done all we can in this area. I would support the Attorney at least giving the proposal a go, perhaps with the addition of a sunset clause, if he likes. That is my suggestion, that there be a sunset clause for this particular amendment. I suggest that we give it a period of say, five years, or something like that and at the end of that time the Attorney could come back and say 'I told you so and that is the situation' or he could leave it there.
-The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has not responded-I do not mind how long he takes to respond-to the point that I made. He has made statements here which are patently not correct.
—What are you talking about?

—I am talking about section 14 (6). The Attorney-General's Department has made the survey on the basis of section 14 (6) which has absolutely nothing to do with this matter. I concede that it might have been relevant when considering the previous proposal but it is not relevant now. I was prepared, quite frankly, to ensure that the objections, all apart from costs , were met and that is what I have done in this amendment. I took notice of what the Department said and what the marriage guidance organisation were saying. They were not saying these things to the Attorney-General only, they were saying them to me. I took notice of that and I have come up with this particular amendment which, as I indicate, I understood was a matter which had some currency within the Department.

—I was endeavouring to observe Senator Walters's strictures and not to get to my feet simply to repeat points I had made earlier on. But quickly, the answers are these: Of course there are differences, which I acknowledged in my opening speech, in the section 14 (6) model and the one that Senator Harradine proposes, to the extent that section 14 (6) does not require the compulsory conference concept of getting both parties together. The reconciliation counselling can take place, in a way, at the discretion of the counsellor and there is that difference. It may be that in practice something will flow from that but Senator Harradine cannot produce any evidence for the greater likelihood of counselling of that kind being successful because there is none available to him or to us other than in analogous areas such as industrial relations and so on.
—That is right.

—There are many points of similarity and difference but I suggest he is really flying on a wing and a prayer, with respect, to try to build an edifice based on that kind of analogy and that kind of metaphor. Really , all I am saying is that the similarities between his present model and the original one are still there, namely, that it is a compulsory process and it is not a process that will operate compulsorily right at the outset when the marriage breakdown first occurs and when the separation first occurs. He has acknowledged that in the nature of things that cannot be achieved. So the prospects of there being a greater degree of success here are not particularly great on all the evidence available to us about the likely reaction of people to compulsory situations. At least they are not so great as to justify the massive allocation of resources. The particular figures that I have-and I cannot quite believe them; that is why I did not put them into the debate-are $26m a year on the basis of no contribution from individuals. But whatever they are, they are certainly well over the $10m mark and I simply say that, if we do a cost benefit equation, the benefits are not so certain. Indeed, they are so problematic that it would simply be irresponsible, given the kind of advice we are getting from these organisations, to make this compulsory process, even in the revised format , part of the Family Law Act. I am afraid I cannot add anything more to it. Could we possibly get this point at least to a resolution tonight?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Cyclophosphamide

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advised Senator Grimes, the Acting Minister for Health, that I would be speaking in the adjournment debate as this is a matter which relates to the portfolio he is administering at present. I will not need to take terribly long. A doctor from Queensland wrote to me just a few days ago to say that a patient of his suffering from a rare disease, dermatomyositis, was being treated with the drug cyclophosphamide. As Senator Grimes will know, that is a drug normally used in the treatment of cancer. What has happened is that the drug is no longer available as a pharmaceutical benefit. The reason it is no longer available is that the drug company and the Department of Health are in dispute over the question of the price of the medication. I wish to speak briefly on this subject. Cyclophosphamide is a very powerful anti-cancer drug. It has been used for a number of years in the treatment of malignant disease. It has been found also to be effective in the treatment of certain rare diseases where immune systems are disturbed and it is prescribed by immunologists for certain of those diseases. Because it is an anti-cancer drug, some questions of occupational safety arose, among other things. The company had to put a large amount of capital expenditure into its Australian plant. Production costs have doubled and, in any event, the company has been in dispute with three Ministers for Health over the costs which the drug should attract as a pharmaceutical benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not mind that there is a dispute and I do not really mind how it is resolved, but the effect of the dispute has been that the drug has been delisted by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) because the company proceeded to raise the price. The drug will now cost a patient who has to buy it outside something like $20 every time he buys a normal prescription, which is fifty 50-milligram tablets. There is no remission of that $20 cost by way of pharmaceutical benefit , although it has been a pharmaceutical benefit until now. I have checked with one of the leading immunologists in this country, Professor Ronald Penny, whom Senator Grimes would know, as to whether or not it is a true bill of goods, whether or not the drug is essential for the purpose which concerns me. There are few people in Australia-the drug company tells me it might involve only 200 to 300 prescriptions a year-who have these rare diseases for which this is the best drug. I am told by Professor Penny that there are indirect substitutes available but no direct substitutes. Other drugs only modify the situation, they do not control it. If patients are inpatients in hospitals, say they are being treated for certain malignancies, they can have the drug given to them, but if they are outpatients, as some of these patients with chronic immunological disorders are, they can no longer get the drug.

The dispute is clearly one involving the pricing of drugs. It is a very difficult area; these disputes do arise. My concern is that it is these patients who are the meat in the sandwich. I am not asking the Minister or the Government to give in or to resolve the matter in some inappropriate way. What I am asking the Minister to do is make some interim administrative arrangement so that the patients are not the ones who suffer. Surely there is a specific case in which no other drug will do. The dispute is an administrative dispute between government and industry, and the number of prescriptions is very small. Because it is the patients who are suffering, some arrangement is necessary.

I believe that the case for the use of this medication is a valid one. It is sparingly used, it is used in the hands of experts, and some of the patients are suffering real disadvantage because of what has happened. Patients cannot afford the kind of cost involved, although they may have to. A price of $20 for each 50 tablet prescription will be a great imposition on them. I ask the Government: Is it not possible to devise some administrative arrangement so that the patients are removed from this conflict? The Government can then take as long as it likes to resolve it, and may the best man win.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GRIMES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Acting Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume let me know this afternoon that he would raise this evening the matter of the delisting of cyclophosphamide. Unfortunately, through a series of circumstances, I do not have the full details. As I understand it, the company has been in dispute, as Senator Baume says, with several Ministers for Health. The drug was delisted because the company unilaterally increased the price without agreement by the Government. As Senator Baume says, it is a special and difficult case. The drug is of great use to a small number of people ; he says a couple of hundred, and that is probably right. There is no reasonable alternative, and I think it is sensible that we try to get some administrative arrangements at least for those few patients who can in this unusual circumstance clearly be delineated. The whole situation can be quarantined to those few patients.

SPEECH.PARA: I will seek advice from the Department of Health, of which I am the Acting Minister at the moment, and get a reply for Senator Baume as soon as possible. We certainly cannot have a situation where patients are the meat in the sandwich in a dispute between government and industry. That would be unfair and I will see what can be done in the near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.37 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Are disability pensions payable under the Repatriation Act 1920 disregarded for the purpose of the income test for any pension or benefit payable under the Social Security Act 1947; if so, what are the details and what is the reason for disregarding disability pensions for this or these pensions or benefits, and why does a similar situation not prevail for all other social security pensions and benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: If a disability pension is received by a person in receipt of unemployment or sickness benefit it is disregarded for income test purposes.

The exception to this is where the sickness benefit is paid for the same incapacity as the disability pension. In this instance the amount of disability pension is deducted from the maximum rate of sickness benefit otherwise payable to ensure that two separate forms of assistance are not paid concurrently for the same incapacity.

Where a disability pension is received by a person in receipt of an age, invalid or widow's pension, supporting parent's benefit or similar assistance, that payment is taken into account for income test purposes.

Disability pensions are paid under the Repatriation Act and associated legislation, and as such are seen as a form of compensation to ex-servicemen and women and their dependants for death or various degrees of incapacity related to service for their country in the defence forces.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the results of an investigation carried out by the Castaing Commission for the French Government which show that :

(a) there is no solution for long term disposal of radioactive waste and that projected packaging in glass, cement or asphalt may not be considered as definitive and moreover, there are no regulations in France to define the conditions for disposal;
(b) France does not have important safety systems drawn up for the operation of reprocessing plants;

(c) the Commission recommended that the reprocessing process be extended to remove not only the uranium and plutonium, but also long lived toxic alpha- emitters, neptunium, americium and curium, because of their long life, above 10, 000 years, which is said posed a greater risk than plutonium;

(d) considering the cost of reprocessing has risen nine times since 1970 and the capacity to reprocess is lagging way behind, that final disposal of irradiated fuel rods should be regarded as an alternative to reprocessing; and
(e) the price of a kilowatt hour produced by a fast breeder will be two to three times higher than the kilowatt hour produced by a conventional reactor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My attention has been drawn to the results of the study carried out by the Castaing Commission, which assesses the options currently available to France for the management of spent fuel from the nuclear fuel cycle, namely immediate reprocessing, delayed reprocessing and no reprocessing. It is the type of investigation any country utilising nuclear power should perform from time to time to enable a realistic understanding of the extent and nature of future requirements. The essential message of the report is one of caution against premature commitment to a particular option pending a fuller examination of alternatives.

(a) The Commission considered that final proof had not yet been offered with regard to the long term disposal of radioactive waste. It therefore recommended against the irretrievable disposal of solidified high level waste or unreprocessed spent fuel at the present time and advocated more French research into deep geological burial. Such research would be directed at minimising current margins for uncertainty with regard to the containment of long-lived alpha-emitting actinides.

(b) The report noted that a satisfactory safety record had been maintained at existing French reprocessing plants, but significant technical improvements and a detailed safety analysis remained to be made in the case of new plants still at the design stage.

(c) The report considered that there was no uncertainty about the ability of borosilicate glass to provide adequate containment of high-level waste in the short and medium term. However, the Commission was concerned about the potential radiological dose from neptunium-237 in high-level waste and unreprocessed spent fuel, together with that from americium-241 and curium 245, which form neptunium -237 by radioactive decay. It therefore recommended that separation of long- lived emitters of alpha particles (neptunium, americium and curium) from fission products should be investigated for possible application in future reprocessing plants. The separated actinides would undergo special treatment, including immobilisation in ceramics such as Synroc, or nuclear transmutation. Neptunium separation would not involve any major technological difficulty but americium separation, which is currently being investigated at the French Atomic Energy Commission (CEA), would require considerable research and development prior to its commercial application. Industrial implementation of these processes in France was envisaged by the end of the century.

The potential significance of neptunium-237 arises from the revision in 1979 by the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) of estimates of radiation dose from ingestion of certain radionuclides. In its revision, the ICRP noted there was considerable uncertainty in the data, which was based on a small number of experiments on rats, and that ingestion of neptunium in trace quantities or incorporated in food may reduce its absorption by a factor of 10. Studies on the absorption of neptunium are being carried out in the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The technology for removing long-lived radionuclides from high level wastes for separate treatment has been studied by the Commission of the European Communities. In 1982, the International Atomic Energy Agency concluded that such removal was unlikely to be cost-effective in reduction of potential dose from waste repositories.
(d) The Commission recommended intensive research on the behaviour of irradiated fuel in deep storage conditions.

(e) The Commission concluded from one economic assessment that the cost per kilowatt hour (kWh) generated by a fast breeder reactor (FBR) could be two to three times that for a conventional pressurised water reactor (PWR), and from another that costs could be competitive. The Commission recommended that the French Government should take appropriate measures to ensure that satisfactory data on such costs are obtained. A number of countries are proceeding with FBR research and development programs in the expectation that when factors such as cost of electricity production, safety, nuclear waste management, energy supply security and non-proliferation objectives are taken into account, the fast breeder reactor will be a viable option.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what criteria did the Department of Social Security decide on a ' notional return rate of 10 per cent' to be applied to non-exempt assets in determining entitlement to pensions under the proposed new assets test.
(2) Will the rate be subject to change, if so, in what circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I refer the honourable senator to my parliamentary statement of 23 August 1983 (Senate Hansard of 23 August 1983). Therein, I stated that the Government has decided that the proposed assets test will follow in broad terms that which applied prior to November 1976. Under the pre-November 1976 test the notional rate of return applied was 10 per cent and the legislation then in force did not provide for that rate to be varied. I also stated that the final details of how the new test will work in pactice will not be settled until after I have consulted with pensioner organisations. That process is not yet complete.
